Some years ago the Hawke Government introduced a policy of progressive budget cuts for Commonwealth departments, in line with its general macro-economic strategies. At the same time the Government made moves towards program budgeting concepts and indicated its intention that departments were expected to respond to this new found freedom by implementing substantial efficiency reforms and by precise targeting of Commonwealth expenditures to the areas most in need.

In the early stages of these reforms the means by which these objectives were to be achieved were left up to departments themselves. Many responded in kind to the budget cuts by simply projecting them uniformly across all departmental activities. In line with the old principles of equity, every division, branch and section suffered equally. To some extent this move could be likened to the corporate paranoid response characteristic of large organisations faced with unwelcome prospects of change. Instead of more of the same, as there had been in the past, there would now be progressively less of the same-but it would be the same, nonetheless. This response was hardly surprising from a Public Service that has been variously described as toxic, fear-based, pathological, repressive, reactive, paternalistic and neurotic, to the extent that some departments are seen as presenting manic depressive mental disorder symptoms. That strong language is not my language; it is language appearing in various reports commissioned by the Public Service Commission and the occasional papers that are produced as a result of that process.

Just why the Australian Public Service is like that is a consequence of historical development throughout a lengthy period where due process carried far more weight than outcomes. Certainly, the Federal Parliament has contributed to the development of the jackboot, head-kicking management style that is still commonplace in the public sector. Too often the manner in which Parliament seeks to maintain principles of fairness, impartiality, probity and public accountability is characterised by the use of its powers to seek punishment of those who are seen to have made mistakes, regardless of any consideration of risks involved and at the expense of acknowledging and rewarding success. Any poor soul who has had the dubious privilege of facing the sharp end of a parliamentary committee of inquiry would readily agree with those sentiments. In the adversarial environment of the parliamentary chambers the concept of ministerial responsibility is occasionally abused in the same vein.

This is not entirely surprising, given that fault in public servants, through the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, is sheeted home on their ministerial supervisors. So if it is possible for a parliamentarian to expose some area of fault in the Public Service, inevitably the clamour comes up for the Minister to resign. The process is accordingly dominated by the exercise of seeking fault rather than seeking out those opportunities to reward properly with praise initiatives which are successful. One of the prominent writers on Public Service management methodology, John Baker, in his booklet entitled Some Private Sector Models for New Directions in Public Sector Human Management, has noted this conundrum. I think in some of his writing he has observed that, to give an example, a public servant may succeed in eight tasks yet fail once. The score should be plus six, but in fact the one failure only is remembered, so he has a score of minus one. So it is rational, in a cynical sense, to do nothing, to take no risk because the worst he or she can get is a score of zero; he or she will not be recorded as having made an error.

With the prospect of greater public awareness through live media coverage of parliamentary inquiries and processes, it may be that some fundamental reforms to parliamentary processes will herald the final stages of public sector management changes. This is unlikely to happen, however, until a suitable alternative forum for the selection of ministerial material is developed. Meanwhile the executive arm of the present Government has managed to put some fairly impressive runs on the board in terms of dealing with the more intractable problems facing the nation. Along the way the Hawke Ministry has developed a sense of common purpose and, for the time being, mutual trust with the Public Service. It might be argued that Ministers have a ready opportunity to do this because they can easily control large areas of Commonwealth expenditure directed towards a common client base for both government and the Public Service. In these areas the Public Service is not directly threatened and is thus more likely to respond positively to requests for new policy initiatives.

There is perhaps some evidence that this success will now feed its way through the administrative reform of the Public Service itself. Nevertheless, it must be accepted that the nature of the reforms expected of the public sector are quite unlike anything to be faced by the public sector manager. In the private sector the name of the game is generally increased market share, profit and the like. The dismal science of economics tells us that this type of activity fits well with basic human nature. People can be expected to do this sort of thing without any special training. In the private sector one can also resort to the fairly basic technique of offering more money to attract needed resources. In the contracting public sector environment the name of the game is, however, quite the opposite. Public servants are essentially being asked to be more creative, innovative, entrepreneurial and to work harder towards the ultimate objective of doing themselves out of a job. In many cases they are also obliged to accept lower salaries than their private sector counterparts for this privilege.

The dilemma faced by public sector managers has been to find some mechanism to encourage staff to respond to the invitation of self-destruct in a positive way. It is not surprising that the Australian Public Service has taken some little time to deal with the problem but a solution does seem to be beginning to evolve.

At the heart of the new-found strategy is the growing realisation that public servants are in most respects fairly normal human beings. That is not a sentiment that is likely to find much favour with the Australian public at large. For reasons of personal safety it is also not the sort of proposition that one might put with any conviction at the local watering hole on a Friday night. Nevertheless, if one is prepared to be open-minded enough to accept the possibility that there might be a grain of truth to this proposition, then the prospect of radical change could well arise.

Numerous psychological studies have shown that normal people like to do a good job and they especially like to be told they are doing a good job. Eighty-five per cent of all people believe that they are of above average ability. Normal people tend to perform better when they are praised and respond positively to people who praise them. This is true even when they are on the receiving end knowing full well that the praise is false. Criticism, on the other hand, has the opposite effect. Good people managers know this and use it to their advantage. Effective managers also know that most believe that they are of above average ability in most things. This may sound absurd but it is true that people believe it about themselves. It is also true that enlightening people to the basic absurdity of these widely held beliefs is not something that is likely to persuade them.

Bearing all this in mind, the new program budgeting regime of accounting provides opportunities to identify parts of a public sector operation that, in some senses, can be seen as potentially profit making or at the very least capable of self-funding. Activities that are less amenable to this type of analysis can also be lumped into the general category of a statutory responsibility and therefore exempted from further considerations of efficiency.

In the past a high proportion of the extensive managerial talent to be found in the Public Service has been directed towards competing for basic resources such as pens, paper, chairs, desks and the like. By linking the notional profit elements of favoured parts of departmental operations back to allocated mechanisms for these highly prized items one can introduce an effective reward system. It does not matter that the items dispensed have little more intrinsic value than a gold star or a rubber stamp on the hand, but it does matter a great deal when some people have ready-made opportunities to amass more prizes than others.

By using these simple techniques the effective manager can acknowledge and reward the achievements of people and in so doing encourage them to do whatever it is that they are doing well. In this way the prediction of profit potential tends to become self-fulfilling. Those people who are unwilling or unable to adapt to the new regime will tend to fall victim to the various retirement and retrenchment options available, and therefore take themselves out of the game. The more far-sighted of the successful people might then seek to market these newly recognised skills in the private sector, but that is of course a process of interchange between public and private sectors which is in the process of being developed.

The main difficulty with this inevitable result is that the process of change does not seem to require any objective assessment of overall economic efficiency in the final outcome. It may be that the resource reallocation mechanism guarantees greater efficiency in some way that is not obvious to myself. Still, there remain plenty of people who are less than convinced by the efficiency arguments, but so long as the marketing approach to management change continues to command public acceptance people will embrace it; so there is not a great deal of point in further resistance. Dare one suggest, however, that faced with the twin barrels of existential irrelevancy the notion of public service might grow to flourish well beyond its present limited domain. No doubt the money or the gun approach of the economic rationalists will decide the issue.

In summary, I have noted some of the developments in Public Service management and pointed to concerns that I have in terms of the way in which the managerial environment in the Public Service has been unresponsive to social conditions and has bred a pathological and fear-based managerial style. I think Parliament does have a responsibility to make sure that it does not contribute towards poor performance in the public sector. I think we all have our own examples of instances where Parliament has gone past what is proper in terms of examining the conduct of Public Service departments. I think of the shameful pursuit in the Senate of officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs last year as just one such example-an example that could only be seen as an attempt to hunt down those who were being painted as guilty before any offences against them were demonstrated.

This is not a plea for the Parliament to avoid its responsibility in scrutinising and inspecting the Public Service nor to resile from its responsibility to criticise wrongdoing. But it is a plea for the Parliament to balance that responsibility with an awareness that the Public Service is made up of ordinary human beings, people who do respond to praise as well as criticism. It is not enough simply to engage in the negative processes of attack; it is also very important to recognise success and to reward it. We must, obviously, get away from the situation where many tasks being achieved successfully are disregarded and one task being performed poorly is regarded as the measure of the public servant without being weighed against the many successes. Ultimately, people are the primary asset of any organisation, and people are the primary asset of government. A people-centred approach is not a soft approach, not an altruistic approach, but is an approach based on a hard-nosed economic principle that we will only succeed by developing good management techniques applied with good sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is a classic example of attitudes which are fundamentally undermining the accountability of government in Australia today. It presents us with bizarre propositions which are themselves contradictory and demonstrates the dangers of the approach to the public sector which has been pursued by the Australian Labor Party in office. I intend to demonstrate that it is this Government's abdication of responsibility and the effective abandonment of the time-honoured practice of ministerial responsibility which has made public servants the subject of political focus. More disturbingly, underlying this motion is the idea that somehow the Parliament and taxpayers of Australia exist solely to provide a living for the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting this motion the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) displays a complete misunderstanding of the role of government in civil society and the role of democratic institutions as a check on the power exercised through the Public Service. To the extent that this motion calls for closer identification between the interests of public servants and this Parliament, it has ominous Orwellian overtones. The mover's desire that government employees should be one big happy and cooperative family under the constructive supervision of the big brother Parliament is reminiscent of the memorable canteen scenes in the film version of 1984. This is consistent with his collective motion that a government department can have the symptoms of a manic depressive, as expressed by the honourable member in his notice of motion. One of the greatest dangers is that civil servants become so happy with the activities of one government in office that they will use their positions to try to ensure that that government remains in power. With a growing list of failures of this Government it is essential for the well-being of our country that that does not happen.

The role of the Public Service cannot be considered without also deliberating on the role of government. Whilst it is undoubtedly true that government employees perform many vital functions in Australia today, it is not self-evident that all of these functions should be performed under the auspices of government. To suggest that many functions undertaken by the public sector could be better performed by private individuals and firms is not to attack the public sector but to defend the ability, enterprise, independence and other qualities of which most Australians are capable. The public sector comes into disrepute when it interferes in the lives and businesses of Australians. When government steps beyond the limits of that narrow consensus about what governments should do it condemns those whom it employs to act on its behalf to the enmity and distrust of many other Australians.

The unfortunate truth is that, generally speaking, the Public Service is not highly regarded by many people in the community. It does, however, rate above politicians. People base their judgment of the Public Service on their experience with public servants as they perform their duties or on the anecdotal evidence of others who interact with the Public Service. This is not an indictment of those individuals who happen to work for the Commonwealth but of those governments which have asked them to perform tasks which are neither desired nor needed to further the interests of individual Australians. These problems are not helped by the burden of taxation which this Government, in particular, imposed on taxpayers who rightly feel that they have paid with their own effort for what salary and prosperity is enjoyed by public employees.

Success in the public sector is almost impossible to judge or measure, but I think that in the minds of most Australians the most successful Public Service is a nearly invisible one which neither touches their lives nor their pockets more than is absolutely necessary. Rewards for public employees are seen as a cost or punishment for taxpayers. To the extent that this Parliament, the members in it, and the decisions we make, are not respected by the people who pay for government through taxation, the people who administer those decisions will not be respected. That respect has been gravely undermined by the Labor Party in government. Desperate for power, Labor has seen the Public Service as its tool for achieving that end and rewarding those who have helped it along the way. It is true that individual public servants should not, in the normal course of events, be the subject of criticism in this place.

The Westminster system of ministerial government is designed so that the person who is ultimately responsible for a government department is a member of the Parliament. It is the role of that Minister not to protect but to take responsibility for the action of those public servants who are part of the department which he or she oversees. The legitimacy of all that this Parliament does rests on the principle that Ministers of the Crown administer the decisions of the Parliament and, in turn, are accountable to it-the Parliament. This Government, under its Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), has gravely undermined the practice of ministerial responsibility. It has used the system of portfolio and junior Ministers to ensure that neither takes responsibility for either their own actions or those of their departments, while avoiding scrutiny of their actions through the forums of parliament. If, as the honourable member for Denison seems to suggest in his motion, the Parliament seeks to use its powers to discipline public employees-I reject any such notion-then it can only be because the responsible Minister has evaded his or her responsibilities.

Public employees are, in the first instance, responsible to their Minister. The procedure of Senate Estimates committees, to which the honourable member for Denison referred, allows the Parliament to scrutinise the performance and statements of the Government and its Ministers, rather than the performance of individual public servants. Unfortunately, under the present Government public servants are more likely to be rewarded for protecting from scrutiny the failings of their Minister than for performing their duties in the interests of the country. I remind the House that Mr Charles Perkins served as the fall guy for two failed Ministers who refused to accept responsibility for the manifest failings in the management of Aboriginal affairs. He was not a victim of parliamentary scrutiny but of a desire to hide mistakes by the Government. When it is convenient Hawke Government Ministers have been all too willing to hide behind senior public officials and departmental advice.

The Commonwealth Statistician was forced to take a major public role in defending the Government's failure to table the notorious household expenditure survey because the Treasurer (Mr Keating) thought that such a requirement was beneath him. The Commissioner of Taxation has become the public advocate of the Government's approach to the collection of taxation, again taking on a role that the Minister avoids. In doing so the Commissioner has brought his own office into disrepute. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has blamed and hidden behind anyone who crossed his path to avoid responsibility for the Medicare muddle. The Prime Minister, more than any of his colleagues, has become a master at evading responsibility for everything which goes wrong and claiming credit for the slightest success. This is in commendable but stark contrast to the performances of Senator Walsh and Senator Button who have both been remarkably candid in admitting mistakes and failure.

Many commentators have been critical of politicising the Public Service and public agencies, particularly under State and Federal Labor governments. Similarly, there is an extensive literature which talks about a new class of those who are wholly dependent on the public purse for their livelihood, status and success. The Labor Party in government has compounded this by seeking to merge its political interests with the personal interests of many who work in the public sector. By offering the promise of more power through new programs, more staff, greater autonomy and more money, Labor has rewarded public sector employees for doing its bidding rather than being impartial administrators according to the rule of law. Through the appointment of political candidates to public office, the scrutiny of the actions of those office-holders has become essential.

A classic example of the need for parliamentary scrutiny of politicised public office has been the destruction of accountability by the Western Australian Labor Government. In a damning report, the Burt commission found that some government agencies had become so distant from those to whom they should be responsible that they refused to answer questions put to them by the commission. Two former senior government employees who had close ties with the Labor Party have been charged in connection with `Western Australia Inc.' deals. On too many occasions government agencies seem to have become the vehicles for the support of private interests and the political interests of the Labor Party. Only the most rigorous parliamentary and public scrutiny can provide some protection from this so-called cooperative and constructive approach to blurring the distinction between the Executive, the legislature, the Public Service, political parties and private interests, which has become known as a corporatist form of government. The Western Australian Labor Government has, by its actions, put a slur on all government employees and fundamentally undermined confidence in the impartiality of the public sector in that State. I might add that many of the same criticisms could be levelled at past governments in New South Wales and Victoria, under Labor, as well as in Queensland.

It is highly desirable that the principles of fairness, impartiality, probity and public accountability are restored as an integral part of the Public Service, to be rewarded with the respect that such high standards deserve. Instead, Labor Ministers have abdicated responsibility, encouraging public servants to become involved in political debate. They have played favourites with those in the Public Service seen as allies. They want all power but no responsibility. They have moved towards the formation of their own nomenclature for the privileged who benefit wonderfully from the party in power at the expense of those who are excluded. Those are the real reasons why some are not happy in the Public Service and many are not happy with the Public Service. The honourable member for Denison suggested in his motion that the fundamentals on which our democracy is based are out of touch with contemporary personnel management practices. If that is the case, it should not be democracy which is compromised. I urge rejection of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on the matter of private business and I compliment the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) on proposing it. There has been much debate in this country over the future of the public sector, particularly its ongoing role in the economic process. The debate has centred on the notion of privatisation of government business entities such as Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. One approach has been to assume, as an almost self-evident statement, that the private sector is inherently more efficient in the delivery of services and the production of goods than the Public Service. I hold to no such notion. However, I do acknowledge the relevance of this debate and the need to ensure that both the public and private sectors in Australia lift their game if our nation is to overcome the economic challenges and provide all Australians with an increasing standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government has not adopted wholesale privatisation, it is fair to recognise the move to corporatisation not only of business entities but also of the broader Public Service. Responsibility for the efficient operation of individual government departments has devolved principally to the management of each department. Gone is the Public Service Board and the centralised control of the day to day operations which the Board symbolised. In its place has come departmental corporate plans, mission statements, objectives and goals. In this way the public sector has mirrored the developments in the private sector which have followed some clearly identifiable trends. These trends include a focus on cost cutting and efficiency; lots of mergers and reorganisation of activity; and new attitudes and emphasis within organisations on how to manage and use people effectively. While the Australian Public Service is familiar with the first two of those trends, I do not believe that the third one has been so evident. All three trends represent quite radical changes for individual employees. However, better management of human resources is probably the only one of the three which offers advantages to individual employees, rather than the corporation or department involved.

As members of parliament, it is far too easy to rest blame with the Public Service and individual public servants. It is part of the Australian ethos to downgrade public servants as lazy `shiny pants' who have permanently full in-trays and equally empty out-trays. Most members of parliament would have had little detailed contact with the Public Service prior to their election. What contact there was would have been mostly on a business or professional level or, as with most Australians, as a consumer of one or more government services. It is all too easy for parliamentarians to blame public servants for unpopular decisions and to be hyporcritical when the local office of the Department of Social Security gets it wrong and a pensioner or beneficiary does not quite get the service that he or she wants. The position of the public servant is put rather well by a short poem which reads:
It's not my place to run the train
The whistle I can't blow
It's not my place to say how far
The train's allowed to go
It's not my place to shoot off steam
Nor even clang the bell
But let the damned thing jump the track
And see who catches Hell!

That is the position for public servants. They do not determine what the Government does. They do not change, say, the operation of the assets test as it affects pensioners, but they must administer the changes. If they get it wrong even once their local member of parliament or the Commonwealth Ombudsman-any number of mechanisms are available-makes sure they know that they have got it wrong.

As the honourable member for Denison pointed out, very little time and effort is given to rewarding people who get it right. I suppose it is the nature of our system to concentrate almost solely on mistakes and to point out where things have gone wrong. However, it is equally important to point out to people who do get it right, by administering things properly and efficiently and adopting a caring attitude towards members of the public, that they have done so. There are more public servants who are dedicated to their job, willing to spend time explaining things to people to make sure that an often confused individual actually understands where he stands than there are those who are offhanded and officious in their attitude. However, it is the public servant of whom a constituent is critical that we as members of parliament hear about. We only hear complaints; we rarely hear praise.

The Government has accepted that the Public Service needs to operate more efficiently and has placed very definite goals for the Public Service to reach. That is a sensible and proper thing for the Government to do. However, a number of the new management practices which have followed other trends in the private sector have been a bit slower to come through the Public Service. Considering the cost involved, it makes very good sense to have a more efficient work force. Currently the wages bill for the Commonwealth Public Service is some $4.7 billion. A productivity gain of just one per cent would therefore result in a saving of some $47m. Mr John Baker, in his paper Some Private Sector Models for New Directions in Public Sector Human Management, identified some 18 practices which could be examined as providing gains for individual Public Service Departments. Some of the proposals are, in my opinion, very worthwhile and should be pursued. For instance, he identifies the need to move away from great volumes of personnel manuals and replace them with general policy objectives. The matters raised by the honourable member for Denison are worthwhile and I believe that the House is right to debate them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Fisher will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House urges Australian business to address the implications for itself and the Australian economy in general of European economic integration post 1992.

One of the problems for Australia is that it is an island fairly isolated from the mainstream of the international community, and the difficulty with being isolated in that way is that sometimes the great debates of the international community come to us rather late in the day. Sometimes we are not really as aware of those great debates as perhaps we ought to be, particularly in the context of our own long term prosperity. When one goes to Europe these days, east or west, there is no doubt that enormous changes are taking place. The changes in east Europe are very exciting and very encouraging and one looks forward to the day when east Europe will achieve not just greater economic prosperity but a much greater degree of political freedom and pluralism.

When one goes to west Europe what strikes one there is the way the European Community is developing with such pace and with such effectiveness. The proposition that after the end of 1992 Europe will become a single economic market is really one of the most important changes that have taken place in west Europe since 1958, when the European Community was formally established. The European Community is really exceeding the expectations of many of the more sceptical observers of the evolution of the so-called European dream. I have always been rather sceptical about where the European Community would ultimately lead; I am happy to admit that. I do not think, and I think many people in Europe would agree with this, that we will see a united states of Europe in the next few years or perhaps in the next 100 years.

What is interesting in Europe is the enormous commitment there is now to doing more and more things on a European scale where doing them on that European scale brings very obvious benefits. There is enthusiastic support in Europe now for the European monetary system and some criticism of Britain for not joining that system. As a result of the Madrid European summit recently, there is now a commitment from Britain eventually to join the European monetary system. There is now talk in Europe of achieving economic and monetary union in the next few years, of having a single European currency, of having perhaps one central bank for all 12 countries of the European Community rather than 12 separate central banks, and of some harmonisation of taxation policies within certain margins right around the European Community. Then there has been the evolution of the European Parliament as a democratic institution. As some time has gone on, particularly since the first direct elections to the European Parliament, which were in 1979, that Parliament has gained increasing power and increasing relevance as an institution of the European Community and as a political institution of the whole of Europe.

The real revolution in Western Europe, without doubt, is the so-called single European act, the absolute commitment towards what is little less than an economic revolution in that part of the world post-1992. Already, companies and governments within the European Community are taking action, and taking action very rapidly, to prepare themselves for this single post-1992 European market. Those who are a bit sceptical about the effects of this European market post-1992 should take a bit of time to read the Cechini report, produced last year, which contrasts the effect of continuing to have 12 separate markets within the European Community with the benefits that could be reaped, will be reaped, from having that one integrated market: integration in industry; integration in transport; integration in telecom- munications; and integration in business and financial services.

The first point the Cechini report makes is that the European market, if we could call it that, post-1992 will provide savings for European Community firms of something in the vicinity of $365 billion. That is an enormous saving, brought about by the harmonisation of regulations, the harmonisation of practices and the like, and completely free trade within the bounds of the 12 member states. The Cechini report estimates that the single European act, the post-1992 Europe, will lead to the creation of an additional two to five million jobs and that it will contribute to economic growth within the European Community to the extent of between 5 and 7 per cent per annum. That is an enormous boost to growth within the European Community.

It is obvious when we look at it why this will happen. The Europeans will gain enormous economies of scale when they are dealing with a market of 320 million people rather than their individual home markets, particularly in the smaller countries such as Belgium, Greece and Luxembourg. Secondly, the greater commitment therefore to competitiveness brought about by this open market will lead to substantial increases in productivity within companies in the European Community and steps are already being taken in Europe to improve that productivity. In turn, that should lead to a greater degree of profitability. The Europeans will also benefit from much greater mobility in both capital and labour. Again, they will benefit from a more efficient allocation of resources than is possible within the confines of 12 separate boundaries.

One of the things that has really inspired the European Community to do these things in an economic sense-leave politics aside-is the real need for them to be able to compete with the Japanese. Wherever one goes in Europe there is a concern, particularly in the manufacturing area, about their capacity to compete with the Japanese. One only has to look at the European car industry to see how there is almost a paranoia about the effect of imports from Japan, and they have a number of non-tariff barriers in order to stop imports at this stage. They are determined that they are going to be able to compete with the Japanese and they believe that one of the most effective ways they can do that is through the breaking down of the barriers between the 12 members states. I believe that they will succeed in doing that. They will certainly live up to many of the rather glamorous aspirations written out in the Cechini report.

I have talked a little about how exciting these changes are in the European Community. Unlike Mrs Thatcher, I really welcome these changes. As somebody who lived for some years in Europe, I think it is a tremendously exciting thing. But it is enormously relevant also to Australia. We as Australians have increasingly to look at ourselves in a global context and ask: What are the implications of these important global changes for our way of life, for our society and for our economy? The first and most obvious point I would make about the relevance to Australians of Europe post-1992 is that Australia will be competing with a much more competitive European community. That only underlines the absolute urgency in this country of those micro-economic reforms that so many members of this House talk about but so few happen to be implementing; the absolute urgency of making sure that our general taxation structure is one that takes into account the need to compete with other parts of the world; the absolute urgency of ensuring that our industrial relations system changes so that we get rid of outmoded restrictive practices, in particular in areas such as transport and the waterfront and the building industry, in order to make us more competitive to deal with this much more competitive European Community.

Make no mistake about it. If we in this country do not become substantially more competitive very quickly we will be drowned economically not only by the Japanese but also by the new dynamic European Community. People should be aware of that. In a sense people in Australia should be very concerned about that. It will be harder for Australian firms to sell into the European Community after 1992, not easier, because the Europeans will be much more competitive. It will be harder for Australian firms to gain access to third markets and retain access in third markets because of greater competition which is coming from a much more dynamic Europe. Unless we take seriously these changes in Europe and make ourselves more competitive we will keep falling further and further behind other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries and slipping further and further into economic poverty.

The second point I make in relation to the European Community post-1992 is that Australian companies need to give a lot more thought than perhaps many of them have done already to establishing a foothold within the European Community. We talk a lot in Australia, understandably, about how so many of us have our ethnic roots in different countries of Europe. We have those contracts with Europe and yet we tend not to take Australian firms and Australian enterprises to Europe-with the possible exception of the United Kingdom, where there has been a certain amount of Australian investment and enterprise. We do not do very much in countries like Italy or Greece, in spite of the fact that so many Australians come originally from those countries.

Australian firms in a broader sense need to look at establishing a greater foothold in the European Community so that they are able to operate more freely in that market and take advantage of the opening up of that market of 320 million people. We can do it in areas like banking, transport, the provision of financial services and-dare I say it-manufacturing as well. There is no reason why Australian companies cannot set up some manufacturing capability within the European Community in order to facilitate access to those European markets and take advantage of Europe post-1992.

When one travels around Europe these days it is interesting to see the way in which the Japanese have pursued this strategy-and have been doing so for a number of years. They see the benefits that could come eventually not just to Japanese companies but to the Japanese economy by the way the European Community is developing. It is a central part of Japan's strategy in dealing with Europe and we ought to take a leaf out of its book.

In conclusion, Australian firms need to become much more Euro-conscious. Australian business needs to be much more conscious of changes that are taking place in Europe. We should not just concentrate on competition from Japan and the newly industrialised countries of our own region. If we do not rise to the challenge which is being thrown down to us by a more dynamic European Community then, as I have said, any chance of this country restoring its prosperity or guaranteeing continued prosperity will be blown away by those in other parts of the world who have taken the opportunities of greater competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general terms I agree with the context of this motion, although the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) needs to think further about many of his specific comments. There is no doubt that there will be a revolutionary change in Europe as a result of the 1992 changes. Not only Australia but the rest of the world will have to accommodate to those changes. I have had the honour of being elected this year to go to the European Parliament and European institutions. The No. 1 agenda item to be discussed is the changes of 1992 and their impact on other countries, including Australia. I look forward very much to these discussions, to identify not only the benefits for Australia but also what problems we may encounter as a result of this.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously the concept of a single Europe has evolved tremendously in the last few years, notwithstanding the opposition of some people. It is interesting that the honourable member for Mayo distanced himself from the great leader of the conservatives around the world, Margaret Thatcher, in her continuous and obstinate refusal to accept changes in relation to the development of a single Europe. I wonder whether that is the official policy of the Opposition. What is the position of the Opposition in relation to Margaret Thatcher's actions? It is probably the usual position of the Opposition, with half a dozen different positions in relation to the issue.

The question of a single currency is a very important matter. If Mrs Thatcher continues to oppose a single currency we will get a kind of reactionary attempt to prevent the concept of a single economy from actually taking place. I agree with the comments of Francois Mitterand in relation to the British on this point. The British have to decide whether they want to be part of a single Europe or not. They have gone down the road about 80 per cent but they keep pulling back and saying, `We don't know whether we want the next step', and they want to run away. The British Government has to make a decision as to whether it will cooperate in relation to the single European concept in terms of the economy and the evolution of other things.

The honourable member for Mayo mentioned that he does not expect to see a united states of Europe for a hundred years. I think he is wrong. I expect that there will be a united states of Europe much sooner than that. Already political integration is moving apace as a result of the economic dynamism of the 1992 reforms. One of the most surprising things to arise when one studies this is the power of the European Parliament and the European Commission. The Parliament is a lot more powerful than people recognise in determining the overall policy and structure that governs what ultimately is one of the most significant aspects of life, namely, economic life. I think we will see increasingly that more and more significance will be given to the European Parliament and European Commission as a result of the economic changes. We will see greater pressure for integration. Of course there are cultural differences in Europe which will create some problems but perhaps people there could learn from Australia and adopt a--

TALK.START.PARA: —Multicultural.

—Multicultural policy. This is a serious comment. Multicultural policy in Europe will help to achieve greater cohesion and overcome some problems. There will be problems in terms of European countries coming together. I believe that one of the main problems will be to achieve things like a common policy on taxation. As honourable members know, although every country has a value added tax, there are completely different levels at which that tax is imposed on different goods and services. The process of negotiation will be difficult because it will impact differently on the income of the different countries of Europe, depending on the level of tax which they impose and on the commodities on which they impose it.

SPEECH.PARA: The breakdown of barriers, and the free flow of capital, goods and people will mean, for example, that people can go from Britain to Greece, work there completely unfettered, pay tax and behave as if they were citizens of Greece in most respects. Obviously that situation will have a very dramatic impact. There will be great movements of people towards centres which have greater employment and opportunities.

We have to look at the impact on Australia. I was surprised that the honourable member for Mayo did not mention one of the most important aspects of this for Australia, namely, the common agricultural policy. The common agricultural policy is that aspect of European integration which we are not too happy about. It talks about free markets and access and all of those things; about moving towards a greater dependence on a liberal market. The Europeans talk about the single market as a dynamic component of a liberal world economy. True, if one looks at manufacture; but it is not true if one looks at agriculture.

From the Australian point of view-I was surprised that the honourable member for Mayo did not mention this-the concept of the single European market by 1992 unfortunately does not contain within it any suggestion of further liberalisation of access to the agricultural market of Europe. Nor does it contain any suggestion, so far at least, for some change in the common agricultural policy and the subsidisation of farm products. That will be a difficulty for Australia. As the Europeans move to this position in 1992 we should be putting maximum pressure on them by saying, `Philosophically, you are talking about this being an important component of a liberal world economy. We agree with that, but what are you going to do about the agricultural policy and, in particular, the impact of the agricultural policy on other countries?'. This concerns not merely the United States, with whom they are engaged in a war, but other countries such as Australia, who in a sense are innocent victims of the agricultural war between Europe and the United States.

The honourable member for Mayo mentioned the importance of Australian companies and Australian individuals taking advantage of the 1992 changes and getting a foothold in Europe in order to participate in that process through an investment window. That is an important point. The honourable member mentioned Greece and Italy. I have been discussing this in relation to Greece and Italy, and indeed Spain and Portugal. We have excellent opportunities, with relatively low wage costs vis a vis Europe, to invest and to use the cultural connection between Australia and Europe. Australians of Italian, Greek, Spanish and Portuguese background, people with cultural connections, can be used if Australian companies are sufficiently intelligent to take up that cultural connection and say, `We have people in Australia who have these backgrounds and who can assist us gain a foothold in those countries of Europe where we can then participate in a huge market of 320 million people'. If we do that it will be very positive.

The Government should initiate more activity in this area. We should have more encouragement. Austrade and other economic bodies should encourage people, especially Australian companies, to invest in that segment of Europe and to use the linguistic and cultural resources which we have here in Australia to establish that link. If we do that, and if we do get a foothold in Europe, it will be very important, as the honourable member for Mayo said, in our future relationships with the European Community. I certainly support that. I go further than the honourable member for Mayo and say that through government initiative we need in some way to encourage this process more than we are doing at the moment.

The honourable member for Mayo mentioned that Australian industry has to change in order to come to grips with this European phenomenon. True. But the suggestions of the Opposition about Australian industry are laughable. Opposition members talk about micro-economic reform. Of course, when they were in government they did nothing about micro-economic reform whereas this Government is putting into place the first substantial micro-economic reforms in 40 years-the waterfront, in transport and in a whole range of areas.

The honourable member for Mayo thought that he could score some political points about micro-economic reform. The fact is that Australian industry will be able to compete with European industries only if we support high technology and efficient systems in Australia in the way the Europeans do. That is the way we should be going. We should be supporting the development of those systems and supporting industrial development in a broad range of areas. We hear nothing from the Opposition about industrial development. In the last Budget we brought down a package of superannuation changes which will directly encourage superannuation firms to invest in Australian industry. It is a very significant package. We hear nothing from the Opposition about those significant changes and what their impact will be on the capital formation in Australia and on the investment capacities of Australian firms both here and abroad.

The honourable member for Mayo also mentioned the taxation structure. I do not know what sort of changes he envisages in the taxation structure which we have not already put into place. Dividend imputation for companies was the last revolutionary change in taxation. The conservatives talked about it for many years; we put it into place. It is one of the most important changes in the taxation structure for capital formation and investment. There is no problem in the taxation structure that we are not looking at. The changes that we have already put into place are significant and they will help us develop a competitive economy that will deal with the problem.

I go back to the central point about the 1992 changes. We do have a problem, in terms of our rural constituency and rural products, with the common agricultural policy. As Europe changes and moves towards 1992 we should be negotiating with European countries and insisting that if they are going to be more liberal and more competitive at the level of industrial goods, they should allow greater access for our primary industry products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the motion put forward by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), with which I wholeheartedly concur, I must say that he has put the case very eloquently for Australian business to become more aware of what post-1992 Europe will be all about. There will obviously be great opportunities but he sounded a very clear warning that Australian business will have to face up to a more competitive market not just in Europe but right around the world. The honourable member for Mayo brought in some very important statistics from the Cechini report, which showed how the European Community will be more efficient.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available to me I would like to turn back to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). It was rather disappointing to hear an honourable member take so much time with the usual diatribe which we might summarise as bashing the poms, as though they are always at fault. He then spent a fair bit of time trying to defend what is, in many cases, the indefensible lack of action by the present Government when he spoke about some of the present Government's rather pathetic attempts at micro-economic reform. He spoke about the waterfront, for example. As far as I know, all the Government has done is commission more reports than any other government, and arrange more meetings. So far there has been nothing more than meeting after meeting. He also drew a very interesting long bow. He said that industry will somehow be improved because the Government has encouraged superannuation investment. I am not quite sure how the Government intends to tie superannuation investment to industry alone. That was an interesting point.

I would have to agree with him that we are concerned about the common agricultural policy and it continues to be a problem, and I do not think post-1992 we are going to see any dramatic changes, although I know the Europeans keep telling us that they are moving in the right direction. But I think the overall message is, as the honourable member for Mayo has put it so eloquently, that when the single market does in fact come into place there will be the removal within Europe of physical barriers, of technical barriers and probably, most importantly, fiscal barriers. When this happens it will provide opportunities for Australian companies, particularly, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Mayo, if they take the opportunity of either going into joint ventures with European partners or in fact establishing a foothold, as, of course, the Japanese have done, such as in the car industry. The warning is there as well that with a more efficient Europe, as was pointed out in the Cechini report, then no doubt there will be a more competitive Europe not only within the market but also as European companies continue to trade around the world. The warning is there for Australian business to take up that challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the light of the joint select committee report on video pornography and violence being finalised, the Government should recognise the urgent need to present legislation to stop the importation into Australia of X-rated and excessively violent videos.

The present classification system in Australia today is divided into five groups: G for general viewing; PG for parental guidance, recommended for under 15-year-olds; M for those over 15 years old; R for over 18-year-olds, and this group includes explicit depictions of violence; and finally X-rated videos, which includes explicit sexual acts. The present situation in Australia today is that all States, whether Liberal governed, Labor governed or National Party governed, have long ago banned the sale of X-rated videos in their respective areas of jurisdiction. However, the sale of such material has been permitted and encouraged in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) while the present Federal Labor Government has had jurisdiction over these matters. This has allowed the bans in all the States to be circumvented because of the vigorous mail order businesses run out of Canberra. I think there are about 13 of them. Regrettably that continues under the Labor self-government rule that administers the ACT today.

However, the Federal Government, if it really wanted to, could still withdraw the support which it is so willingly giving to the pornography industry in Australia and fulfil the wishes of all decent Australians by banning excessively violent and X-rated videos from being imported into Australia. That would not eliminate the industry entirely but would certainly cut it off at the knees and go a long way towards getting rid of this rather sick aberration of our modern-day society.

I must say at the outset that I would like to see this present industry go, not because I personally disapprove of the material it peddles but because the overwhelming mass of evidence now conclusively shows that it is substantially harmful not only to children as a whole but also to a certain group of adults. I have some sympathy for the argument that adults should be allowed to view in the privacy of their own homes what they want. However, the argument is not as simple as that. There is another argument, an overriding argument which says that these videos are so harmful that their detrimental effects far, far outweigh the libertarian considerations of a person's right to view whatever he or she wants.

If anyone ever doubted the truth of that-and I must confess I was once never totally sure of the balance between the two competing arguments-then an examination of the evidence contained in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material presented to the Parliament last year would put the issue beyond doubt. However, to understand the present situation with videos in Australia it is necessary to retrace a little history. This whole area started to go wrong back in Senator Murphy's day, when he told Customs to lay off pornography and the like and give imports of it a low priority. That situation was eventually granted a formal legality back in 1984 when Senator Gareth Evans outlined the official government guidelines to the Film Censorship Board. I quote:

Barriers to the importation of hard core pornography other than child pornography, publications which incite terrorism and publications containing extreme violence and/or sexual violence have been lifted.

Following that, there was an enormous backlash from this irresponsible decision which led to a Senate select committee being set up to inquire into video material in Australia. This Committee brought down an interim recommendation that a moratorium be placed on the sale and hire of X-rated videos in the ACT. The Federal Labor Government panicked at the existence of this committee which clearly threatened the viability of the pornography industry in Canberra. It refused to do anything with that interim recommendation and replaced the Senate Committee by agreeing to set up a joint select committee of both Houses to inquiry into video material. The Government, in the meantime, laid down guidelines for X-rated videos in April 1984 which read:
Language: No proscriptions-
in other words, anything can be said-
Sex: All explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults (except those referred to under ``Refused Classification'')-
that includes the promotion of hard drugs, or bestiality, or sex with children; that would be banned-

including explicit penetration, masturbation, ejaculation, fellatio, cunnilingus, insertion of objects in orifices; miscellaneous other sexual activities and fetishes, (e.g. urolagnia, necrophilia, coprophilia, sadomaso- chism).

All that would be allowed. One has only to consider the fetishes there. One could smear oneself with human faeces, dog faeces, eat it, have intercourse with dead bodies and all these other perverted types of behaviour that I do not think should be allowed in Australia today. Fortunately that recommendation was amended a little in December 1984. Explicit violent sexual acts were taken out, which we would all agree with; however, the fetishes bit was left in. That is virtually the situation we operate under in Australia today.

I turn to some of the evidence presented in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. Just to show what the Committee was up against, I open up by quoting the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties, which gave evidence. That council said not only that X-rated videos should be retained in Australia but that this classification should be expanded. Can you believe it-expanded! Senator Harradine asked the question:
That means that you would then say that people should be free to read or see material that depicts child pornography, bestiality, terrorism, and misuse of drugs, for example.
Mr Horler, of the New South Wales Council of Civil Liberties, said:
It is not my wish, but if that is their wish then they should be entitled so to do.

That is indeed a remarkable attitude on the part of that organisation. I would like, first, to quote some material relating to violence in videos. The Committee took a lot of evidence in this area and it had evidence presented that the viewing of violent material makes a contribution to aggressive behaviour. In fact the 1982 report of the United States National Institute of Mental Health said:

After 10 more years of research, the consensus amongst most of the research community is that violence on television does lead to aggressive behaviour by children and teenagers who watch the programs.

Nothing could be more definite than that. Further American research, presented by Drs Leonard Eron and Rowell Huesmann in a 22-year longitudinal study begun back in 1960 and involving 875 boys and girls and 85 per cent of their parents, with follow-ups in 1970 and 1982, came to the conclusion that:
. . . there is a significant relation between television viewing at age eight and the seriousness of criminal convictions by the time you are an adult of age thirty.

In fact, their study found that children reared on a heavy diet of television violence had a 150 per cent greater chance of being convicted of a criminal offence by the time they were 30 than children reared with little exposure to television violence.

In further evidence, Dr Thomas Radecki, the Research Director of the National Coalition on Television Violence, said that 21 out of 22 studies concluded that violent entertainment has a damaging effect on some viewers. He estimated that at least 25 per cent of murders in the United States are `due to the diet of violent entertainment in our country'. He said further:
In the United States the average adult, by the age of 21, will have watched 10,000 hours of violent entertainment . . .
I read a report which stated that the average viewer views about 45,000 murders or attempted murders by the time he is 21 years old. Dr Radecki continued:
. . . children who are becoming brutalised by violent entertainment and who develop anti-social values are indeed more likely to get into drugs.

Dr William Belson, a prominent researcher on video violence, also appeared as a witness before the Committee. He referred to the results of a very thorough study of 1,565 London boys aged from 13 to 16. He divided them into two groups according to the extent of their exposure to televised violence. The two groups were then matched with a set of 217 variables. It was an incredible study. His findings gave strong support to the hypothesis that long term exposure to televised violence increases the degree to which boys engage in violent behaviour. He said that in his view the effect of exposure to televised violence is-and I quote:
. . . to `wear down' boys' training or conditioning against being violent, so that they tend to act as if that training had not occurred.
Dr Belson also said:

. . . long term exposure to television violence increases boys' participation in violent behaviour, increases their preoccupation with violent acts shown on television, makes them more callous in their reactions to the spectacle of violence in the world around them, produces sleep disturbances, reduces respect for authority, makes them feel more willing to use violence to solve their problem . . .

Example after example has been given by professors and other well-known experts around the world. Another expert, Professor Peter Sheehan, backed up Bandura's social learning theory that people can learn new behaviours. He said that there is a relationship between a child's viewing patterns, which are in turn largely influenced by parental viewing patterns. Another witness, Dr Patricia Edgar, said that if a viewer is inclined to aggression but has an inhibiting factor working against this predisposition, the video breaks it down by making violence appear more normal, and thus more acceptable. Dr Ann Knowles, from the psychology department of the Swinburne Institute of Technology, said that viewing television violence can, in some children, subsequently increase aggressive behaviour. Some non-scientific evidence was also presented to the Committee. I will refer to two witnesses who gave such evidence. Ms Amanda Ann Vallance, a primary school teacher representing the Tasmanian Teachers Federation, gave this example:
Their-
that is, the boys in her class with access to videos-

playground behaviour became quite vicious and their games suddenly changed from being boisterous and energetic to being quite obsessed with making knives, swords . . . with which they victimised everyone else in the playground . . . and in particular the girls in my class . . .

Ms Sonya Ryan, who taught on Tasmania's west coast, noticed a similar phenomenon. She said that some boys, after watching R-rated videos, become obsessed with violence and began to treat the girls just as objects. Evidence was given of two street massacres that had occurred in Australia. With regard to one of the incidents, police were said to have found several violent videos in the killer's room.

What about pornographic video material? A lot of evidence was given on that subject. Professor James Check, who undertook research for the Fraser Committee on Pornography and Prostitution in Canada, revealed that those who had been exposed to category II non-violent pornography subsequently reported a higher likelihood to rape, and to force unwanted sexual acts on women, than subjects who had not been so exposed. In fact, more than twice as many men indicated at least some likelihood of raping after exposure to non-violent degrading pornography than after no such exposure. What could be more conclusive than that? He said that frequent users of pornography had the most striking inclination to sexually aggressive behaviour. Professor Check said that frequent users of pornography had come to accept and endorse the values represented by pornography.

Dr James Weaver, Assistant Professor, College of Communications, University of Kentucky, said that exposure to media portrayals of female sexual permissiveness can activate cognition that reflect a general loss of respect for female sexual autonomy and self-determination. He noted:
. . . repeated exposure to such depictions is thought to result in the generalization and misattribution of characteristics associated with sexually promiscuous women to other women.

Zillman and Bryant, two other well-known, respected researchers, showed that massive exposure to pornography promotes acceptance of such material. They found that exposure to pornography causes both males and females to trivialise rape and to increase male callousness towards women. Further, they stated:

The most astonishing effect of prolonged pornography consumption on family values, however, concerns the desire to have children . . . exposure to pornography reduced the desire to have children and it did so in a uniform fashion . . . The desire to have male offspring dropped 31%. The desire for female offspring . . . dropped by twice that margin: 61%. This reduction proved specific to gender. Male respondents expressed little desire for female offspring altogether. It is the desire of females for offspring of their own kind that, after consumption of pornography, shrank to one third of its normal strength . . .

Zillman and Bryant also found that prolonged consumption of pornography `reduced sexual satisfaction and sex-related personal happiness markedly'. They said that subjects often compare the appearance and performance of their partner, such as their spouse, with the pornographic model and, as a result, become very dissatisfied after a period of time with their partner. Other behavioural scientists gave evidence that where no willing adult sexual partner is available, there is a possibility that some children may be at risk of sexual abuse, including incest. Inspector Johnson, of the Victorian Vice Squad, stated:

We have evidence from the Child Exploitation Unit, which I am in charge of now, that . . . paedophiles watch films and stimulate themselves and then they go out and have intercourse with children, or they bring the child into watch the film and get the child excited and then the crime is committed . . .

There is example after example, taking up hundreds of pages. If anybody doubts that violent or pornographic videos are not harmful to children and some adults in society in tipping the latter group over the edge, I suggest that he should read the report. As I said at the beginning of my speech, I had some doubts myself, but this evidence has left me in no doubt about the detrimental effects of such videos.

Approval for the sale of X-rated or excessively violent videos in Australia today is totally irresponsible. It is harmful for the children of this nation, it is harmful for a certain percentage of adults and, in particular, it is degrading for women. It makes Australia a less desirable place in which to live. I know that the Australian Labor Party suggests that X-rated video classification be changed to a new classification called non-violent erotica. The NVE classification will be identical to the X-rated classification. I say to those members of the Labor Party who support this suggestion-I know that not all members do-that this move will only entrench perversion in society today.

I believe that Australia is in danger of exhibiting the `fall of Rome' syndrome in permitting the sale of this material to continue. While I fully appreciate the censorship argument that those on the other side will no doubt put forward, apart from anything else, this material is a bit sick. Quite frankly, I believe that society can well do without it. I believe that the Government should ban imports of this material and perhaps even consider making it illegal for this material to be sent through the mail. If the Government took these steps it would fall in line with the wishes of all States in Australia and, I believe, with the wishes of the majority of Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say at the outset that the only people who support the proposal put forward by the honourable gentleman are people in organised crime. The only people who will profit by those proposals put forward are people in organised crime. Prohibition has never in the history of the world solved a social problem. We have banned illicit drugs in this country and, as a result, we have created organised crime.
—What are you going to do-legalise murder?

—Those opposite can interject and they can keep their own peculiar moral attitudes well out in front, but they do not provide answers as to how to prevent this sort of material or illicit drugs from reaching the marketplace. If we have not learnt from the history of illicit drugs in the last 20 years then we, as politicians, have learnt nothing. We cannot keep illicit drugs out of Australian gaols. That is the simple fact. We cannot keep them out of buildings with a razor ribbon around them and with armed guards. Until we find out how to control moral behaviour we will not stop people wanting to view the material, which, frankly, I find reprehensible. I find pornography absolutely boring. One can watch just so much of human beings coupling sexually; it does nothing whatsoever for me. The reality we face is that we must find a better solution to the problem than simply imposing a law banning pornography.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members opposite have not been to Asia recently, I suggest they go. I suggest they wander around the street stalls and have a look at the video material available on the streets-unarguably in breach of most copyrights, but freely available and at very cheap prices. Only about a month ago, in a street in a large Asian city I saw the latest Raider film-it had just hit the Australian cinemas-for sale at $5 a copy. It is technology that will beat those opposite. They are 20 years behind the times. They are back there before the days of cheap videos. They are back in the days when maybe governments did have the ability, by banning importations, to control the material our populace watches. That time has gone. That is neanderthal thinking. It is a nonsense to think that governments today can control what people want to view. It is just a nonsense. This material comes in in container loads.

Look at what has happened in the American States that have banned this sort of material. Is anybody going to tell me that the material is not available? Is anybody going to tell this House that where countries have banned pornography people cannot get it or it is not readily available? We cannot say that because it is readily available. It is there, it is on the streets, but with no control by government. It is freely available.

Unless those opposite can say that their proposals will solve the problem, they should not suggest them. They will not solve the problem. All that would happen is that the moment this Parliament banned the importation of non-violent erotica-and I will come back to the Opposition's confusion about other matters in a minute-organised crime would start shipping material into the country. They already have the marketplace chains established through illicit drugs and prostitution. There is the marketing system. They would ship the stuff in and we would have material such as snuff films coming out of America. Does the Opposition know what a snuff film is? It is where the female model being used to depict sexual activity is murdered-actually killed-in the video. That is the sort of stuff we would get in this country. It is currently banned, currently unavailable. The only pornography which is available in this country is in fact non-violent. There is no violent pornography available; it is all non-violent.

I do not happen to like the stuff. As I said, in the earlier part of this year when the debate was on, I bothered to go and view some. I have been to countries where sexual activities are performed on stage and I frankly find it very boring. I do not really think the evidence the Opposition produced from the report of the Joint Committee on Video Material was very fairly put. The report contains an equal amount of evidence to suggest that, for the normal human being, such depictions of sexual activity have no effect whatsoever. But when it comes to violent activities, I will support the Opposition all the way on its attitude.

I am absolutely horrified to think that our children are being exposed on television to the sort of nonsense that Rambo and similar figures get up to. It really leaves me cold. I have raised three children, and very early in my life I joined a group that monitored television. It was an adult group that was concerned about what children saw on television. For years I have been concerned about what children see on television; but to ban it will not stop it. How many houses in Australia do not have a video cassette recorder? Very few, and those that have not are buying them at the rate of knots. If the house has a VCR people do not need anything other than someone flogging the product out on the street to buy it.

I come back to organised crime. They are the organisations who are making literally billions of dollars around the world from prohibition. They are the only supporters of prohibition. If we ban some of this material, the increased profit going into the hands of organised crime would be frightening. I am the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority and in the past few years I have managed to gain some expertise in the marketing techniques and the way in which organised crime is infiltrating not just this country but the world. I can say without question that that would be the only result.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) speaks regularly on this subject. No-one else in the House raises this topic in such a regular manner. It is interesting to note that he is an expert on the fetishes. I did not even know what he was talking about. He seems to be very well experienced in the fetishes. He seems to know what he is talking about, and I find that quite surprising. I find it surprising in a debate of this kind that he had to detail in some graphic terms what sort of fetishes there were. Is that really part of this debate? Is it not more of a moral issue, a principle issue for discussion, rather than having a member of this House stand up and so graphically suggest that people find sexual pleasure in eating dog's excrement or smearing their bodies with it. I mean to say, really! I find that just as offensive as the thing he was complaining about. I wonder about the honourable gentleman's problem-why he has almost compulsively to stand in this House regularly and raise this topic in such graphic terms.

The honourable member was thoroughly confused about X-rated and violent videos. The evidence he quoted was confused between the two and he gave little credit to the report of the Committee which examined this subject. Violence is banned in X-rated videos. It is not available in this country and it cannot be obtained through legitimate sources. That has to be clearly put and clearly said. Much as I may not like pornography, much as I may wish that I lived in a society where the demand for such material did not exist, the demand does exist. It is part of our society.

The honourable gentleman should state clearly that non-violent erotica exists and that the violent material is in fact legal. I object most to the sorts of films that appear in our cinemas and which come too regularly on our television sets. If I wander into a video shop in my State-I do not know what it is like in other States-I now have trouble getting a video I am prepared to watch. Eighty per cent of the material in most video shops in Australia is absolute rubbish. No wonder we are getting peculiar people out there, if children are growing up and being fed on a diet of such material. That is where this Parliament should direct its attack. The debate gets confused when the honourable gentleman tries to marry the two issues.
I reject the honourable member's motion, I think it is ill-founded. His only supporters are the organised criminal groups.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.20 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 30 August 1989. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.20 to 2.40 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In the light of the decision in Abu Dhabi today, the third country now to reject Australian live sheep, will the Prime Minister assume personal control of this important export trade issue and conduct negotiations with his counterpart in Saudi Arabia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that there is properly on both sides of the Parliament a real concern about the issue which is the subject of the honourable gentleman's question. I am sure the honourable gentleman appreciates that the Government is concerned to protect Australia's reputation as a live sheep exporter.
