It has moved quickly to address the Saudi allegations of disease. As honourable members know, we sent a high level delegation to investigate its claims.
—Not high enough, obviously.
—The honourable member should just wait for a minute for once in his life instead of being stupid.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —When we are faced with it we have to identify it and honourable members are being stupid. Honourable members opposite should listen to the answer and presumably they will accept it. The Saudi officials acknowledge that the diseases did not originate in Australia but they are refusing, as I hope the honourable gentleman knows, to provide Australia with the test details or results. Obviously, in this situation we have yet to be convinced that a serious disease problem exists. All rejected shipments have been accepted and cleared of disease by other Middle East markets.
—That is not the case.

—That is the case. Kuwait, in particular, has rigorously tested the rejected sheep and has declared them free of the alleged diseases. Positive disease tests were subsequently overturned and we have yet to confirm the United Arab Emirates disease findings. We are looking at further measures to satisfy Saudi animal health concerns and a mechanism to deal with future problems should they arise.

ANSWER.PARA: In the interim, we support the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation's action to protect Australia's interests by temporarily suspending further shipments to Saudi Arabia. I repeat that this matter has been handled very efficiently and with complete commitment. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has had the cooperation of those with whom he has dealt. We are not in possession of any evidence whatsoever to suggest that there is any basis, in terms of Australia's position, to justify the action taken by the Saudis. There may be some explanation in some of the internal Saudi considerations. Neither my Government nor our great sheep industry can be held responsible for what may be happening within Saudi Arabia to explain what has happened. There is no responsibility on the part of Australia's great primary industry, nor is there any responsibility on the part of the Australian Government.

It is a tragedy that on just about every issue that arises, whether it concerns the pay claims of avaricious pilots or in regard to a situation such as this where Australian farmers have acted honourably, properly and without the possibility of any suggestion being made against them that they have acted otherwise than properly and safely, where the Government is giving them all the support it possibly can, this pathetic Opposition regards as the last item on its agenda the real interests of Australia. It is about time it woke up to the fact that the people of Australia are getting sick and tired of a situation where members of the Opposition put their miserable selves first and their country last.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: there is no disagreement with the Prime Minister's description of the live sheep problem. The question was--
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Will the Prime Minister now become involved--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Will he become involved because so far everything else has failed?
—Order! I warn the Deputy Leader of the National Party.

—Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your recent election to the high office of Speaker. My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Yesterday the honourable member for Mayo asked the Prime Minister a question about an alleged agreement between the Remm construction company and the Builders Labourers Federation and claimed that there had been a 30 per cent wage deal on the Myer redevelopment site. Does such a deal exist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Carrying on from the Prime Minister's remarks, what we saw in the honourable member's question yesterday was another attempt by the Opposition to do anything to damage this country just to gain sheer political opportunism for itself. Those are the facts. The honourable member's statement at the weekend and his question yesterday were clearly designed to give comfort, support and encouragement to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots in the damage that it is wreaking upon this nation's economy.

—I raise a point of order as to relevance, Mr Speaker. The Minister was simply asked whether or not an agreement had been made. The Minister should answer it by saying yes or no so that we can get on with the important business of this place.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. I remind him of standing order 55.
—What about wasting time?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—As I have said, the honourable member's statement and his question yesterday were clearly designed to give support to the Federation of Air Pilots. We have the hypocrisy of the Opposition day by day attacking the Government for the damage being done by the Federation of Air Pilots and at the same time encouraging that damage. That is really what the Opposition is about. The Opposition would be better served if the honourable member for Mayo got his brain into gear before opening his mouth because on this issue, as with so many other issues that he raises, he is wrong. Do not take my word for that, Mr Speaker. Let us consider what the company concerned has had to say about it. I will inform the House of the company's response to the honourable member for Mayo. It is not the Government's response. In a full-page advertisement in today's Adelaide Advertiser headed `You're wrong Mr Downer' the company stated:

ANSWER.PARA: On Sunday, August 27, the Federal Liberal Member for Mayo, Mr Alexander Downer, made allegations about wages paid to workers on the Myer Redevelopment site in Rundle Mall.
Mr Downer's claims were poorly researched and, in most cases, totally erroneous.

We wish to set the record straight, on behalf of all workers on the site, particularly members of the Builders Labourers Federation (properly known as the Australian Building and Construction Workers Federation) who were singled out.
Mr Downer claimed that the BLF had obtained a `backdoor wage increase' of 30 per cent over the above award payments in the building industry.

This is wrong. All workers' wage rates are strictly in accordance with appropriate State or Federal Industrial awards and industry agreements, which make provision for certain allowances, including site allowances.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just BLF propaganda.
—The honourable member might not like it, but he is going to cop it.
—Order! The Minister will continue to answer the question and not respond to interjections.
—The advertisement continued:

ANSWER.PARA: It is standard practice in the building industry to negotiate site allowances for projects.
When work began in September-October last year, an industrial agreement was signed by REMM Construction (Australia) Pty Ltd and the eight unions involved in the redevelopment.
This agreement provided for extended working hours and included site allowances of up to $3 an hour, allowable within the awards.
Mr Downer interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.
—Good point though.
—If the honourable member for Mayo continues to defy the Chair, I will deal with him.
—The advertisement continues:

ANSWER.PARA: No workers employed on the Myer site have received-or even demanded-any increase in wages or allowances outside this agreement.
No back-door payments have been, or will be, paid on this site.
Mr Downer was right in suggesting that construction workers can earn high weekly wages while employed on this site. Work is available seven days a week on a two-shift basis.
These workers work hard for their money, in the interests of productivity. Mr Downer should have no argument with that.
The sponsor of the advertisement is Remm Construction (Australia) Pty Ltd.

Might I say in conclusion from the Government's point of view that the Opposition and the honourable member need to note that labourers are covered by State jurisdiction and the tradesmen are under Federal jurisdiction. As yet the agreements have not been ratified by either the State or Federal industrial relations commissions, which are the proper places for examination of these issues. What the people of Australia need to understand is that the damage being done to the tourism and travel industries in this country by the Federation of Air Pilots is being supported, encouraged and condoned by those who now sit opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Government's decision to intervene in the negotiations between Qantas and its pilots for productivity increases for the new Boeing 747-400 series aircraft. Is it a fact that those negotiations began more than two years ago and were conducted under the normal productivity guidelines applicable to aircraft type which have already resulted in pay reductions as well as increases at Qantas? Did the interim agreement have the full support of the Qantas board, including Simon Crean? Will the Prime Minister admit his intervention at the instigation of Ansett was unnecessary and stupid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, let me deal first with the latter part of the question, the insinuation that I intervened on this matter at the instigation of Ansett. I do not know what has come over a gentleman who I had previously thought had a mixture of intelligence and decency.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Jull interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, the honourable member can shrug his shoulders and try to shrug it off. The fact is that what he is trying to say is that the Prime Minister of Australia acted on the basis presumably of a friendship that he has with the head of Ansett. Okay, good. Let us have it out into the open. The fact is that on this matter, in the presence of my colleagues the other Ministers, the head of Ansett, Sir Peter Abeles, and the head of Australian Airlines met me in my office-not just me by myself, but with my Ministers there. The question raised was raised jointly, not just by Ansett but by Australian Airlines as well. Why does not the honourable member demonstrate at least a modicum of decency in his question and ask whether I acted in response to pressure from Australian Airlines and Ansett? Unfortunately the honourable member would not do that because that is the whole truth of who was there. He should not jump up in a muddled little way and try to say what is the whole truth of the issue. I am telling the whole truth about who was there. But no, he could not do that. He could not ask whether it was pressure from the airlines; it had to be `Was it pressure from Ansett?'. Why does he not at least have the decency to say, `Well, did the airlines?'. Now the airlines did raise the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Aha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Airlines; not just Ansett, but Australian Airlines too. Ted Harris and Abeles, representing their airlines, raised the question, and legitimately. What was the question they raised? A very simple one. It concerned the fact that there were existing agreements within the Australia airline industry covering the domestic airlines and Qantas, and under those agreements there was an understanding, and agreement, that no-one would handle this question of re-crewing and re-manning arrangements and attendant possible changes in salaries unless and until any one of them concerned, confronted with a claim on this, had consulted with the others. That was the existing agreement that they had, and Australian Airlines and Ansett, naturally enough, being confronted with demands from their pilots, were saying that they were very concerned that something could have been done in defiance of an agreement which could push them into a situation where they may be forced under industrial pressure to pay increases to their pilots outside of anything that was reasonable.

ANSWER.PARA: So the answer is yes, the two domestic airlines very properly raised the issue with the Prime Minister of this country and the two of my Ministers concerned, the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Minister for Industrial Relations. Yes, they did raise-and properly raise-this issue with me, and I properly took it aboard.

Let us get the facts straight for this very confused honourable member and an increasingly discredited Opposition. I am informed that the Leader of the Opposition had a press conference before the Parliament resumed this afternoon to explain or attempt to explain his position on this issue to the Press Gallery. The universal judgment was that he did not know what he was talking about-it was bewildering. That is not surprising because that is what we have witnessed in this House.

Let us get clear what the facts are. The new Qantas 747-400 series aircraft provides for two crew in the cockpit-a considerable improvement in productivity over earlier generation 747 series. In assessing any increase in work value due to new generation aircraft in the aviation industry, it is clearly this Government's wish that an industry approach be adopted, as is required under the existing agreements, and, secondly, that such matters be pursued through the Industrial Relations Commission in accordance with wage fixing principles. Now Qantas has given the Government an assurance that no new allowance has been paid in respect of 747-400 crew and it has given us the undertaking that any such proposal will be pursued within the Industrial Relations Commission as required. It is a measure of the responsibility of the Australian International Pilots Association, AIPA, that they also accept that position, and that they have agreed to pursue the matter within the wage fixing system.

Let me conclude where I began. I regard as beneath contempt the insinuation in the question from the honourable member that this was an approach from Ansett because of-my God, it is not a state secret that Sir Peter Abeles is a longstanding friend of the Prime Minister. But, because of that very poorly kept state secret, there is this miserable insinuation in the question that Sir Peter Abeles and Hawke have come to some position. The fact is that Sir Peter Abeles on behalf of Ansett and Ted Harris on behalf of Australian Airlines properly came to me and the two Ministers and said, `This is a real issue of concern which, if allowed to go through into the domestic situation, could wreck the wages system and the Australian economy'. The Australian Prime Minister and his two Ministers properly took that issue into account.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Defence seen comments today that Australian Defence Force personnel returning from exercise Kangaroo 89 are being given second priority to civilian requirements for Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircraft? Are RAAF crews being required to work unnecessarily long hours during the dispute? Has the Government neglected its commitment to review pay and allowances for defence personnel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question because the statements to which he alludes are yet further evidence of what has been persistently revealed here in Question Time in questions from Opposition frontbenchers and in the way in which they have participated in debates. I have seen those statements in today's papers. They came from a press release from Senator Jocelyn Newman, the shadow Minister for defence science and personnel. The statements are replete with the type of comment that has come from the other side of the House allegedly supporting the Government's position but in fact opposing it. Senator Newman goes along with the theme which she has long adopted in that area, which is at least half suggestive of the motion that perhaps the Services ought to do other than operate under direct government directive. For example, she says:

ANSWER.PARA: Our servicemen and women have no right to speak about their own treatment. It is an ironic state of affairs when one considers that the essential duty of our Defence Force is to defend and protect our democracy and freedom of speech, yet they are the only Australian body of people denied just that-the freedom of speech.

Right through that press release is the implicit assumption that the defence forces have the right to avoid a direction from the Government on this matter or any other. That is an extraordinarily dangerous constitutional position. It would be an interesting matter of debate in itself. In this context, Senator Newman's statement is produced to provide implicit and explicit criticism of the Government's decision to employ the RAAF to fly people in this country in the absence of the capacity of the civilian airlines to fly them following the resignation of their pilots.

In answering the points the honourable gentleman made in his question, I have nothing but praise for the way in which the RAAF has conducted itself during the last week. It has provided an absolutely essential service and it has done it well. Senator Jocelyn Newman comments, `You can imagine how they personally feel'; I know they personally feel very good about it indeed. They are providing a service to the people of this country. The people who are using that service are expressing their gratitude when they get off the planes at the fact that they are able to get to their destinations. We are getting no complaints at all from the pilots about the services they are performing. That is the first point I make in response to the Opposition's continuing effort at subversion of the Government's activities in ensuring that the travelling public is properly served.

The next aspect of the honourable gentleman's question I will deal with relates to the priority of return from the Kangaroo 89 series exercises. In circumstances in which the travelling public is massively inconvenienced it would not be unusual if the Government were to assign a higher level of priority to shifting civilians around as opposed to leaving full time defence personnel in place on an exercise. In these circumstances it would not be unusual for the Government to do what has been suggested in Senator Newman's press release. The fact is that we are not; we are continuing to assign top priority over the other requirements to the return of defence personnel from the Kangaroo 89 series exercise. When the withdrawal of those personnel is complete we will have additional RAAF capacity available for civilian purposes. In some circumstances, people who would have been carried either by RAAF flights or by civilian flights on a charter basis have been picked up by Qantas. The fact is that the Government assigns higher priority to the completion of the Kangaroo exercise than it does to the shifting of civilians. There are aircraft to do both jobs.

We then get to the question of pay and allowances. It is erroneously claimed that pay has not been reviewed. It has been reviewed repeatedly and consistently upgraded in accordance with Government wage fixing principles. Those wage fixing principles have produced a massive lift in service allowances over the last couple of years and, most notably, given the nature of this particular issue, a 75 per cent increase to a maximum of $11,000 a year in the flying allowance. Those service pilots are paid well. They are certainly not paid as well as their civilian counterparts.

Eight hours a week at the stick is an unknown figure to Royal Australian Air Force pilots. The fact that they are not flying eight hours a week at the stick during these weeks is no particular hardship to them. They are, however, flying considerably more hours than they would normally; they are doing it cheerfully and under Government directive. They are accepting the role that the defence forces always accept from the Government in a democracy-that they act in accordance with Government directives. To fail to accept that principle introduces a revolutionary element into the politics of this country. The Opposition is prepared to assume tacitly that it will accept such a revolutionary element in this dispute. It is yet another example of its total unwillingness to confront this issue. There is no policy really in the Opposition as far as this is concerned. We have got the Chauncey Gardener of Australian politics leading the Opposition here. He is the man who likes to watch.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark.
—The Minister's remarks are not out of order but he should refer to members by their titles or by their electorates.
—The Leader of the Opposition is the Chauncey Gardener of Australian politics.
—The Minister will not compound the matter. The Minister will answer the question.

—I will withdraw. The point is that the Leader of the Opposition is not leading on this particular issue. He is allowing this plethora of criticism to emerge from his front bench, implicitly and explicitly, on the question of handling what is clearly absolutely critical to the issue of the future of the economy of this nation and this example from Senator Jocelyn Newman is simply the latest.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister now reached an agreement with the domestic airlines to pay compensation for their losses resulting from the pilots dispute?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of proposals that have recently been publicly canvassed to implement a two-rate personal income tax scale? Can the Treasurer advise the House on how such a scale could be implemented while also accommodating the objective of maintaining a tight fiscal policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that such a proposal could not be accommodated within current fiscal policy and the Budget saw the emergence of a bipartisan view about the fiscal stance when the Leader of the Opposition said in his Budget reply:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the forecast surplus this year is the right result achieved the wrong way.
He is endorsing the surplus and then in his speech headed `Fiscal and Monetary Policy' he says:

The Government has claimed a lot of credit for producing a $9.1 billion surplus this year. I am not about to criticise that for the sake of criticism but I have said that the surplus is the right result achieved in the wrong day.

So he has endorsed the Government's fiscal policy or the stance of fiscal policy. To just add some information to the debate about this proposal which we have seen floated about a two-rate personal income tax scale-that is, both by the Opposition and by other elements of the community-I have calculated how the present tax scale would have to be adapted to fulfil those conditions, that is, two rates only, the top rate no more than the company tax rate. Plus, I have assumed that nobody wants the existing tax bill to rise; so I have got that as a third condition. The lowest cost tax scale that could meet those three conditions would be to have the existing bottom rate of 21c running up to the existing 39c threshold and then 39c applying to all higher incomes. That is the lowest cost tax scale that is (a) flatter, (b) two rates only and (c) does not increase the tax bill for any taxpayer. As one would expect, it would be a typical kind of Liberal style tax cut.

There would be nothing for lower income earners. Nobody earning $17,000 or less would get any tax cut at all. There would be very little for middle income earners, a flat $4.55 running up to $35,000; and a lot at the top. At $100,000 it gives $104 a week. So, to sum it up, it is 55c a week for someone on $18,000 and $55 a week for someone on $68,000 a year. I table for the benefit of the House an actual rate scale and income scale. The cost of such a proposal would be $2.8 billion this financial year. The out year cost would be significantly higher. This is relevant when we consider that on the night the Leader of the Opposition replied to the Budget Speech he said:

Let us give them a scoop. First, we will move towards a flatter system of personal taxation that has only two marginal rates. Second, we will ensure that the top rate for individuals is not higher than the company tax rate.

The Leader of the Opposition, in his reply to the Budget Speech which was shown on national television, committed the Opposition parties to to a two-rate system, with the top personal rate aligned with the company tax rate. That was a firm commitment given to the public. Since then the Leader of the Opposition has used more obscure media performances to try to walk away from that commitment. In an interview on a radio program he said, `We would need to maintain for some time a three-rate system'. Later in the week he referred to a four-rate system. Apparently, at a press conference before lunch today he slid between two and four rates.

That $2.8 billion cost is on top of the cost of abolishing the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, providing a tax bias for families and an inflation adjustment for the tax system. It is supposed to be funded only by a $1 billion cut in government spending. So a $1 billion cut in government spending will fund a $2.8 billion cost in this financial year of that sort of rate scale, the abolition of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, substantiation, a tax bias for families, and an inflation adjustment for the tax system. The Leader of the Opposition said today that in a couple of weeks he will give us his tax details. This is about the fifteenth time we have been told that in the life of this Parliament. He has told us he will give us the details by October. He has approximately 30 days to give the Parliament and the public details of the tax scale.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't set our agenda.

—I will do a pretty reasonable job of it, brother. It will be interesting to see how much of the $2.8 billion the Leader of the Opposition includes in his figuring for his two-rate scale and his top rate alignment with the company rate. It will be interesting to hear whether it is the kind of tax scale which he could live with, because people on the bottom scale would get a 55c tax cut while people earning $65,000 would get $55. At the same time, he proposes to abolish the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, he would have a tax bias for families and, of course, there is his much heralded inflation adjustment for the tax system, from which he has been dissembling since the day he first raised it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. What are the financial arrangements between the Department of Defence and the commercial airlines for the provision of Boeing 707 and other aircraft for the carriage of their passengers? Is the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) receiving from the airlines the full ticketed fare or at least its full operating costs for the operation of the various aircraft?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —An agreement has been reached between the airlines and the RAAF for the use of its aircraft. I will give the honourable gentleman a more detailed answer, but off the top of my head, as I recollect it, as I dealt with the matter some time ago, the airlines are carrying the direct cost of supplying the aircraft with fuel and with what they need to fly at the time they fly. There is an agreed rate of subsequent payment for maintenance. The fares are being collected and the operation is being conducted by the airlines themselves, so there is a complex set of payment arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: The assumption is that this operation is being conducted on a non-subsidised basis. Of course, we have not had to do this before, and it is not inconceivable that we could find that there may be a gap between what is being paid for maintenance and the actual cost of flying the aircraft in these sorts of circumstances. If that were to occur, I would address my colleagues on that subject in the course of Additional Estimates committee hearings. However that is not anticipated as the likely outcome. We believe that we have struck a reasonable deal with the airlines. As I said, it will probably take some time and experience in the course of these operations to work out whether or not the operations are going exactly as we anticipated. However, it is our objective to ensure that civilian personnel get uplifted. It is not our objective to make a profit out of the airlines or to put the airlines in a situation in which they have difficulty in conducting their affairs. I think it is reasonable for me to ask the Opposition whether it has an alternative view on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister to inform the House of what action the Government is taking in response to continuing human rights violations around the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can truly say in this case that it is well known in the House that the honourable member for Hughes has a particular and continuing interest in this area of affairs. Australia is very active in making representations to foreign governments about human rights cases. The policy of the Government in this respect is unqualified and it is non-discriminatory. We make representations to any country from which we have received confirmed reports of human rights abuses. Human rights reporting by our overseas posts and our close links with Australian human rights groups, including the parliamentary group of Amnesty International, enable us to respond promptly to human rights abuses. I think it is a credit to this Parliament that in this area of Amnesty International activities we have a thoroughgoing bipartisanship.

ANSWER.PARA: Our immediate and unequivocal response to the tragic and deplorable events in China provides clear recent evidence of our commitment to this policy. I should say-I hope that without any question I would have the full support of all parts of the House-that we have recently made representations to Bulgaria on its policies of forced assimilation and repression of ethnic Turks which have led to an exodus of some quarter of a million of those unfortunate people to Turkey. I can say that we will continue to press our concerns to the Bulgarian authorities and to ask them to find a solution to the exodus which is satisfactory to all parties. We believe that it is also very important to participate in multilateral forums in order to develop and promote internationally accepted standards of human rights.

Briefly, in answer to the honourable gentleman's question, I repeat: wherever we have confirmed reports of the abuse of human rights, wherever they occur, we make appropriate representations. I am strengthened on the part of the Government in being able to do that by the bipartisanship which does exist substantially in this area. I repeat that particularly in the most recent case of the tragedy that is happening in regard to the ethnic Turks that are being expelled from Bulgaria we have made and will continue to make very strong representations in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister guarantee that the mixing of international and domestic passengers on trunk routes will not enable the transfer of items such as drugs between passengers in the cabin and hence circumvent normal Customs checks on exit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder when we are going to get to the bottom of the barrel with this mob opposite on this issue. First of all we had the issue that we were playing around with the safety of passengers because of a particular firm that had been chartered in, when the fact is that the Civil Aviation Authority, the independent body in this country which is responsible for handling these matters, made it clear that the charter in question satisfied the requirements of the Federal Aviation Authority in the United States and our own.

ANSWER.PARA: Having tried that fear and smear proposition in regard to the safety of the chartered aircraft, we now get to the question of drugs. I wonder when this pathetic mob opposite will stop dredging the barrel to find every conceivable argument they can to prop up and support the pilots. When are they going to stop? They impugn the Royal Australian Air Force and what it is doing, as though RAAF personnel are being dragooned. Not content with impugning our service men and women and questioning the safety of the aircraft that are brought in, they are now into drugs.

I give the same answer in regard to this miserable collection of people opposite, this thoroughly miserable, discreditable mob opposite: we have in this country competent, dedicated, arm's length independent authorities whose responsibility it is to discharge the laws and the regulations of this country. I have confidence that they will do so. For the sake of everything reasonable in this country will those opposite stop this incredibly stupid proposition of trying to find every conceivable argument they can for this Government giving up the fight, because it is too hard, against this group of people who are carrying out the Opposition's industrial relations policy? It is fair enough, in a sense, that honourable members opposite want to defend the pilots because they are carrying out their policy, but even with their limited sense of commitment to the interests of the nation one would have thought that by now they would have reached the end of the road or, more appropriately, they would have reached the bottom of the barrel. For God's sake, stop it!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I offer my congratulations on your appointment. Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of a decision announced by the Queensland Government that the rail freight rates will be changed for new and big expansions of existing mines? What effect will this have on the coal industry in Queensland? Does the Minister believe that these changes will help to solve the problems in this area?

—Firstly, I know that the honourable member for Oxley is very worried about the mines in his own electorate. Recently I visited some of them with him. Secondly, this change in policy relates only to new mines; it does not help existing mines in difficulty, particularly those in the west Moreton area. This is really a pre-selection stunt by the corrupt, undemocratic and increasingly desperate National Party Government in Queensland. I had hoped that someone would ask me a question about the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct but we have an enormous silence on that from honourable members on the other side of the House. Just as Ahern is stuck with that rotten, corrupt National Party Government in Queensland, so is every National Party member in this House. Criminality from Joh and Hinze. We have here the man who, in 1987, said, `Joh for Prime Minister'. What happened? There was not enough solidity, principle or policy on the other side of the House to resist that rotten old corrupt crook-except maybe the honourable member for Ryan.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. This is all about increasing desperation. This is going just a little bit of the way. The Queensland Government has always done a series of deals. It has never had any rational rail freight policy. It did a deal with this mining company or that mining company and it got to the absurd stage where any new mine that wanted to open up was faced with full costs. There was never any rational basis to the Government's rail charging policy as Queensland was run on nothing other than a series of hillbilly deals. The Liberal Party went along with that for most of the time it was in coalition. The National Party members in this House, particularly those from Queensland, stand condemned. For years that rotten corruption and nonsense was put up with by the Liberal and National Party members in this House-see no evil, hear no evil, think no evil. They all knew what was going on. This policy of the Queensland Government goes some way towards getting a rational discussion on this whole issue of rail freights for the coal industry in Queensland, but it is nothing other than a pre-selection stunt. It does not help existing mines; it does not help the mines for which the honourable member for Oxley is fighting so hard.

DEBATE.TITLE: SECOND WORLD WAR-CONTRIBUTION OF AUSTRALIAN MEN AND WOMEN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, remembering (a) that 3 September 1989 is the fiftieth anniversary of the outbreak of the Second World War and (b) that nearly 34,000 Australian service-men and women died in that conflict, this House expresses its profound hope that the troubled peace since the end of the War will become a permanent peace in the world and, in particular:

(1) reaffirms its deep and continuing gratitude to those Australian men and women who served their country in that War, both overseas and at home, and its continuing sympathy to the families and friends of those who died or were wounded in combat; and

(2) resolves to ensure that the sacrifices of those men and women were not made in vain, by meeting our nation's continuing defence and security responsibilities and by working to preserve and extend the goals for which the War was fought: a peaceful world in which the human rights and democratic aspirations of all men and women are inviolate.

On Sunday the world will mark the fiftieth anniversary of the beginning of the Second World War-the second time in our century that the tragedy of global conflict engulfed us. It is appropriate that the Australian Parliament should mark this event on behalf of the Australian people. As this motion notes, the anniversary of the outbreak of the war is a time for us to recall with deep gratitude the sacrifices made by all those Australian men and women who fought overseas and who served at home during the Second World War. It is a time to recall in particular the debt we owe to the 34,000 Australians who died in the conflict, to those who suffer still as a result of their experiences in the war, and to the families and friends of those who died.

So much has changed in the world over the past half century and in Australia's place in it that it is sometimes difficult for younger Australians to appreciate how much we owe to the generation which responded so bravely and so enthusiastically to the dreadful challenges of 1939 and the years that followed. But it was the heavy human and economic price they paid that resulted in the final defeat of fascism and imperialism and the liberation of the peoples of Europe and the Asia-Pacific region from the crushing weight of two barbarous tyrannies. This victory, in turn, permitted the creation of the most positive and dynamic feature of the world we have inherited-the collection of free, democratic and equitable societies in North America, Western Europe and East Asia that has been the driving force behind the development of the more prosperous and peaceful world order that now beckons us.

Australia reaped another benefit from the tragedy of the war-the immeasurable enrichment of our society through the massive influx of new settlers who fled the devastation of their war-ravaged homes to build a new life in the clear Australian atmosphere of freedom and prosperity.

It is true that the eventual victory in the Second World War did not secure for all people the democracy and human rights so painfully regained for some. As we have been reminded in the most moving way over the past few months in places as diverse as Beijing, Hungary, Poland and the Baltic states, the democratic impulse has been smothered for long periods throughout many parts of the world. But it now seems possible that parts of the world which had appeared frozen in repression may finally be able to take their place with the rest of humankind as we move to a more cooperative and prosperous future.

We are indeed privileged to be living through an exciting and challenging time in international affairs. For the first time in our unhappy century we can contemplate the idea of a world in which another global conflict seems improbable. Appalling problems, of course, remain. In places such as the Middle East where the suffering of the Lebanese people is so tragically prolonged and the gap between Arabs and Israelis is so apparently unbridgeable, and in South Africa under the abhorrent yoke of apartheid, peace still seems a distant and elusive hope. But, on the whole, we are entitled to permit ourselves a degree of optimism about the future.

So, this anniversary, Mr Speaker, gives us opportunity and it gives us reason to remember that we have reached this potentially benign point in human history only with the help of the sacrifices that were made by ordinary Australians during the Second World War. It gives us reason, too, to remember one of the great lessons of that war-that peace and security are fundamentally intertwined. Having recently returned from observing the Kangaroo 89 exercise I am particularly conscious of the role that the men and women of our Defence Force have played not only in time of war but also in preserving the peace. They serve us and our nation well.

Just as Australians can look back proudly on the part we played in helping to win the war, so we can reflect with pride on the way we have helped to sustain the peace. In recent years Australia has made intensive efforts to contribute to an international climate aimed at protecting and expanding peace. Throughout active work in multilateral arms control organisations, by our diplomatic action in our own region, and through the influence we have exerted within the councils of our alliance relationship, we have been able to work towards a safer world. In particular, we have made our voice heard loudly in support of the very welcome measures that have already been taken by the superpowers to reduce their deadly arsenals of nuclear weapons. Although much more has yet to be done, we have worked tirelessly to reduce the risk of other countries joining the nuclear club and we have been at the leading edge of international efforts to prevent the proliferation of the modern plague of chemical weapons.

As we consider this motion today, Australians are helping to keep the peace on behalf of the United Nations, often in dangerous and uncomfortable conditions in Namibia, in Cyprus, in southern Lebanon and Golan Heights, and along the battle-scarred border between Iraq and Iran. I call on honourable members to support the motion before the House and, at the conclusion of the consideration of the moment, to join me in a moment of silence, recalling the courage of those who died in the Second World War, the resilience of those who survived, and our common hope that by our actions we will repay the debt we owe those Australians, in the best way we can, by ensuring that such sacrifices are never again necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost 50 years ago my predecessor in the seat of Kooyong, the then Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, in sadness and regret, announced to a troubled nation that England had declared war on Germany and as a result Australia was also at war. In every city and town, from Hobart to the cane fields and mining communities of the outback, people gathered around radio sets listening to those words of ominous tidings little realising that the carnage to follow would ultimately involve every continent and prove even more devastating than the Great War of 1914 to 1918. So began an episode in our nation's history and our world's development which we should neither forget nor do anything to cause a repetition. Fifty years later we remember that war and draw upon its experience to strengthen our pursuit of a world free from needless conflict and bloodshed, a world which respects and dignifies fundamental human rights, a world in which every nation has a vested interest in continuing peace, cooperation and freedom.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I second this motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I was pleased that it had drafting input from my office. As such, it stands as a declaration on behalf of the three political parties represented in this chamber and by implication it has the unqualified support of every member of the House. It is appropriate for the Prime Minister to move the motion, for the Parliament today to pay due recognition to the fiftieth anniversary of the outbreak of the Second World War and to express the important sentiment and hope embraced in the terms of the resolution put to the House by the Prime Minister.

The war was the seminal experience of any Australian alive at that time, including those who subsequently came to our country through immigration in the postwar years to escape the ravaged and torn European subcontinent. Indeed, it is the only war in our two centuries of existence as a nation which has actually touched Australian soil-the bombing of Darwin and submarine attacks in Sydney Harbour by the Japanese. It was a war provoked by a sinister and evil ideology which poisoned the very soul of humanity with racial slaughter and acts of barbaric brutality against captured enemies and against innocent civilians alike.

As an escapade in mass war culminating in the use of atomic weapons, it changed forever the nature of great power conflict. The Second World War was also, as I think the Prime Minister indicated in his speech, the turning point of modern history. It marked the end of colonialism as the practice of European empires, and the end of American isolationism, and it changed forever the global balance of power. We entered the war a dominion of the British Empire. We were targeted for Japanese attack at Hitler's request in 1941 to weaken the Empire by capturing its colonies. We ended the war an ally of the United States, to which free world leadership passed as surely as economic leadership began to shift from Europe to the Pacific rim.

Every citizen of Australia and of other countries more directly involved in the conflagration was intimately touched and affected by the six years of prolonged and bloody conflict. The Second World War was a tragedy of unbelievable magnitude in human, physical and social terms. Some 50 million people, military and civilian, lost their lives on the battlefields or as innocent victims of war. The Soviet Union by itself suffered an estimated 20 million dead. To put that into perspective, imagine the entire population of our country, with an additional three million people, forever wiped out from the face of the earth.

Our own country, small though it was, paid an enormous price for peace, as welcome and overdue as that was. Unquestionably the cream of a generation was lost in senseless bloodshed in the mud of Europe and the festered tropics of Asia and the Pacific. Some returned home wounded, some permanently incapacitated; services lost to our nation. Thirty-four thousand Australian service men and women gave their lives in the conflict within both the European and the Pacific theatres of war. Of a national population of only seven million in the war years, over 900,000 Australian men and women answered the call to duty and enlisted in the armed forces for part or all of the war, and of those over 550,000 courageous people served outside Australia in wider fields of conflict, where they carried with honour the pride and the character established by the Anzacs, the original diggers at Gallipoli and in the Somme. By the end of the war, 20 Victoria Crosses had been awarded to Australian service personnel in recognition of outstanding courage, determination and bravery.

This touches, does it not, one of the awful ironies of war: in the face of horror and destruction there emerge inspiring and heroic acts in which considerations of personal safety surrender to a selfless determination to succeed. All of us in this House-and this attitude is shared by all parties-have a continuing debt of gratitude and care for many of our former service men and women and their families. Over 600,000 veterans, their wives or widows and dependants, are reliant on disability and service pensions. This is not a form of compensation to them; it is the execution of an ongoing duty to provide support which I believe is acknowledged by all sides.

In the Second World War what can be described only as the darker side of human personality emerged. All wars are horrific, but in that Second World War nowhere did horrific acts reach such appalling depths as in Hitler's genocidal Holocaust against the European community of Jews. In this respect, as in others, there was a concert of intent and sympathy between the communist tradition and the fascism of Hitler's national socialism. Even before the war there were signs of impending racist horror when Nazi-inspired prejudice led to the destruction of shops and houses owned by German Jews. The systematic slaughter of six million Jews, shipped like cattle to fields where they were mercilessly gunned to death in mass graves, poisoned in showers of cyanide, literally carved up alive by the surgeons of hate, or locked in concentration camps where torture and starvation were the orders of the day, was a genocide without equal in history.

A decade or more ago we saw elements of this in Cambodia. The Prime Minister does the House justice and right when he talks of the need for us to work for peace, to enshrine the principles of freedom and democracy and never again to allow such events to occur. They can be avoided, as he says, only with the conjoint of peace and security. Peace cannot be wished for; it has to be worked at. All honourable members would join in working for what he gave voice to today.

I mentioned at the outset that the Liberal and National parties entirely support the sentiment of the motion. Fifty years ago the world entered a period of great darkness and despair. Through sacrifice, struggle and determined effort the people of the free world emerged triumphant. Whatever our partisan political differences-and this is the chamber whose right to enact legislation despite those differences was fought for-our continuing overriding mission, notwithstanding philosophic differences, is to maintain the pursuit of peace through democratic means and to ensure that the blood of our children should never stain the soil of foreign lands, let alone the wattle. I join the Prime Minister in commending the motion and in the moment of silence in the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I would like to join with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in supporting this motion. As a member of the generation born after World War II, I am very conscious of the enormous debt of gratitude that my generation owes to those who served during the Second World War. Our lack of direct recollection of the war in no way diminishes our abhorrence of the Third Reich or our resolve to be both vigilant and prepared. To my knowledge, while only two members of the House at the present time-the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar)-participated in this war on Australia's behalf, many in this chamber today will have memories of the war. Almost all members' families will have been affected in one way or another in various countries, as my family was affected by the tragedy of World War II.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a mountain of literature now available about the nature of the Third Reich leadership. The inhumanity and sheer maliciousness of the regime is beyond dispute. Out of this horror, however, came a great sense of camaraderie within Australian society. Our people pulled together. There was a sense of team and purpose as the whole nation worked to defeat what was a great evil. Of course, the greatest sacrifice was borne by those in the services. At the end of the war the Australian service personnel returned with an outstanding reputation for toughness, initiative and thorough professionalism.

Like their fathers before them, the Australians also went overseas with an earthy commonsense. The work of the Repatriation Commission and our repatriation hospitals is a reminder to us all of the continuing need to care for and to compensate those who returned. Those who did not return left behind widows and families. In that context I commend the fine work of Legacy and the Returned Services League throughout Australia. We all hope that such an appalling conflict never again occurs. We must be both vigilant and prepared. World War II offers us an insight into the bitter consequences of a lack of preparedness and vigilance. To illustrate this point I would like to quote briefly a short passage from Gavin Long's official history of Australia in the war:

Ministers, hoping at the eleventh hour war might be avoided, sought to escape lasting defence commitments. From this point of view it might prove more economical to order equipment abroad rather than establish factories to make it at home, to increase the militia than recruit long service regular units.
History had proved and was to prove again the futility of such a military policy.
Defence is not cheap, but, as those who returned will remind us, the price of liberty is eternal vigilance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—The honourable member will not debate the issue. He will say where he was misrepresented and then resume his seat.

—It has, for example, been asserted, as did the Minister during Question Time, that I was incorrect in saying that site allowances had never been part of awards. The fact is I am correct in saying that. Secondly, I have pointed out that since May the Industrial Commission has refused to consider site allowances--
—You are now arguing the point. You are now debating the matter--
—And it is claimed that I am incorrect in that. No, Mr Speaker, I am pointing out where it is being said that I am incorrect--

—I think it is only reasonable that I should be able to point out what the correction is, otherwise the point is lost.

—No, it is not reasonable. The time in the proceedings to do that can either be by a substantive motion or on the adjournment. The procedure at this stage is that you can say where you were misrepresented and then resume your seat.

—Mr Speaker, the company, that is Remm, and also the Minister have gone on to say that I was incorrect in pointing out that there was a $1.50 site allowance which was not in the award. DEBATE.TITLE: MASONIC PEACE MEMORIAL HAVEN OF NORTHERN TASMANIA (INC.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Management Performance Review on the Masonic Peace Memorial Haven of Northern Tasmania (Inc.), and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the Management Performance Review on the Masonic Peace Memorial Haven of Northern Tasmania (Inc.)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The funding of the Peace Haven Nursing Home has attracted considerable press coverage in Tasmania and there have been many requests for the release of this report. In July 1988 new funding arrangements for nursing and personal care staff in nursing homes were introduced. Under these arrangements, for the first time in Australia, nursing homes are funded by the Commonwealth according to the needs of their residents, rather than the lobbying powers of nursing home management or historical factors.

SPEECH.PARA: Peace Haven Nursing Home, operated by Masonic Peace Memorial Haven of Northern Tasmania Inc, received extremely generous funding under the old arrangements-well in excess of those received by other Tasmanian nursing homes. Apart from extremely generous capital funding of $902,200, this nursing home was funded for the highest infrastructure costs of all Tasmanian nursing homes. While the new arrangements are reducing the infrastructure funding of Peace Haven, some 90 per cent of nursing homes in Tasmania are receiving real term increases. In addition, while the average nursing home in Tasmania received recurrent funding for 17.1 hours per resident per week, Peace Haven was funded for more than 10 hours above this average.

Over the past few months, it became apparent that the management of Peace Haven would prefer to continue to receive more funding than other nursing homes and was refusing to accept the new funding arrangements which treat all nursing homes equally. In an attempt to force the Government to approve huge additional funding for this home, the management of Peace Haven made public threats that they would close the doors of the home if such funding was not forthcoming. These threats aroused fears amongst the residents of the home, and their relatives, that they, or their loved ones, would be forced onto the streets because Commonwealth funding for the home was inadequate. For this reason, I was pleased to meet Peace Haven's public request for an independent examination of the financial arrangements of the home.

This report, which is the end result of that independent examination, was researched by one of Australia's experts on nursing home finances, Mr Peter Geary of Coopers and Lybrand. It finds that efficient management of the home should turn its current operating loss into a sizeable operating surplus, within the funding presently provided by the Commonwealth Government. Mr Geary's report also highlights the exceptionally high level of money being spent on administrative staff at the home, and the fact that some of the costs incurred by Peace Haven have actually been on behalf of other facilities. The report stresses that poor management practices had been the cause of most of the financial problems of the home. While these poor practices could be supported under the previous inequitable funding arrangements, they cannot continue now.

The report clearly supports the Commonwealth's position regarding this home. It does not, in any way, support the repeated and public claims by Peace Haven's management that the level of Commonwealth funding was inadequate and that therefore the home was being forced to close. It is in response to these allegations by Peace Haven's management, which were supported by some members of this House, that I have now tabled this report. I present the following paper:
Masonic Peace Memorial Haven of Northern Tasmania (Inc).-Management Performance Review-Ministerial Statement, 31 August 1989.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the presentation of this report on the Masonic Peace Memorial Haven of Northern Tasmania (Inc.), which, I must say, is in stark contrast to the initial press releases put out by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) in this regard. I think some of his comments may have unnecessarily offended the nursing home involved. Some of those comments related to poor management, too many administration staff, and the fact that a higher level of service could be obtained if certain practices were in place. An implication regarding the standard of care was commented on by the author, Mr Geary of Coopers and Lybrand. There was also a comment by the Minister about the nursing home refusing to accept the umpire's decision. In fact, if one looks at the report, one sees that it commends the home on its high level of service and it made no detrimental comment whatsoever in that regard. In fact, the nursing home itself asked for the report to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The report must be looked at in the context of its very narrow terms of reference. Some more meaningful investigations into the home, and the problems of funding dementia care, were omitted from this report. Therefore, while I have every faith in the accountants who prepared this report, some of the methods they used to determine that funding could be saved might miss the point, because such reductions in service and nursing hours care might lead to a deterioration in the fine service that this home has provided.

In June I visited the nursing home involved in this consultant's report, at the invitation of the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), in whose electorate this nursing home is located. It had its problems. One problem was that it had raised these matters with the Minister last July and had received no response from him until January, and even then the response did not adequately address those queries. Invitations have been extended to the Minister to visit this home. I suggest that he avail himself of that invitation because it is a very important matter. The major problem facing the aged care industry at the moment is dementia. This particular home devotes itself particularly to the care of people with dementia. It provides this facility at a cost of just over $2m. At one stage it was reaching for an area of excellence in nursing care which it was hoped could be provided.

I reiterate that the Minister might do as well-he has been hasty in bringing in this particular report-to give this chamber the report that was provided by the Victorian Aged Services Peak Council. As a result of a study over a selection of 27 homes it has indicated that there is a problem in the funding of aged persons homes just on a normal basis, but there is a greater and additional problem with the care of people with dementia. In this particular report to which I am referring, the aims were identified as follows:

1. Identification of the impact of SAM/CAM on the quality of care in and on the viability of Victorian Nursing Homes; 2. Assembly of information about changes in Nursing Home policies, procedures or practices brought about by the new funding system; 3. Development of options under the proposed incentives funds concept for programmes which lift Nursing Home care above custodial to high quality care.
I will just mention briefly the impact of this report. It is just an abstract section, and four clear conclusions emerged. Firstly, under the heading `Working conditions', it is stated:
Working conditions for nurses and other staff are pressured and strained, and this is already causing major stresses in the system . . . Occupational injuries are increasing.
Secondly, under the heading `Communication with residents', it is stated:
A rushed atmosphere is discernible in homes which have experienced funding cuts and have accommodated these cuts by staff reductions.
Thirdly, under the heading `Diminution of choice', the report states:
The overall pattern that was observable was one of paring activities back to medical and nursing necessities in a tense and pressured environment.
Fourthly, under the heading `Maintenance', it is stated:
Major concerns emerged in the study that the maintenance of buildings and equipment was a significant casualty of reduced funding.

I mention this only because this report could have applied itself to the aspect of underfunding particularly in the dementia area. The Government is wasting 18 months in coming to grips with this problem by embarking on a consultancy when evidence is available within this home. Authors within the industry right around Australia have committed themselves to paper on this problem of dementia, and the conclusions that are drawn there are available. Unless the Minister addresses himself more purposefully to the funding of this dementia problem, it will not go away; it will be exacerbated and it will not be tackled within the time it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Masonic Peace Haven Nursing Home is in my electorate. I will not canvass the broader issues that have been raised by my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), but I would say that this issue does have a broader implication; that is, the whole question of the treatment of dementia in our community. What happened in Tasmania with regard to this home I think needs to be put into perspective. As the honourable member for Dawson pointed out, the brief statement by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) does not gel with some of the rather outlandish press statements he made after the release of this independent report. He was asked some considerable time ago by myself, by the Board and by other members of parliament, both at State and Federal level, to come to Launceston and discuss with the management of the home the difficulties that it was having with the new funding guidelines known as the care aggregate module (CAM) and standard aggregate module (SAM) arrangements. He rejected those invitations and I think that it was remiss of him to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: This home enjoyed the strong support of the former Minister for Community Services, Senator Don Grimes. He, of course, was from Launceston. The community enjoyed the relationship that had developed with Senator Grimes in the provision of this home, which is the most modern in Tasmania and has the largest dementia unit in Tasmania. It is one of the largest of its type in Australia. The issue of the funding of these dementia units has to be looked at in this sense: it does not have normal nursing home requirements; the nursing home requirements and staff requirements of non-nursing staff are much greater and, therefore, cost much more than they do in normal nursing homes. What the Board was concerned about, and what every nursing home board and every member of this House should be concerned about, is that with the community rapidly ageing, life expectancies lengthening all the time and the incidence of dementia increasing, the issues that arose in Launceston have national significance. We wanted from the Minister some understanding and some capacity to deal with the issues in a sensitive way. In the end he chose to do what I believe was quite contrary to the principles he should have been following: he rejected invitations and he responded after the release of an independent report in a most cavalier fashion.

I remind the Minister-I think it is sad that he has chosen to leave the chamber when we have been allowed only some few minutes to debate this matter-that there was in Launceston a community meeting of parliamentary leaders. Present were Labor Party members, Independent members, members of the independent Legislative Council, representatives from Senator Aulich's office and Federal politicians. A response was drafted by me, signed by these people and sent to the Minister. This is what we said:

We welcomed the initiative to immediately have an independent analysis of the home's financial position under the Commonwealth's complex funding formula. We wish to point out to you that all of us view with deep concern the development of a situation that would see the special 48-bed dementia unit closed. The social consequences of such a move are not acceptable to our community and we thus seek your assistance to do all in your power to forestall such an eventuality. We urge that upon the completion of the independent analysis you move quickly to discuss with the home and the State government all avenues to maintain the excellent services that are now provided. As this is Tasmania's largest specialist dementia unit to allow it to close due to a funding crisis and a seemingly alleged inflexibility of the current guidelines is an issue intolerable in a compassionate and caring community. We need your urgent help. Helpful intervention in this matter is respectfully sought and urged.

We got our independent report, which found that the home was providing expert care; that there were avenues where savings could be made; and that there would have to be delicate negotiations with the Hospital Employees Federation to determine staff cuts. Ten people have lost their jobs. Ten of those people are not nursing staff; two are. I think the attack the Minister made on the management of the home is despicable. It is not appreciated by members of the community which I represent, be they Labor, Liberal or Independent voters. We felt that we got no consideration from the Minister. The approach of his Canberra bureaucrats-not, I might say, of the representatives of his Department in Tasmania, who were most sympathetic and helpful at all times-is to be deplored. In my view, the person who prepared the press release for the Minister ought to be put under extreme scrutiny. If the Minister read that press release before he put it out he ought to be ashamed of himself. His allegation that there was mismanagement in that home is utterly and totally false.

As I said at the beginning of my brief remarks, this is a very broad issue that all of us in this place ought to be cognisant of. This home took the only possible avenue of action that it could after having been ignored continually by the Minister for some 12 months. I believe that the steps the home is now taking to ensure that it stays open and that the 48-bed special dementia unit is able to provide people with the top flight care it is now providing is something for which all in my community are very grateful. For the Minister to come in here and make a statement that is completely contrary to the original remarks he made to the press, acknowledging that the home provides good care and ignoring the broader issues of dementia in our community, really marks him as a Minister who fundamentally does not understand the very difficult issues that this Parliament has charged him to deal with.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Airline Pilots Dispute
Commonwealth Offices Project

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Commonwealth offices project, Alice Springs.

This is a proposal to erect an office building in Alice Springs which will provide 2,800 square metres of usable office space with underground parking. The proposal is in line with Government objectives of increasing the proportion of owned office accommodation and reducing overall costs associated with rented accommodation. At present the Commonwealth leases about 4,750 square metres of office space in Alice Springs. The proposed building of 2,800 square metres replaces space that is currently leased but is inadequate in terms of size, standard and location. The original plan was for an office building of 3,600 square metres at an estimated final cost of $9m. Further analysis of the office accommodation market in Alice Springs has indicated that the proposal needed to be reduced to 2,800 square metres as some Commonwealth agencies were suitably accommodated in leased space at a justified rental rate in the private sector. This proposition is a compromise between public sector accommodation and private sector accommodation at Alice Springs. The proposal to build the 3,600 square metre office could not be economically sustained at this time. The proposed building has capacity for a future extension when we might require it. A detailed economic analysis has shown that the proposal I have just described is a sound real estate investment against a number of parameters including construction cost, level of financial return, ongoing management costs and residual value.

The provision of a Commonwealth centre in Alice Springs is considered essential to the provision of efficient Commonwealth services in the region. The building will also serve as the regional headquarters for areas such as Yulara, Tennant Creek, and as far north as Elliot. This proposal would allow ready access by the public to a building clearly identifiable as the focus of Commonwealth services and activity in Alice Springs. The major tenants for the proposed building are the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Commonwealth Employment Service. The building structure will have the capacity to provide an additional floor of some 1,400 square metres to cater for future expansion. Two groups within the Department of Administrative Services are involved in the project. The proposal is sponsored and will be managed by the Australian Property Group-situated within my Department-and it will be designed and built by Australian Construction Services, also situated within my Department.

The limit of cost estimate at August 1989 is $5.68m and the total estimated cost on completion is approximately $7m, inclusive of fitout, escalation and fees. I have much pleasure in tabling all drawings of the proposed works and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the reference of this work to the Standing Committee on Public Works, which no doubt will consider all the implications. Nevertheless, I wish to draw to the attention of the Parliament the fact that this now brings to $550m recent construction proposals by the Commonwealth, using taxpayers' funds, primarily for new office buildings. The Opposition is concerned about this for a number of reasons. Firstly, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) advises us that industry would be subjected to interest rates at 24 per cent to slow down economic activity. Whenever the Opposition raises questions about cuts in government spending there is an immediate reference to welfare as though that were the only place where the Commonwealth could reduce its expenditure and the effect on the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly such projects as the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) keeps bringing to this Parliament almost on a weekly basis, are also areas of government expenditure that have a severe effect on the overheating of our economy. One would wonder whether, in every case, the money is warranted. The projects cover a variety of requirements. Such things as airports naturally contribute to our export effort and are to be encouraged, but a lot of the office buildings that the Government is constructing are available from the private sector and, irrespective of the Minister's view of what is reasonable by way of accommodation, they are clearly being provided at the present. No doubt the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is deeply concerned about this matter but it is no good the Treasurer using punitive interest rates on the private sector to restrict its investment in our economy and then the Government going down the road of spending $550m to counteract that particular situation.

It is also notable of course that a large number of these projects, this one included, are in marginal Labor seats and one must wonder to what extent the pork barrel is at work. They are the comments I wish to make. I hope that when the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works starts considering some of these proposals, it takes into account the Treasurer's words in terms of his intention of slowing economic activity and the pressure he is putting on the private sector through interest rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend this reference from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) and make a couple of comments on some of the absurd statements which have been made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). I would like the previous speaker to take his statements to the Northern Territory and explain to the building and construction industry why he thinks it should not have these sorts of developments in the Northern Territory. The sorts of capital works programs that this Government has been proposing, and has announced in the last Budget, are the sorts of programs which would be an inducement to the building and construction industry in the Northern Territory to get out of its trough.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the honourable member opposite, who apparently bleeds concern for people in the business sector, would be supporting their wishes that these sorts of constructions go ahead. There is no doubt that this building will be very important for the local Alice Springs economy but it will also, as the Minister pointed out, rationalise the Government's use of office space. In that sense it is an economically sound proposition, one which ought to be supported by the Opposition and one which I think, under closer examination, the previous speaker would support totally without the derogatory remarks which he made at the conclusion of his speech.
