PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This, I am mindful, is the sixteenth annual Budget which I have had the opportunity of addressing since being elected to the Parliament in 1974. I am mindful also, as a consequence of my announcement that I am not going to contest the next election, that it is the last Budget I will have an opportunity of addressing. Over that period I have enjoyed-to use the word perversely-a period in opposition and a period in government, and I am back in opposition. I have experienced the fervour, the fever, of the Whitlam period with innovative measures warmly embraced by society; the more sober-dare I say responsible-Fraser Government which fell short of the expectations of the electorate for reasons that may be argued; and now the present Government which has left its particular imprimatur on our society and on our economy. What have those three periods got in common? They have in common the harsh realisation that none of them have been able to cope in absolute terms with the problems confronting our country. They have all failed to establish confident, positive, viable, firmly based economies with prospects. They have all pursued the expectations of a society which expectations in the main have been far removed from entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: Again today we have the opportunity under this Appropriation Bill just to step back and have a look at our country, where we have been, where we are and where we are going. The Budget essentially addressing the revenue and outlays of the Government invites address probably on two elements, quantum and quality. Quality of course is the area in which the political parties, government and opposition, can demonstrate their particular character and the establishment of priorities as to where the outlays may be placed. By way of illustration, it is not inconceivable that some of us on this side of the House may have a predisposition or an inclination to give a greater priority to expenditure on roads, rather than pursuing funding to achieve excellence in sport. I hasten to say that I do not dismiss that activity as being without some relevance to an orderly society, but it is a question of priorities.

So it is the area of quality priorities which distinguish one group from another and in the fullness of time requires an electorate to make a judgment as to in whose hands the future of the country might be best placed. But the quantum is the challenging element, because in that term rests the continuing challenge: how within the resources we possess can we fairly accommodate the entitlements of the community, but worse still the expectations of the community, because there is no question of doubt that invariably a substantial gulf exists between the expectation and the entitlement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which we feed.

—And we feed, as the honourable member for Curtin anticipates my comments, because in the nature of the democratic system governments are not free to govern wisely lest their very wisdom has them promptly dispatched from office. It is necessary to accommodate the expectation of the electorate essentially to maintain oneself in office or alternatively to attain office. That explains perhaps why there is an aura of impotence within our society and within this Parliament presently, why it is not possible for the opposition of the day to clearly establish attractive alternatives, just as it is not possible for the Government to satisfy the community that it has the solution in hand to restore the fortunes of the Australian populace.

SPEECH.PARA: The bitter irony of it all is that the fortunes which the electorate seeks to have restored, by some economic legerdemain or some irresponsibility of government of this Parliament, and which it previously enjoyed, should in fact not have been enjoyed. I do not say this out of any lack of charity or sympathy for my fellows. The realisation springs from the simple fact that we in this country, a mere 16 million people, are clawing for a toehold on this planet in competition with near 6,000 million fellow human creatures who owe us nothing. Yet we have the conceit to strut and swagger as if we are masters of our own destiny. Our fortunes rest in the manner in which we can acquit ourselves in the global marketplace.

One does not have to be an intellectual colossus to work out that at any one time not all nations on earth can enjoy a trading surplus. One nation's fortune becomes another nation's misfortune in economic terms. Somehow or other we seem to believe that we can ignore that truism. So in this country of ours, blessed with such incredible resource and happy circumstance, inviting exploitation in the proper use of the term, we have elected to do nothing about it, to let opportunity go by, deluding ourselves that somehow or other we had entitlements. Of course, there can be a reasonable expectation. There is a reasonable expectation that when young people marry they have a right to a house. That is a nice notion, even though, sadly, I must admit that I can recall as a child of tender years that the ambition of my aunts and uncles when approaching matrimony was to find a nice little place to rent. If they found it they were in paradise.

Today things have subtly changed because we have enjoyed good fortune, circumstantially. We have lost touch with reality and believe that to be the norm. We predicated all our thinking on that proposition. The reality is that these entitlements are relative. Let me give a very simple example to underpin that proposition. We are all dedicated to the proposition that we should look after our ageing population-those who, in their own and various ways, have made contributions over the years and are now in the twilight of their lives. We subscribe to the popular and supportable proposition that through welfare schemes we should support them with a pension. The Government of the day is to be congratulated for finally edging up the old age pension to 25 per cent of the average wage. I congratulate the Government. There would not be a pensioner in Australia who was not absolutely convinced that the pension was his or her unassailable entitlement. We believe that, within ordinary parameters.

Today, just within the last hour, this House has marked the events of 50 years ago. Is it reasonable to put up the proposition that if the enemy alluded to had invaded this country, as he could well have done so far as our military capacity to repel him was concerned, the pension cheques would have gone out a fortnight later? Would anybody have suggested that we had rights? The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) could tell us that in his war experiences he did not even have the right to human dignity. He was subjected to the most extraordinary experiences because of that involvement, that circumstance. So when we say that we have an entitlement, it is a relative term. It is an expectation predicated on precedent or practice. They are all within our reach if we apply ourselves within the essential confines, the confines of the marketplace. In simple terms, we have to provide the right article at the right place at the right time. We must be competitive.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I had the pleasure of your company in South Korea on a parliamentary delegation last year. I would not presume to say that you could make a reciprocal comment, but you also witnessed the incredible development in growth in South Korea. South Korea has virtually dragged itself up by the bootlaces in the past 20 years-out of the rice paddies. It is going to be a creditor nation in 1991. We could talk about working conditions and say that the South Koreans work six days a week. From my observations, there were no sweatshops and the people were not exploited, but their cost of unit production was lower than ours and therefore they were able to capture the global markets. We could do that but we resile from the proposition that we should because we have become accustomed to conditions reconciling with our expectations as distinct from our entitlements.

The choice is ours. If we want to finish up as a banana republic, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) foreshadowed a year or two ago, that is fine-if we are reconciled to the lifestyle that attaches itself to that changed environment. If instead we have a preference to legitimise and consolidate that which we have been enjoying as a consequence of our expectations, and intimidating political parties in or out of government to accommodate it, then our future is already written. There is no future.

In this Parliament we have a gathering of talent-at times cunningly disguised, but talent nevertheless. It grieves me, in the twilight of my parliamentary career, to see that talent dissipated and thoroughly wasted in pointless political confrontation. I am not being naive. The very nature of the profession suggests that there will always be a trial of strength. If we persist in deluding an electorate that we can restore its fortunes by some artificial economic device, by some economic legerdemain, which will free people from the requirement to measure up, to toil, to sell their talents in the marketplace and to be rewarded accordingly, we betray them. It is as simple as that. We have been betraying them because of the very nature of the democratic system in which governments are not free to govern wisely. We accommodate the electorate.

I point out in analogous and very simple terms-so simple as to be almost an affront to the intelligence; it is not intended to be so-that in my seventh Parliament I am convinced that there is only one point of difference between governing a country in a democracy and bringing up a family where the youngsters know in an instant what they want. The parents, hopefully having acquired a modicum of wisdom through experience, have to make a judgment essentially on two points: firstly, whether it is good for them; and, secondly, whether they can afford it. If the answer is no on either point, the youngsters instantly hate their parents' guts but they cannot vote them out at the next election. That is the only point of difference. Honourable gentlemen should ponder that. The more they ponder the more they will realise that that is the continuing frustration of trying to discharge one's responsibilities to the generations yet to come and to accommodate the reasonable expectations of our society.

Government remains impotent to deal with the problems with which we are confronted unless it can gain the cooperation of the electorate. For the electorate to have confidence in the diagnostician, it must be given the facts. Just as the worker in the field must realise that the best job conditions on earth are not worth a crumpet if they have the effect of putting his employer out of business, he or she must have confidence in the employer and must have the facts. Workers must know how the company stands and what it is about so that we can bring our collective talents and resources together to get this country where it should have been and where it could be. If we persist in deluding ourselves that we can just snap our fingers and achieve that condition, there is no solution.

I say without any overtones of superiority that throughout the Whitlam and Fraser periods and now throughout the Hawke period we have shrunk from our responsibilities and perpetuated the notion that expectation is synonymous with entitlement. It rarely is. It is high time this Parliament-I use the term advisedly-came clean with the electorate. Failure to do so will ensure that this country will sink further into the mire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) for his contribution, which was, as usual, erudite. Whilst I did not agree with everything he had to say I did have some sympathy for a great deal of it. He referred to reasonable expectations. He said that some believe reasonable expectations to be an entitlement. He said that an expectation is predicated on precedent or practice. The matter I wish to refer to during the short time I have available this afternoon goes to the heart of what the honourable member for Wide Bay has said.

SPEECH.PARA: We have within the labour market reasonable expectations. Most of the Australian work force accepts that those reasonable expectations will be met within the confines of the industrial relations system. There are some, however, who have sought to have what they perceive to be their reasonable expectations seen as an entitlement which, as the honourable member for Wide Bay said, is predicated on their belief about precedent or practice. I am, of course, talking about the pilots. They have asserted an entitlement which is not a reasonable expectation by any stretch of the imagination. It is not an expectation that is shared by the rest of the Australian work force, which has been happy to play by the rules set down by the Industrial Relations Commission and which has worked actively through the trade union movement and has accepted the umpire's rules. A reasonable expectation of government might be that under the industrial relations system wage claims would be confined to a certain ceiling as a result of an agreement between the Government and the trade union movement-that is, the accord.

A group of people have asserted an entitlement and, unfortunately, it is based on precedent or past practice. In 1966 pilots went on strike for 28 days because they wanted a 28 per cent wage increase. In 1974 there was a further dispute when the pilots wanted a 27 per cent wage increase. On this occasion they are seeking a 30 per cent wage increase. I would not have thought it was reasonable to hold the Australian economy to ransom because of what they perceive to be an entitlement. I think the honourable member for Wide Bay was right in that sense, because the pilots have not seen what their reasonable expectation ought to be within the confines of the Australian economy and the industrial relations system. What they have said to the Australian community, the Government, the companies for which they worked and the travellers they carry is that they are not prepared to be in a system which sets reasonable expectations in terms of limits; they feel that they are entitled to go outside the system and try to negotiate a wage increase which is 25 per cent above the norm. They can have only one ultimate purpose in doing that-that is, breaking the system. Is it not a reasonable expectation of the rest of the Australian work force that those people should act responsibly and say, `We realise the implications of our action'? They have not done that. Quite the contrary: they have thumbed their nose at the Australian work force.

I will illustrate the implications of the pilots' actions on a small community in central Australia and outline what it will mean to that community if they pursue their actions. I am talking about my home-that is, Alice Springs. We have talked about reasonable expectations. It is a reasonable expectation of the residents of Alice Springs and travellers who wish to go there that they should be able to fly in and out. However, they cannot do so because of the absurd claim being made by the pilots which, unfortunately, seems to be supported by some sections of the Opposition, at least tacitly, by its failure to speak out against it. It is a reasonable expectation of the Australian community that Opposition members would speak out vehemently against the pilots and the threat they pose to the Australian economy, particularly the tourism industry. But we have not heard them do so. They have vindictively attacked the Government for an alleged failure to handle the dispute properly. The Australian community has a reasonable expectation-indeed, an entitlement in this instance-that the Australian Government and this Parliament should stop such absurd claims which would wreak havoc on the industrial relations system and the Australian economy.

The implications of the pilots' action for their fellow Australians are yet to be estimated. However, the tourism industry in Alice Springs in the central Australian region is on its knees as a direct result of the pilots' actions. Opposition spokesmen have spoken out against using military aircraft-Royal Australian Air Force aircraft-to transport passengers. Let me inform honourable members of the net effect on Alice Springs of the use of those aircraft. Between 24 and 28 August 1989 the level of traffic carried from Alice Springs to Darwin and return was 4 per cent of its normal level. The level of traffic on the Melbourne-Alice Springs-Darwin route was 8.5 per cent of its normal level. Under normal traffic operations one would expect 2,857 passengers to be carried on the return route from Darwin to Alice Springs, but in the period mentioned the figure was 114.

Is it any wonder, therefore, that the airport shuttle service has closed down and all those employed on the shuttle service have been either laid off or made to go on leave? Is it any wonder that in the very near future the social security system in Alice Springs can expect an influx of 300 people upwards, seeking to gain social security benefits? Is it any wonder that car rental companies are complaining about an 80 per cent reduction in their turnover? Is it any wonder that tourism companies are experiencing a 100 per cent reduction in some cases in the level of work they are getting? Is it any wonder that places of accommodation in the Alice Springs region are suffering occupancy rates 40 to 50 per cent lower than they could normally expect at this time of the year? Is it any wonder that small operators in the Alice Springs region are extremely concerned that overseas visitors, who constitute 75 per cent of their bookings in the summer months and who should be booking now, are reluctant to do so? In fact, they have few forward bookings. So, even if the dispute ended tomorrow the results would carry over into the central Australian economy for some time to come. Is it a reasonable expectation of the residents of central Australia who are suffering from this exercise for the pilots to say, `Hey, what are we doing to the Australian community? What is the potential damage we can wreak upon the Australian economy and the airline companies which we used to work for?'. I would have thought that it is reasonable for them to do that, but apparently and unfortunately it seems that some of our friends on the Opposition benches do not.

I share the concern of the honourable member for Wide Bay that we should have expectations, but those expectations ought to be restricted, in this instance, by our capacity to provide. We know that in the industrial relations system in this country we have a delicate balance. It cannot and never will be able to afford increases of the type pursued by the airline pilots. I was involved in the trade union movement for many years and I would never condone scabbing on another trade unionist. However, the pilots have opted out of the system. They have resigned from their jobs. They took that foolish step and they do not have my sympathy. Their so-called leaders ought to reconsider their actions and attempt, as far as is possible, to negotiate a reasonable deal with the Australian airline companies which takes account of productivity increases-not the absurd and unreasonable expectation which they have placed upon the Australian community of a 30 per cent increase in their wage levels.

I share with the honourable member for Wide Bay a concern for the way in which the people of Australia perceive their entitlements. However, it is appropriate for people to have expectations. It is appropriate for people to expect governments to provide. It is appropriate for people to expect employers to provide a reasonable living wage. It is appropriate for people to expect that over a period their wages will increase as productivity increases or in some cases the cost of living increases. That is appropriate. But it is not appropriate for the airline pilots of this country to hold this nation to ransom.

It is about time that our friends in the Opposition, including my good friend the shadow Treasurer, took their Party to account and said, `Let's unite with the Government on this issue! We cannot afford to have a protracted industrial dispute of this nature. We cannot afford to continue the sniping attack upon the way in which the Government is handling this issue for the benefit of some cheap political stunt'. The stakes are too high, and I would have thought that would be apparent to everyone, especially those on the Opposition benches who purport to represent the business community, because ultimately the people who will suffer most from this exercise, apart from the wage and salary earners dependent upon business, will be the business proprietors themselves. That is the case in central Australia. It is not unlikely, as has already been said by the Minister responsible for tourism, that we will see a number of bankruptcies in the tourism industry. It is foreseeable that a large number of people will be put out of work for a long time by these pilots. But they do not seem to have any qualms about it, and that is of concern to me.

If any of the pilots are listening to the broadcast of this debate, I now plead with them to go back to the negotiating table and to accept something which is reasonable, and to accept that what they are imposing on the Australian community is unacceptable. The Australian community has an expectation that the pilots should be dealt with fairly, but that they should not themselves deal with the Australian population and the Australian economy unreasonably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to add to some of my comments on the Budget in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90. On Budget night my initial reaction to the Budget was in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: When you cut through the veneer of responsibility painted by the Treasurer in this year's Budget Speech there is an overwhelming disappointment at the extent to which the Budget fails to address our fundamental economic problems.

It fails to develop an anti-inflationary strategy, it fails to stimulate national savings; it fails to have an effective strategy for reducing our total debt; it fails to develop an effective strategy for increasing our productivity and exports; it threatens a recession and it has no answer to the current wages break-out.

Indeed, the great irony is that history will judge this Budget by the extent of its economic irresponsibility. Just when it was essential to convince our foreign creditors that we could come up with a plan of action the Treasurer failed.

That is what I said on Budget night, and here we are, 16 days after that Budget was brought down, and that document is dead in the water. Everything the Treasurer said on Budget night is now totally irrelevant. That Budget strategy has nothing to do with the economic realities of this country.

It is not just the Opposition that is saying that; it is a number of other leading groups and institutions, not only in this country but around the world. The Reserve Bank of Australia itself has canned the Government's economic strategy. The Reserve Bank went out of its way-in a very uncharacteristic way-in its recent annual report to draw attention to the fact and to emphasise that there are risks that the present stance of policy may not lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit. It went on to warn that these risks will be greater in certain circumstances, including, for example, where there is a substantial slowing in world growth or where there is a decline in commodity prices or some other sort of shock to this system. One of the major shocks is under way at present: the collapse of the Government's accord and wages policy.

The second group to come out since the Budget and attack it, quite directly and quite explicitly, is Moody's Investors Service, which has downgraded our credit rating for the second time in three years-now to AA2, it having been AAA just three years ago. Moody's went out of its way to emphasise a number of factors in our very poor economic performance since it downgraded us last time, in September 1986. It emphasised in particular that in our relative performance with countries that were similarly listed as AA1 at that time-particularly in terms of our debt and our debt service ratio-we have fallen out of line; we have deteriorated in relative performance terms. Moody's said that it anticipates that our relative external debt position will probably worsen before it stabilises in the mid-1990s. It went on to list a number of factors of particular concern, and then, most importantly, it commented on the fact that the Government's `total policy mix' is insufficiently rigorous to balance the external accounts. Moody's questions whether the total policy mix is sufficiently rigorous to balance the external accounts. Its view, by implication, is that it is not. Then quite explicitly, it says in relation to this Budget:
. . . the Budget fails to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity.

So in the space of just 16 days the Budget's strategy has been canned by the leading economic organisation in this country, the Reserve Bank, and by a major international credit rating agency, Moody's. I was fascinated to notice the attacks on Moody's, in anticipation of this downgrading, by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and subsequently by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer on the occasion of the downgrading, calling Moody's incompetent, calling it unprofessional. Government Ministers did not worry about that; they did not take that view back in September of last year prior to the Victorian election, when the Acting Treasurer on that occasion praised Moody's and sought to quote it as an authoritative source which had given a reasonable credit rating at the time to the State of Victoria. Who knows why, but it did. So it is a double standard in relation to an organisation like Moody's.

But the key thing is the current pilots dispute. It is the collapse of the accord. It is the collapse of the Government's wages policy. We have seen an attempt in the course of this week by the Prime Minister to say, `This is your industrial relations system that is on trial. Let's all sit back and look at it'. As is characteristic of this Prime Minister when he is in trouble, he reveals an acute sensitivity. He always lets people know what worries him. He always lets people know where he is exposed. He always lets them know what problems he has. And his problem is that it is his wages policy that is on trial, not ours. The break-out has occurred under his wages policy-and it is not the only pressure on that wages policy. The Australian Council of Trade Unions itself has not yet accepted the recent decision of the Industrial Relations Commission, as an example.

Most tellingly, on Budget night, Simon Crean came out immediately the Treasurer had finished talking, saying that he was disappointed that the Budget did not have an anti-inflationary strategy. Simon is now admitting the pressure that is on him from the rank and file of the union movement, recognising that they were duped in this current wage deal. They were conned into agreeing to a deal to hold earnings growth to 6 1/2 per cent at a time when this Treasurer was forecasting that the inflation rate would fall to 4 1/2 per cent by the middle of this calendar year and 3 to 4 per cent by the middle of next year. They thought they had locked themselves into a good deal. He comes in in the Budget this time and he admits that inflation is stuck at about 7 1/2 per cent at best and that it is not going to improve much over the course of the next several years. Of course, Simon immediately comes out and says, `Well, how am I ever going to hold these guys together?' They have been done in the eye. They have accepted a deal that they know is unsustainable. The Budget puts down earnings growth numbers as 6 1/2 per cent to 7 per cent. They are already running well ahead of that and by the time this process has run its course, we will see what this accord, this special relationship the Government is supposed to have with the union movement, has really cost this country.

It is an enormous cost. We are seeing it now in terms of the impact of the pilots dispute on industry, most directly the tourism industry. Tourism accounts, I think, for nearly 500,000 jobs in this country; about $22 billion of gross expenditure; about six per cent of gross domestic product-and that it is all at risk under this Government. The truth is that the Government's Budget left this country precariously exposed to a lot of risks, as the Reserve Bank said. One of the big risks is its own wages policy coming unstuck. As we teeter on the brink of a recession this more than anything else will probably tip us over the edge.

The Government's own figuring in the Budget suggested that a recession is a possibility. The growth numbers given in the Budget, the statements made about the outturn of growth and about employment and unemployment in the course of this year clearly are consistent with the possibility of a recession in the second half of this year, with rising unemployment as a consequence of that dive in domestic economic activity. We are left on the edge of a recession. A pilots dispute or some other form of wage pressure comes along, tips the economy over the edge and drives it down. That is precisely what will happen in the course of the next 12 months unless this Government acts.

If we think back to the so-called special relationship the Government is supposed to have with the union movement and this wonderful document called the accord, we should not forget some of the detail of that document. When this Government came into office in 1983 the accord was the magic that it brought with it. It was the thing that was going to stop it having to fight inflation first. The accord was going to bring wage restraint and control of inflation so that the Government could go out and run a very stimulatory fiscal and monetary policy on the back of this decisive little document.

Within two years of that policy being adopted, in early 1985, the country had a massive exchange rate and balance of payments crisis because the whole strategy, the accord, blew the economy right out of the water. It has taken us the best part of the past three or four years to recover from the shock and disgrace of that experience. Yet here we are, again in this Budget, in a similar situation, with the threat of major economic crisis in this country in the course of the next few months because the Government has failed to deal with the problem and left us totally exposed.

Let us think about the accord. Really what is it? It is a device by which the Government has elevated the Australian Council of Trade Unions-and, in particular, a couple of members of the ACTU-to Cabinet status. The Government has made the ACTU a branch of government. It has put Simon Crean and Bill Kelty in the team as effective Cabinet Ministers with veto power over a host of major economic decisions-fiscal policy and social policy decisions and decisions in the fields of education, welfare spending, training and so on. Simon Crean and Bill Kelty have an effective veto power over all that. We hear them comment on a wide range of all aspects of government policy.

The deal that has been done is, firstly, to elevate the ACTU to a position as a branch of government, as I say, with two Cabinet posts to go along with it. Secondly, it is essentially a deal to run the economy in an unsustainable way. It is a sell-out to that power of the union movement to run the economy at rates that are unsustainable, to create the environment in which unions can derive benefits and there can be rapid increases in jobs. But those rates are unsustainable. It is a sell-out of economic management in those terms. In only one year in the life of this Government have we had a situation where spending has not outstripped production. That was in 1985, the year of the exchange rate crisis that I mentioned before.

The accord is supposed to have lowered industrial disputation in this country. Where is the evidence? Industrial disputes and their costs are at record levels. Thirdly, the accord has locked us into a rate of inflation that is now stuck at about 7 or 8 per cent because it goes on doing deals. The Prime Minister said the other day, `Don't talk of deals'. It is a deal. The whole thing is a deal. The Government has locked this country into a rate of inflation that is double that of its trading partners. It is giving wage increases across the board that are unrelated to productivity and double the rate of those paid on the average by our trading partners. Therefore our inflation is locked in at rates of 7 or 8 per cent from now into the foreseeable future as a result of that deal. Some deal! Tremendous!

In that sense, the accord fails to address the issue of competitiveness which is fundamental to our getting out of our current economic difficulties. But, perhaps most importantly, the accord effectively represents the surrender terms of overall economic management in this country. All the key decisions that need to be taken cannot be taken because of the veto power that has effectively been given to the ACTU, sometimes with the duplicity and support of members of the parliamentary left wing of the Australian Labor Party.

The key issue at the present time concerns our need to increase our rate of production, to increase our productivity, to increase our exports-to trade our way out of our economic difficulties. Yet in every key area in which a decision needs to be taken the ACTU effectively blocks that decision. Think about the issues of privatisation of government enterprises; of cutting government expenditure; of reforming the tax system; of cleaning up the waterfront; of injecting competition into coastal shipping and road, rail and air transport. None of those decisions are being taken because of the effective veto power of the ACTU.

The special relationship that the Government is supposed to have with the union movement is summarised in this document-this moveable feast, I should say; the goal posts have been moved so many times one loses track of what it actually stands for-but we know by its result what it stands for. It will bring this country to its knees for the second time in the life of this Government. The first time was in 1985-86 and it is about to bring this country to its knees again. The Budget is sitting there. It is totally irrelevant and has no answer to the emerging industrial relations and wage system crisis that exists at the present time. The Treasurer has boasted many times in this Parliament. He has attacked us and belittled us with the argument that, `If you can't run wages in this country, then you can't run the country'. He will be damned out of his own mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), I wonder exactly what he is on about. I am not quite sure whether he was here to talk about the Australian economy or simply to give a recitation of the concealed economic policies of the Opposition, which the Australian people have been seeking to obtain for some months. For the whole of this sitting week in this Parliament there has not been one question asked by the shadow Treasurer of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on issues that one would have expected a shadow Treasurer to canvass. There has not been one question about the assessment by Moody's Investors Service Inc. of the economic performance of this country or any of the major issues which the Treasurer has addressed. There has not been one question on any of the Budget papers or the appropriations by this Government to ensure the continued stability and growth of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: After listening to some of the speeches by Opposition members and after listening to the Treasurer and studying the Treasurer's documents, I am convinced that the Australian people are well satisfied that this Government, through its Budget, is putting the well-being of the Australian people first. This Budget proclaims a sense of national purpose. It is a sensible and prudent Budget, combining social justice and economic responsibility. It is testimony to the unflinching resolve of the Hawke Government in its crucial mission of good government for all Australian people.

Whenever I have the opportunity to comment on the many economic achievements and triumphs of the Hawke Government, I am compelled to recall the economic record of the Liberal and National parties in government. Who can ever forget those disastrous seven years of economic stagnation, negative economic growth, high interest rates, double digit inflation, high unemployment, high deficits and, above all, a resigned hopelessness among the Australian people who believed that the Liberal and National parties were dragging them down to the level of a third world country?

Wherever I go in my electorate my constituents share with me these sombre recollections. They spontaneously vow that never again do they want that bunch on the other side of the House to have the opportunity of wrecking their personal savings, destroying the job opportunities of their children, and squandering Australia's reputation for economic rectitude. They do not want to relive the Fraser Government years. When I look across this chamber I see many Liberal and National Party members who were part of the Fraser Government years. Since the defeat of the Fraser Government they have said nothing in this House that would lead even their closest supporters to believe that anything would be different were they to regain power. The Liberal and National parties have learnt nothing; they have forgotten nothing. When challenged to reveal to the Australian people their economic policies for the 1990s they retreat; they seek to confuse; they avoid close examination of their policies.

There is no substitute for honest, credible, clean Labor government. Cynical and deceptive government-the dark side of politics-is what we see in Queensland. It should have no place in the administration of this nation's affairs. The fact is that the Liberal and National parties are masters of making and breaking promises. Tax cuts were never part of their economic repertoire while they were in government. Families, particularly those on fixed incomes, bore the burden of their economic mismanagement, while tax avoidance, cheating and a collapse in public morality flourished under their neglect. To discover the face of Liberalism under this Opposition one need look only to the face of Liberalism under the Fraser Government. Those were the years of division and despondency; those were the years of social inequality, social strife, industrial confrontation, tax cheating and pervading unfairness. The Hawke Government has turned around the prospective $9.6 billion deficit that this Government inherited and has created two successive Budget surpluses. The consensus and cooperation of the Hawke Government has revitalised Australia's economic health, restored Australia's reputation overseas and, above all, awakened the Australian people to pride in themselves and their country and the opportunities for greatness which this nation has to offer.

In my speech on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 I would like to refer to one item in the Budget which is of fundamental importance to this nation. I firmly believe that the primary responsibility of any Australian Government is to provide the nation with the armed force capability to defeat an armed attack and also to ensure the nation's capacity to live in peace, to have freedom and independence and not to be constrained by the threat of attack. I said it was a primary responsibility of government to provide for the adequate defence of the nation. In my view, this responsibility takes precedence over any other responsibility of government. The Hawke Government is seeking to maintain and develop capabilities for the independent defence of Australia and its interests. It has sought to promote strategic stability and security in our region. As a member of the ANZUS alliance, Australia continues to fulfil its role as a loyal and responsible member of the Western strategic community. In this regard, this nation owes a debt of gratitude to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley).

This year defence outlays will increase by 6.5 per cent to more than $8.3 billion, or about 9.6 per cent of Government Budget outlays. Key priorities in this expenditure include the ongoing commitment to improved conditions for service personnel and their families and the continuation of the major re-equipment program of the Australian Defence Force. The provision of good standard accommodation for married and single personnel retains priority. Capital facilities such as the continued expansion of the Defence Force presence in Townsville and the increased role of HMAS Stirling benefit from major spending in this Budget.

The Budget also includes provision for continuing payments against major re-equipment projects. For example, it provides $488m for the construction of six submarines, with the first submarine due to be delivered in 1995. It provides $213m for the purchase of 75 FA18 aircraft and associated equipment. Sixty-two aircraft have been delivered and the remaining 13 aircraft are planned to be delivered this year. It provides $153m for the construction of two guided missile frigates at Williamstown in Victoria. It provides $198m for the acquisition of 16 Seahawk helicopters for the operation of FFG frigates. It provides $55m for the development and production of radios for manpack and vehicle mounted and ground station capability. In 1988-89, this project progressed towards the achievement of a build standard of high frequency radio acceptable to the Australian Defence Force and particularly to the personnel of the operational deployment force based at Townsville. In 1989-90, it is planned to commence the introduction of high frequency radios to Australian Army units. At the same time, production of high frequency and very high frequency radios will continue.

The Budget also provides $51m for the purchase of 39 Black Hawk helicopters. Thirteen aircraft had been delivered to the end of 1988-89 and a further 13 are planned for delivery in 1989-90. These aircraft are in full operational service with 5 Aviation Regiment stationed in Townsville. It provides $43m for replacing the Army's land rovers and land cruisers with 2,900 new light field vehicles. It provides $25m for the development and upgrading of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. In 1989-90, tenders will be evaluated and a contract awarded for the construction of the first major radar elements of the Jindalee operational radar network in 1990. This will be built in the electorate of my good colleague the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). The Budget provides $25m to upgrade the avionics of the F111C and its reconnaissance version by replacement of analog avionics with digital avionics and modernised existing radars. This is a long overdue project.

One decision, however, has caused concern and anxiety. This is the decision to disband the Chinook helicopter squadron with effect from 25 August 1989. The 1987 Defence White Paper called for highly mobile ground forces. Exercise Kangaroo 89 vitally demonstrated this requirement. The Chinook helicopter is a twin rotor helicopter operated by the Royal Australian Air Force. It is a twin engine helicopter capable of lifting up to 22,000 pounds within a 100 kilometre radius-that is, loaded out and unloaded return-and with lesser weights up to a 250 kilometre radius. While the `D' model-a remanufactured and modernised version of the `C' model which is owned by Australia-in the long range version carries 13,000 pounds, or 6,000 kilograms, to a radius of 460 kilometres, its ferry capability on internal fuel tanks carries about 1,000 nautical miles and much more with external fuel tanks. The Chinook can carry 44 troops seated and in an emergency as many as 80, as happened in the Falklands war. It is an ideal and rapid troop mover and it can carry internal and slung loads.

The Black Hawk helicopter, one of the best helicopters in the world, has one-third of the lift capability of a Chinook. For planning purposes it has a radius of action of 160 kilometres at 120 knots cruise, with a load of 10 fully equipped troops and their accoutrements in the troop movement mode, or a load of up to 6,000 pounds in the resupply mode-that is, food, water, ammunition, lubricants, or even a 105 Hamel gun. The Black Hawk helicopter consumes 1,100 pounds of fuel per hour. It has a fuel capacity of 2,500 pounds and therefore uses nearly one tonne of fuel for a mission.

There are enough Black Hawks to move an infantry company in one lift. But the primary task of the Black Hawk helicopter is to move troops, supplies and guns in the combat zone within a radius of 160 kilometres of a supply point. From this point it draws its own fuel supply and supplies ammunition for the troops and fuel for light observation helicopters operating in the region and for vehicles in the combat area. Movement further afield requires the setting up of a forward supply point, and Black Hawks alone cannot do this job. The task of refuelling the Black Hawks themselves, as well as supplying their customers, or their users, requires the lift capability of the Chinooks and that thereby enables operations to proceed based on a forward supply point up to 250 kilometres from the initial one.

This is the sort of situation which could easily obtain in a northern Australian setting, particularly in a wet and hostile terrain. If the Army were to try to do this without Chinooks I believe we could quickly reach the situation where the Black Hawks spend much of their effort in refuelling themselves, because it takes 12 Black Hawks to refuel themselves along with the other eight, making up to 20 on-line Black Hawks if the radius of action is doubled out. Two Chinooks can refuel 20 Black Hawks.

What the Chinook can do that other military helicopters cannot do is this: it can recover a downed Black Hawk; fundamentally important, it can lift engineer bulldozers of D4 standard; it can lift all terrain forklifts; and it can lift heavier containerised communications equipment. It is the only helicopter in Australia that can lift the 155 millimetre medium gun. It can lift an M113 armoured personnel carrier, and it can quickly lift ship to shore tonnage and large numbers of troops. Three Chinooks can carry an infantry company; one Chinook can deploy 44 troops 250 kilometres; and four Chinooks can deploy 880 troops over 75 kilometres in three hours. In exercise Kangaroo 89, it would have taken 40 hours to deploy a battalion from Kununurra to Kalumburu, on the coast, using Black Hawks, as opposed to 13 hours with Chinooks-so the Black Hawks take three times as long over a distance of 260 kilometres.

There are nearly $87m worth of Chinook spares in Australia and I understand that more spares have arrived recently. Included in the holding are 33 uprated engines or kits for the D models that Australia should have, and a number of fibreglass blades for the D models. Indeed, 20 per cent of the C spares fit the D model. To be highly mobile, that is air mobile, and to be able to operate over the large distances of Australia and its territories, the range and lift capabilities of the Chinook are a necessity. Otherwise movement is slowed; reaction times extended; and more troops and supporting resources are required to do the same job. If these are not made available-and they are costly-then capability is significantly reduced. If helicopter supported operations are to take place more than 160 kilometres from a supply point, Chinooks are needed to ensure full support. If these Chinooks are disposed of, more Black Hawks will be needed in lieu, accepting that heavy loads beyond Black Hawk capability are denied in the battle area.

The proposal to retain six Chinooks to convert them to D models, which was advocated to the Government by the Army, and to sell the rest is not an answer. The Army needs 11 Chinooks. It needs eight operational Chinooks and three for crew training and for maintenance. The decision to dispose of the Chinook helicopters from operational duty in the Australian defence forces is, in my view, fundamentally wrong and it ought to be rescinded immediately. The 1987 Defence White Paper stressed and declared that Australia must have an effective air mobile capability-and I stress effective air mobile capability-in the combat area if it is to move its ground forces effectively. Australia's 11 Chinooks must be retained and refurbished.

I now refer to Australia's program of assistance in the development of the capabilities of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force. This year, in this Budget, the defence cooperation appropriation has increased by more than 47 per cent. In my view the task of developing the capabilities of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force should be an urgent priority of this Government. I urge the Government to provide increased opportunity for individual and group training of Papua New Guinea Defence Force personnel both in Australia and in Papua New Guinea.

I am not satisfied, on the information available to me, that the Papua New Guinea Defence Force does have a fully trained and fully professional defence force capable of serving the nation to its best capacity. While I acknowledge that there is an urgent need for major and minor equipment development in the Papua New Guinea Defence Force, the fundamental priority must be the maintenance of a professional, disciplined and highly skilled Papua New Guinea Defence Force. Otherwise the day may very well come when Australian troops may be required to serve those tasks that should be performed by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force.

I am pleased to note from the Budget Papers that there has been a substantial increase in the defence cooperation appropriation for certain South Pacific countries. This is an area of strategic interest for Australia which can no longer be treated simply as a recipient of Australian aid. Australia is and must continue to be a primary source of defence assistance and a respected partner with South Pacific nations in regional security issues.

The time limited to me in this debate is coming to a close, but I simply repeat the issues that I have stressed to the Parliament in my speech: this Budget presented by the Treasurer serves Australia's national purpose and no amount of carping, or the unbridled, ill-founded criticism levelled at it, can take away one iota from the fact that it will serve the Australian people and regain their economic confidence. It will ensure that the Hawke Government's continuing efforts to achieve economic reconstruction will place Australia on a sound, first class footing for economic success in the 1990s and the years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget this year was delivered in sombre tones by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and well it might have been because it was a very sad and inadequate document. It was in fact a classic wasted opportunity. This year's Budget failed on just about every count. It failed to address the problems of the Australian economy in the same way as the Treasurer failed to address our economic problems in his six previous Budgets. Labor is still, after six years in power, the highest taxing, highest spending government in the history of this country. This Government, under Treasurer Keating, is locked into policies that have resulted in high interest rates, high overseas debt-rising daily-high inflation and the highest current account deficit on record, and there is simply no relief in sight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, promised us more of the same. He referred to a continuation of high interest rate policies and predicted high inflation. But he did not highlight one statistic, and that is the statistic that in fact predicts rising unemployment. He knows it, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) knows it, and they know the consequences of it for the Australian community. Unfortunately this year's Budget locks us further into the path towards a banana republic. We are going down the Argentinean road, as predicted by the Treasurer, and he has no answers to the problem.

Since the Budget was delivered in this place there have been a number of significant developments. The latest was our foreign debt figures, issued just a few days ago, and they confirm our worst fears. Australia's gross foreign debt is now $135 billion. Our net foreign debt is $108 billion. These figures have risen from a net foreign debt of just $23 billion when this Hawke Labor Government first came to power, and it is one of the most shocking legacies that the Prime Minister and his cronies will be leaving the Australian people when they lose office at the next election. Foreign debt is now 32 per cent of our gross domestic product. It was 13.8 per cent under the previous coalition Government. This Budget will do nothing to improve our foreign debt position. In fact, it will be worsened and that worsening has been acknowledged by the Treasurer in his forecasting of a current account deficit of $18.5 billion for the coming year. That is his estimate, and with the current pilots strike that is likely to blow out considerably further. I will be having something to say about that later.

The second event that has occurred has been the further downgrading by Moody's Investors Service of our international credit rating on 29 August. That was not a novel event, nor a new event, and let me say it was not unexpected. This Government has an appalling, unique record. One hears Government members chant the rhetoric that they have been fed at Caucus meetings, but they do not chant the Government's record in some areas. In September 1986 Moody's Investors Service downgraded Australia's credit rating from AAA to AA1. In December 1986 Standard and Poor's Corporation downgraded our rating from AAA to AA+, and in August this year we went from AA1 to AA2. We can only speculate how long it will be before we move to AA3 under this Government. Unless the Treasurer recognises that his Budget settings are totally inappropriate for our circumstances, that is an inevitable event.

The Treasurer does not have a very good record on Budgets. Everyone remembers last year's discredited `bring home the bacon' Budget. Let us spend some time examining the Treasurer's five previous Budgets. His first Budget, for 1983-84, was supposed to achieve the joint objectives of fighting inflation and unemployment simultaneously. We all know what happened to inflation. We know where we stand in comparison to our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development partners. In the 1984-85 Budget we were promised `an historic opportunity to embark upon a new growth path' which would `consolidate and strengthen the economic recovery'. Five years later, our economy is sicker than ever. The only thing that has been consolidated is our status as a Third World nation.

In the 1985-86 Budget we were told about the economic trilogy. Do you remember the trilogy, Mr Deputy Speaker? There was a commitment that there would be no new increased sales taxes or excises and no increases in income tax rates. We were told that the Government would not increase the percentage of tax revenue above the 1984-85 share of tax in the total economy. If that was the Government's intention, why in 1985-86, did total Commonwealth tax revenue increase by 11 per cent over the 1984-85 figure? Why, in 1985-86, did total individual tax revenue increase by 11.7 per cent over the previous year? Why was the total level of taxation as a percentage of our gross domestic product in 1985-86 basically the same as it was in 1984-85? And it has been higher ever since.

In the 1986-87 Budget we were told that all of our mounting economic problems had been caused by `the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices since late last year'. It was all the fault of overseas factors. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister said, `Don't blame us; it is the fault of people overseas'. They said that it had nothing to do with failed domestic economic policies. The 1987-88 Budget continued to hammer away at the problems being faced because of our international trading difficulties. According to the Treasurer at that time, all of that was under control. The current account deficit for the year would fall to about $11.5 billion and by the middle of 1988 inflation would be about 6 per cent. He failed in that regard. We know exactly what happened with those forecasts. The current account deficit for 1987-88 was $11.8 billion, and inflation for the year was 7.3 per cent. That was the beginning of the Treasurer's bodgie forecasts.
The 1988-89 Budget, of course, was the one which was supposed to `bring home the bacon'-and what lousy quality bacon it was! The Treasurer promised:
This year our balance of payments will be halved from its peak of just three years ago and our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.

The inaccuracy, ineptitude and, dare I say, falseness of the Treasurer's forecasts were really brought home in last year's Budget. The inflation forecast of 4.5 per cent was nothing short of laughable. The actual figure was 7.7 per cent. The current account deficit forecast of $9.5 billion was actually $17.7 billion-only to be exceeded by his forecast for this year of $18.5 billion. Foreign debt, far from stabilising or falling, has reached a new record of $108 billion. Any self-respecting accountant who was that far out in his Budget forecasts would resign, and the Treasurer should do so. Our Treasurer has the hide of an African elephant. He is bouncing back from those rubbery figures. He tells us in the 1989-90 Budget that last year inflation was too high and that the balance of payments did not fall as expected. Let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that every pensioner in this country, everybody on a fixed income, everybody suffering under this Government's wages policy, knows that inflation was too high. When that inflation impact is compounded by this Government's tax policies, we know exactly what the impact on living standards is.

This Treasurer really does not know where he is going. He has highlighted Australia's problems in the Budgets that he has brought down, but he has not been able to address them. In fact, his record has been based on a continued and consistent approach of higher taxation to veneer over his failure to address the structural problems of this economy. When it comes to tax, the Treasurer's record is nothing short of appalling. When we look at the detailed forecasts for this year we see exactly how much more the Australian community will be paying to Consolidated Revenue under the Treasurer's continuing tax policies.

Since coming to power almost seven years ago this Government has increased total Commonwealth tax revenue by nearly 106 per cent. That is an appalling achievement. It has increased total individual tax revenue by nearly 108 per cent over the same period. Company tax revenue has increased by nearly 163 per cent; prescribed payments revenue has increased by a massive 537 per cent; petrol excise revenue has increased by 186 per cent; and, at the same time, road funding has fallen by 30 per cent in real terms. Customs import revenue has increased by 74 per cent and the revenue from the Medicare levy has increased by 612 per cent over the past six years. Revenue from the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes for each year since they were implemented has increased by 105 per cent and 432 per cent respectively, and revenue from the debits tax has increased by 113 per cent. In short, year after year this Government has increased its revenue from taxation virtually across the board. It is the Australian public that is paying; it is the Australian wage and salary earner who is feeling the impact of these rising taxes. The Treasurer, far from being the world's greatest Treasurer, is in fact Australia's highest taxing Treasurer.

This year everybody will be hurt by the Keating economic prescription, but people who live in regional and rural Australia will be savaged more than most. Let us look at the details of what this Budget offers rural and regional people: absolutely nothing. Rural and regional Australia has not just been ignored; it will go further backwards. As I have said, road funding has fallen by 30 per cent since Labor came to power. This Budget does nothing to rectify the appalling road conditions in country Australia. Our tourist roads continue to fall to pieces. Recently I drove from Mackay to Townsville on what we describe as Highway 1.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a great electorate.

—It is the major tourist road running through north Queensland in the electorate of Dawson. That road is nothing short of a disgrace. It is irresponsible of us to encourage overseas tourists to travel on that road. Our export roads are in a similar condition. There may be just one silver lining in this appalling pilots strike that we have at present as a result of the belligerent and aggressive attitude of the Prime Minister and the inadequacies of the wages and incomes policy of this Government; that is, it may be that enough people are forced to travel on our roads so that pressure is applied on the Government and the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) to increase the allocation of road funding in the next Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in addition to not doing anything about roads, has again cut local government funding and, worse still, has slashed it by more than the amount projected in the April statement. In reality, this means that rates in rural and regional Australia will have to increase-and that will be another charge on individuals and businesses in the community-or the standard of services will have to be cut. That will compound the declining standard of living. On top of that, there is the amazing situation and short term approach by the Government, whereby the Commonwealth has opted out of drought funding to the tune of $17m this year, with a further projected cut in excess of $20m for next year. What is more, it has removed drought aid from the natural disaster relief arrangements. Drought requirements for 1989-90 will be funded through the rural adjustment scheme. That shows a complete lack of understanding of the significance of drought to our rural economy and, I would suggest, is a very short term approach to the real needs of an industry which is vital if we are to address the massive current account deficit that the Treasurer is forecasting.

While it might be fair to say that a drought in the current circumstances seems unlikely, it is not the sort of thing that we can afford to ignore or be unprepared for. Droughts are unpredictable, their consequences are severe, and to not have in place a policy prescription to deal with them is nothing short of irresponsible. The airport local ownership plan, which is so important to the development of regional Australia, has also been abolished.

Under this Government's policies there has been a continuation of the shocking treatment of pharmacists throughout Australia. If one lives cosily and comfortably in Canberra, as many of the Ministers do, or in the capital cities of this country, then perhaps one does not understand the significance of pharmacists to the community. They are a major contribution to the standard of health care throughout rural and regional Australia. When a doctor is not available-and there is a scarcity of doctors throughout the Australian community, which will be exacerbated by the proposals of the Government for a vocational register-people resort to a chemist for help. Under the proposals of this Government there will be less opportunity because there will be fewer chemists. Those chemists who do survive will not be able to open the hours that are needed.

In some communities-this may not be apparent to many on the Government side-when doctors are not available people seek the advice of chemists. I spoke to someone in my own electorate the other day whose daughter was running a temperature of 103 degrees. There was no doctor available and there was no chemist available because they were closed. Under the Government's proposals the hours of chemists will be cut back even further. That is the standard of care, compassion and recognition of the realities of life in Australia that exists within this Government at present.

The Government's high interest rate policy and high inflation policies are severely affecting the farming community. The inflationary impact of freight charges is particularly savage. Of course, the Australian Labor Party has no interest in taking into account the impact of these policies on rural communities.

In the few moments remaining to me, I would like to comment on the Moody's downgrading of our credit rating and refer in some detail to the justification that it expressed in its latest assessment of the economy. As the Treasurer would have us believe, Moody's is not some obscure group overseas that has no credibility. Moody's is a well-respected international rating agency that is regarded very seriously by the international financial community. High gradings by Moody's are sought after and valued by its customers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not infallible.

—Moody's is not infallible, but it has got it right three times. It keeps moving our credit rating down in line with the decline in the Australian economy. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) knows that the capacity of the Australian economy to cope with the changing international economy is being reduced day by day and week by week. He knows that his Government's policies have failed abysmally. In fact, one of his colleagues has said, `Yes, our policies for adjustment in industry have failed to encourage export growth and I don't know what to do'. He threw his hands up in the air and said that he did not know what to do.
—Who said that?

—Senator Button said it for the entire Australian community on television and the Minister who is at the table knows that. He knows that he has failed to achieve any implementation of the policies. He understands rightly that the Government has not grasped the dire need for Australia's economy to become modern and to come to grips with the new technology. Let me just quote exactly why Moody's downgraded our credit rating. The factors that Moody's considers crucial to its lowered rating include the following: firstly, the Government's in- ability to control excessive demand growth. The Treasurer has spoken to us about that, but he has not put it in the terms that the objective assessors of Moody's have done-inability to control, failure to act. Unpreparedness to change its policy prescriptions, is another way that it could be described.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that Moody's makes-I think it is made in a very gentle way-is that there has been insufficient progress in generating additional export earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains. That is what Senator Button said-the policies have failed. When the Minister responsible acknowledges that his policies have failed, he cannot condemn a rating agency for coming to the same conclusion. The third point that Moody's makes-this is the most crucial point and it is the greatest condemnation of this Government's total and abject failure-is that continued slow pace of structural adjustment has continued, which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in foreign currency debt. Heaven only knows how much higher our debt has to go before this Government will recognise the inappropriateness of its policies.

Earlier, I spoke of the size of our foreign debt and its growth over the past six years, but here we have Moody's predicting a further growth. The reality is that this Government has policy paralysis. It cannot take the decisions that need to be taken because it is captive of the Labor movement in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is operating to a political agenda and is not aware, nor does it care, about the consequences of its policies or their inaction on the Australian community. Under Treasurer Keating and Prime Minister Hawke we will continue our decline towards banana republic status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not uncommon to hear about cynicism in the electorate-I think everyone knows what I am talking about-lack of confidence in the political process, disillusion engendered perhaps by disappointed expectations, and a general view that politicians are self-serving and governments are ineffective in making a better society for the people they are elected to serve. It is not uncommon to hear about that. It is no wonder, with the sorts of things that the Opposition comes out with, that that sort of cynicism is engendered. I will interrupt myself here to make the point that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) actually talked about having more tax revenue, completely ignoring the fact that we have more tax revenue because we have had more growth, more jobs, more people paying tax, and more investment. He completely ignores and completely fails to tell the Australian public that growth has doubled in the five years under the Australian Labor Party but that it has lowered personal taxes. The sort of thing that engenders the cynicism in the electorate is the absolute failure to acknowledge government achievements. I will stop talking for a moment about the extraordinary statements from the members of the Opposition masquerading as analysts of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: This cynicism is not unusual; it is not rare for it to happen, it happens all the time. To a certain extent it is inevitable and it is not a bad thing. Members of the public should be questioning and demanding things of us. They put us here to do things for them and we ought to be doing that. As I said a moment ago, it is also pretty important for the public to take time to assess and to analyse what is being achieved in relation to tax and to acknowledge that, while the media attention goes only to party political point scoring and perhaps the performance or the non-performance of individuals, the Government is actually getting on with the job and, in our case, working towards the social justice goals that we have set ourselves.

What has been happening is pretty impressive. I am not sure how many people realise the extent of some of the reforms that have been taking place in recent years and are being implemented by this Budget. What is actually occurring in the area of social justice is far more substantial than the community has yet realised. When people analyse what is happening they will understand that our Government is about real reform. I will refer to a few areas where reform has taken place. How many people still do not realise that their children in years 11 and 12 can get Austudy which was not available to them before? There has been a revolutionary reform in the child support scheme-one can never go back to what was there before-which has totally revolutionised the appalling situation in relation to child maintenance that existed until now.

Honourable members should think about what has happened in the area of sole parents. Reforms have been occurring in Budget after Budget after all the analysis that our Government put into the plight of sole parents through the Social Security Review. In regard to the aged, there have been genuine and long lasting reforms as well as a whole policy for the future of the aged. What is happening with children? Members of the Opposition constantly remind us of what we have committed ourselves to do for the children of Australia. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in answer to a question yesterday, said:
The Brotherhood of St Laurence went on to acknowledge that for the first time in this country's history we have a system of guaranteed minimum income for children . . .

Five hundred thousand families and more than one million children are now benefiting from the Government's assistance-the sort of assistance that we have been gradually improving Budget after Budget. I make the point that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) made yesterday: the only thing we have heard from the Opposition is that it is prepared to slash $1 billion off the social security budget. Will it take it from the children or will it take from the aged?

What has been happening to the aged in the last few years? I will begin with what has happened in the Budget we are now addressing. Our commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings will actually be exceeded in April next year. On top of the normal indexation increase next April there will be an increase of $2 a week for single pensioners and $3.30 a week for married pensioners. That has been derided by the Opposition. I heard members of the Opposition call out, `Two dollars a week; so what!'. Putting $2 a week on the pension will cost $300m a year. All honourable members opposite have talked about is slashing $1 billion from the social security budget. Because of indexation, the biggest area of reform that has been carried through to so many other areas, that increase will be locked in, in real terms. In other words, we will not have a fight in every Budget debate about this increase; it is locked in.

Rent assistance will be increased substantially-a real reform for the majority of Australians living in rented accommodation, certainly in my electorate. The maximum rate of rent assistance will increase by an additional $10 a week and, from March 1991, it will be automatically indexed. Since June 1989 rent assistance will have increased by 100 per cent for those people without children and by September 1990 it will have increased by over 150 per cent for those people with children. That shows this Government's commitment to the people who need help most. As a matter of fact, at the moment over 320,000 age and service pensioners are receiving rent assistance. The majority of these pensioners have little income other than their pension. That is usually the case for people in rented accommodation. In most cases, rent accounts for over one-third of their income. So a 100 per cent or 150 per cent increase in rent assistance will make a substantial difference to those people. More importantly, our long-term retirement income policy is getting into place, and that will assist and encourage people especially to save for their retirement.

From July 1991, the indexation of the pension income test free area will make an enormous difference. That will remain tax free. There will be a simplification of tax arrangements for pensioners. From 1995 no age or service pensioner will pay income tax. As a co-convener of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes, I know that that and catching up on the consumer price index lag-which we did-are what most pensioners asked for. Of course, we have also improved access to and the adequacy of superannuation. Those ongoing improvements are part of our long-term retirement income policy.

I turn now to the youth social justice strategy in this Budget. Over the next four years there will be a $100m expansion of the Government's youth social justice strategy. That is not bad. I think someone ought to take some notice of that. An additional 6,000 homeless young people will have access to secure accommodation. Homeless children are a matter of concern for every Australian. We have now begun the process of helping them. There will be a $7.50 a week increase in the maximum rate of the young homeless allowance and related Austudy payments and more effective labour market assistance to help disadvantaged young people enter the work force. In the health area there are new initiatives in this Budget for disadvantaged young people in high risk areas, as well as other measures to help young people.

An ongoing area of concern for all working families is child-care. Low income families will now have greater access to child-care because the fee relief will be increased and indexed into the future. Again, indexation is locking in a reform that we have brought in. Of course, the Opposition will have a great debate about whether government should be involved at all in this area of child-care.

We have increased real funding for disability services and especially pilot projects which will establish what processes will best encourage those with disabilities into independence and employment. A new long-term Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy is about to be formulated which will provide full equity of access, participation and education outcomes for Aboriginal Australians. A number of new measures will help the older unemployed and there is an increase in the unemployment benefit for people aged 60 to 64. There will be expanded labour market assistance for long-term unemployed people aged 55 to 64. We have strengthened residential rights for the aged and people with disabilities in nursing homes and hostels.

All the things I have mentioned that have been brought in in this Budget are evidence of this Government's ongoing commitment to its social justice program. In fact, our achievements since 1983 have addressed all four major requirements that are needed if we are to call our society socially just or in any way working towards a form of social justice. As we have often said, these are: the need for a fair and equitable distribution of income; the protection and enhancement of an individual's rights; an assurance of fair and equitable access to essential community services; and the opportunity to participate in the decision making processes of our society.

As I have been saying during my short speech, there has been a significant redistribution of income towards low to moderate income earners, particularly those in the 50 to 75 per cent of average weekly earning bracket-an enormous achievement in that area. Those on age and service pensions have also been assisted greatly. The measures announced in this Budget build on these social justice achievements, particularly the major reforms to index the income support measures. Social justice is an ongoing process. This Government has created 1 1/2 million jobs since 1983 and it has brought in what I still regard as the greatest reform of any government-that is, Medicare. Our social justice program is an ongoing one and is well on track. I commend it to the House. Mr Speaker, I also take this opportunity to offer you my congratulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Phillip.
