SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take this opportunity to sincerely congratulate you on your progression from Mr Deputy Speaker to Mr Speaker. I hope that you display warmth towards this side of the House and tolerance that is a mark of a good Speaker.
—I always provide warmth and counselling for the honourable member for Moreton even in his most difficult times.

—Thank you very much indeed, Mr Speaker. I do not wish to spend more than passing moments on the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), but I say to the honourable member that when she lauds all these programs that her Party has introduced and says how they are meeting a social need, she should remember that a lot of the people who are now in need have been placed in need by her Party. Her philosophical direction is that the Government knows best. The Government, by its taxation levels and the like, has made a lot of previously independent people now dependent upon the Government. That is what it has done; so the honourable member should not come in here popping out her chest to tell us how marvellous the programs have been, because this country is in ruination. The entire world judges us in that light.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight's discussion is a continuation of the debate on the Budget Speech. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) told this place on 15 August that the people of Australia are looking for the meat rather than the feathers. Ha, ha! He also told us that this Budget will fulfil that national purpose. From that moment I started to wonder whether the Treasurer had properly addressed the economic issues which are causing Australians greatest concern. During the month of July I sent every household in my electorate of Moreton a Fair-Go survey asking them to rate a range of economic issues in order of concern to them. The results from the first 1,050 surveys returned to me have now been collated. The answer was loud and clear: the average Australian is very concerned about foreign debt, taxation levels, interest rates, inflation, and the standard of living.

Had these concerns been addressed by the Treasurer on 15 August? I sifted through the mass of the Budget Speech, the Budget Papers, the Budget statements and the special issue statements. What did I find? What would anyone find? I found gloss; I found hype; I found Keating-speak; I found self-adulation; I found the world's greatest `this and that'. But in terms of the economic issues concerning my constituents, and indeed the people of Australia, I found nothing. There were no solutions, no long term strategy, not even a realistic recognition of the significance of these problems. Respondents to my Fair-Go survey were asked whether they believed Australia was heading in the right direction. Seven per cent said yes; 93 per cent said no. In every age category, dissatisfaction with the way in which this country is heading was above 90 per cent.

Australians are traditionally optimistic, but the `she'll be right' attitude has disappeared under this Government. As Rome burns, the Treasurer has done enough `she'll be right' to last all of us for a good many years. However, he cannot continue to ignore this overwhelmingly gloomy assessment by the people who are this nation's future. Real, non-fiddled, inflation is so close to double digits it does not matter. Month after month, we have record current account deficits; foreign debt is through the roof and rising; mortgage interest rates are at record high peace time levels.

The nine issues which I asked Fair-Go respondents to rate in order of concern to them were: foreign debt, inflation, interest rates, health, lack of incentive, standard of living, retirement income, taxation and unemployment. Foreign debt received the most No. 1 responses, both overall and in every age category except the 18 years to 29 years group where it rated second behind interest rates. Is there any wonder about that? The community sees that everything it buys is made overseas. It sees more and more of this country being sold to overseas buyers, and the Government's reaction as an election approaches is: `Do not blame us, it is the private sector's debt'.

What is the Treasurer's reaction when Australia's credit rating is dropped yet another notch? It is: `They are wrong. They do not know what they are talking about'. Indeed, I say to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, that a proud achievement of the Labor Government is that we are now on a par with Spain. In the absence of the Treasurer let me say that from this survey I know exactly what my electorate is talking about and what it is thinking about. Gallivanting around the world paying back parcels of Government debt will not solve our foreign debt problems. That is what my constituents are saying.

I am pleased that the Grim Reaper did not escape unscathed in the results of the Fair-Go survey. Taxation levels received the second highest score overall and deservedly so. Bracket creep has sent workers on below average weekly earnings into tax brackets that were once preserved for the rich and the very rich. New superannuation taxes will reap $1.5 billion annually. Since March 1983, total tax revenue has risen 120 per cent from $41 billion to $91 billion. In the same period cumulative inflation was at 54.5 per cent. During the same period total fuel excise revenue has gone up 482 per cent whilst road funding has dropped 30 per cent in real terms.

The Government cannot keep its hands out of the people's pockets. Capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, unfair provisional tax-the list goes on and on. What is the Treasurer's Budget reaction to this plethora of unfair tax imposts on the Australian community? It is a sickly gloat about what he terms `the most generous tax cuts in this country's history'. In reality these tax cuts will leave the average family some $56 worse off by the end of this year than it was in 1983. We also heard of massive increases in the company and pay as you earn tax take. But in terms of respite for the tax ravaged Australian, all we had from the Treasurer was a stony silence.

In my survey, interest rates rated third overall, both in terms of points gained and the average score. Not surprisingly they were the chief concern of the 18 years to 29 years age group. These are the young families which cling to the forlorn dream of escaping the unproductive rental spiral. These are the young families which have recently taken out mortgages and have been unceremoniously thrown onto the financial scrap heap as a result of the policies of this Government. How would a compassionate and in-tune government respond? Maybe there would be an expansion of the first home owners scheme, maybe some form of mortgage interest rate relief, maybe government-funded mortgage insurance? But what do we get? Every time the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) speaks of something like this he is rubbished by Mr Keating. How did Mr Keating respond in the Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should refer to the Treasurer as such.

—How did our Treasurer respond on Budget night? `I am sorry', he said, `but you will just have to endure these rates to pay for the current massive modernisation of Australian industry'. Some comfort for struggling John Citizen who is funnelling over 40 per cent of his gross weekly earnings into mortgage repayments. The list of economic concerns expressed by my electorate but ignored by the Treasurer in his Budget go on. Fair-Go survey respondents were asked whether a second breadwinner was needed to make ends meet. Where appropriate, 66 per cent of the relevant respondents said that they needed a second breadwinner. A significant proportion of people stated it would be preferable if one parent could remain at home, but they simply could not afford what they now see as an extravagance. So help me, one bread-winner in a family unit has become an extravagance in the last few years! The quality of family life has been sacrificed by this Government's irrational economic policies. The Hawke Government continues to boast about the hundreds of thousands of jobs it has created. In actual fact, it has merely forced hundreds of thousands of inflation-ravaged and embattled households to send a second breadwinner out into the work force to make ends meet.

SPEECH.PARA: The results of the survey conclusively show that people of my electorate-and I believe Australia-are hurting and hurting badly. I can also report that the respondents to this survey are very aware of the problems which are at the root of our economic woes. Time and time again respondents rued the lack of incentive to work, the lack of productivity, the uncompetitiveness of our exports and the overemphasis on borrowing rather than saving. The message was loud and clear. People want and expect governments to address the economic problems which are threatening to bring this country to its knees. The Budget is ample proof that this Government is incapable of addressing these most important issues. At this point I advise the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) that I showed this document to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the document setting out the results of the survey.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), the Liberal member who has just resumed his seat, brought to this House a survey. I would hope that the examples he brought are a little better than the example his own Leader used of a person in great strife over interest rates when he was having that mock, or phoney, campaign. It is pretty typical of the Liberal Party that it puts forward a family with a couple of kids, two cars they own and a company car, complaining that it does not have enough money to send the kids skiing. That will probably be a typical example of what the honourable member for Moreton has brought forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline what the honourable member said. He made some rather nonsense statements and they ought not to go unchallenged. He talked about this foreign debt but he did not bother to point out that 60 per cent of this nation's foreign debt has been accumulated by the private sector and that this Government has reduced its debt to a point where its overseas assets far outweigh its debt. If we wish to look at any particular debt we ought to look to the Queensland Government, where one of its own authorities, the Queensland Electricity Commission, has a massive debt measured in billions of dollars. The Liberal member for Moreton should certainly understand that. He talked about interest rates and the people who are really struggling. I know that there are people struggling because of high interest rates, but the Liberal Party policy, espoused in this House, is that we ought to remove the 13.5 per cent ceiling. McLachlan, the star of the Liberal Party, told members when he was the head of the National Farmers Federation to get rid of the 13.5 per cent protection on one million Australian families. No doubt the honourable member for Moreton would adhere to the views raised by Elliott and McLachlan.

The honourable member also talked about the tax revenue rise. What he did not bother to point out is that the reason there is greater tax revenue is that under this Government one and a half million extra people have entered the work force. Instead of those people drawing on unemployment benefit, they are earning money. They are part of the productivity boom that is taking place in this nation and they are paying their way in taxes. The other reason there has been an increase in tax revenue is that we have finally got some of the companies which have been rorting the system to pay their way. The vast majority of money that was being paid came from the worker under the pay as you earn scheme. Now industry is being forced to pay its way because the rorts have been removed-the fringe benefits and entertainment rorts and so on.

The honourable member talked about provisional tax. This Government put a threshold of $10,332 on pensioners for provisional tax. What was it under the coalition government only seven years ago? It was $750. There is now a provisional tax threshold limit for the elderly of this nation-almost two million people-of $10,332. He talked about wanting to expand the first home owners scheme, yet until recently one of the Opposition's five policies was to abolish the first home owners scheme. I am not sure how much notice we can take of the honourable member, but I think we ought to be very wary of the sorts of things he says because they are not backed up with facts.

I want to move very quickly to what I think is the real challenge before this nation. I know that interest rates are an issue, but if we look at the broad challenge, it comes back to the changing status of our population in terms of its age. In 1989, 11 per cent, or one in 10, Australians are over the age of 65. Yet 30 years down the track we are going to find that the aged community will make up almost 20 per cent of the population. One person in five will be 65 years or over. The projection is that by the year 2020 some four million Australians will be 65 years and over. It has also been put forward statistically that for every one person who has retired and is receiving a pension there are five in the work force, but in about three decades for every elderly person there will be only two in the work force. That will place massive strains on this nation because it means there will be less tax revenue to meet age pensions. There will be fewer people producing and providing for those in retirement.

If we are going to provide a reasonable quality of life for the elderly as these numbers escalate there has to be a national strategy. That is what this Government has undertaken. The Budget we are now discussing in this Appropriation Bill debate is part of that overall national strategy. It is important that the challenge be met not only by this Government but by State governments and other instrumentalities. I hope that we will set aside party politics on this issue because each and every one of us, God giving the privilege, is going to live over the age of 65. The population is getting older and older.

Not only do we have a challenge to maintain and improve the age pension, but we also have to provide better incentives for people to add to their pensions with a self-generating retirement income scheme. That has been a philosophy put forward by Opposition members as well. It has been argued by honourable members on this side of the House but it has been this Government that has set that objective. It has set that objective not just in place but in cement. It is providing a brand new approach to ensure that there is adequate income support for the needy in its pensions scheme. As honourable members would appreciate, this Budget is going to lift the pension for the elderly of this nation up to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and more by July 1990. The Government is also now setting in train a policy, a plan, to encourage the younger generation to start providing through savings for a higher standard of living in their retirement. That savings program is a superannuation savings plan. We can be very proud of our record of providing security for the aged. In 10 years time people are going to look back at the Hawke Labor Government and praise it for seeing the problem but, more importantly, for having the courage to tackle that problem. It has taken up the challenge.

I know that we already compare favourably with most of the more highly developed countries in the world, certainly when it comes to a comparison with the United States of America and Britain in terms of assistance given to the retired. As we move through the next decade we are going to see major changes. Already we have put together a system whereby the pension allowed under social security and the extra income that is allowed to be earned will be non-taxable. It is a major change for the elderly. By July next year a single pensioner will be able to earn $40 a week, or $2,080, in any one year and know it will be tax free. A married couple can now earn $70 per week. When we add that to the pension, we start to understand that that is a very considerable income by comparison with what people earned or were allowed to earn only a few years ago.

The Government has changed the rebate system significantly. It was $430 last year, for the single pensioner it is going to increase to $650. In other words, single pensioners will be able to earn the amount of money that would have incurred a tax of $650 and not have to pay that tax. For a married couple the position is even better in that they will have a combined tax rebate of $1,040. If, because of unfortunate circumstances, married pensioners are unable to live together, say because of illness, that tax rebate will grow to $760 each per year. This will give each of them a tax free income of $8,710. I think we are finally getting to the stage where the elderly can have a true quality of life. I have always argued that no person can really exist today under $200 a week. I think that is a fair statement. We are gradually getting there. We are enabling people to get a part pension and still earn a couple of hundred dollars a week. By 1995, under this strategy anyone on a full or part pension will pay no tax whatsoever.

When that measure is put in place and we add to it savings schemes and the superannuation proposals to encourage young people to save and enter into a life-long plan, we will address the problem I spoke about earlier. It is obvious that we need to look after people now. That is what the Government is doing. This year 320,000 aged and service people will receive rental assistance. That is an added bonus which will be tax free, except in Queensland. It is shocking that the moment a person in Queensland gets any sort of increase from the Federal Government the Queensland Government taxes it. For instance, if a person in receipt of the Federal Government's family allowance supplement lives in a Housing Commission home, the allowance is added to the household income and the rent is increased. In this instance we have introduced a rental assistance scheme that cannot be taxed by State governments. I hope that the Queensland Government will rethink its responsibility, in terms of social justice, to those on lower incomes, the elderly and families.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be gone in a couple of months.

—I hope that that will be the case. It is certainly a reasonable projection. The Government has sought to bring about social justice in the community and has targeted those in need. It has targeted families and the elderly. Currently, some 1,370,000 people are on pensions and there are over 600,000 veterans. So we have a very special responsibility to two million Australians. Irrespective of the amount of pension they receive and their allowable earnings, irrespective of whether we are assisting them under the home and community care program whereby generous assistance is given to elderly people who stay in their home, irrespective of the $48.75m that is going to the pensioner housing rental program this year, irrespective of the fact that we will double the number of hostel units available since 1983 by lifting the number to 44,000 and irrespective of the special $6.3m program to build multipurpose facilities to provide health and residential community care services for the aged in country areas, I think we are meeting that challenge. I believe that the issue ought to be addressed apolitically. We will always have different stresses and priorities, but we should remember that we have a special responsibility to the elderly. The Hawke Labor Government has a strategy for the next three decades, which will be the crisis time for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I listen to speakers such as the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), I wonder what Government members think they achieve by making the statements they make about the Government's Budget. Both honourable members claimed that the reason the Government will collect additional income tax is simply that more people will be in employment.
—That is right.

—It is not the whole story, although it is certainly part of it. That is a story that is welcome to be told and this is not the first government to be able to tell it. The Government's Budget documents show that a substantial reason for the increase in income tax revenue over the next 12 months is bracket creep. That statement is not a vague allegation: it is shown in the Budget documents. They illustrate that the so-called tax cuts that people received as from July this year will be more than taken up by the effect of inflation carrying people's wages into higher income tax brackets. That has been the story throughout the life of the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact is that people are worse off because of the Hawke Government. The average wage earner is worse off. It has been shown that a one income family with an average income and dependent children is more than $50 a week worse off in net terms-that is, when all things are taken into account-than it was when the Labor Government was first elected in 1983. Also, it has been pointed out by people in the hospitality industry that the greater tax revenue which the Government looks forward to through the increased number of people in the work force is under severe threat because of its inept handling of the pilots dispute. The hospitality industry estimates that by Friday of next week 150,000 present employees of that industry will be out of work because of the pilots dispute. Yet day after day the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) comes in here and throws petrol on the flames of that dispute.

Honourable members have agreed to limit the length of their speeches in this debate in order to allow a greater number of members to speak. Therefore, one must limit the number of subjects that could be covered. I will direct my comments essentially to the Budget as it relates to pensioners and health. Earlier this year we had a debate on the Government's decision to lift the tax threshold so that pensioners do not have to pay taxation on the amount of income that they may receive before their pension entitlement is affected. The honourable member for Capricornia portrayed that as a great reform of the Hawke Government and said that the issue had not been addressed by previous governments. Under the previous Government the issue did not arise. Because of the bracket creep effect to which I referred earlier, if a pensioner's only income was the amount that he could receive before the pension entitlement was affected, he or she would have to pay tax. In fact, prior to last year's Budget a pensioner was faced with having to pay tax on not only the allowable income before his or her pension was affected but also the pension if it was his or her only income. A pensioner who did not receive any part of that $40 allowable for a single person-it is $70 for married couples-would have faced paying tax when all he or she was receiving was the pension. That was the Hawke Government's record. When the Hawke Government introduced a measure whereby those who were getting just that minimum amount no longer had to pay tax on it, all it was doing was winding the situation back to that which had obtained under previous governments.

The announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the Budget that people who receive pension income will not have to pay any tax by 1995 was a quite startling one and, on the face of it, seems to be a very welcome decision. However, when one looks at it a little further one has to draw the conclusion that it has been curiously ill thought out. In fact, curiously little thought appears to have been given to its implications. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) very properly asked the Treasurer how somebody receiving some part pension income would compare in tax terms with somebody who just failed to qualify for some form of pension income. The vagueness of the Treasurer's response surprised me, for one. It seems that the implications of the decision have not been thoroughly thought out. For equity to prevail the Government should be talking about lifting the tax threshold to the equivalent level. In today's terms that would mean lifting the tax threshold for all income earners to somewhere between $15,000 and $16,000.

If such a policy were in place now an age pensioner could receive income in excess of $15,000 and pay no tax. However, somebody who was in receipt of just over the amount that would qualify him or her for just the smallest amount of pension would pay a substantial amount of tax. That would amount to more than doubling the present tax threshold. In terms of revenue forgone, it would be an enormous amount. The Government must address this and say what it intends to do about the tax threshold; otherwise the implications are clear. The most enormous incentive will be given to people to arrange their affairs in such a way that they qualify for even a few dollars a week in pension. In any event, why would Australia's pensioners believe that the Government would achieve its promise of exemption from taxation by 1995 in light of the Government's failure to achieve the Prime Minister's promise in 1987 to eliminate child poverty by 1990? If the Government stays in power-which, clearly, is unlikely-its likelihood of achieving that promise is virtually zero.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker I take this opportunity to add my congratulations to those of other members of this chamber on your elevation to the high office you now hold in the Australian Parliament.
—Thank you.

—Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was saying a few words in relation to the Budget which we are now debating as it applies to pensioners. In the few minutes that are left to me I want to turn to another area of particular moment. We are, of course, limited in the number of subjects we can cover in the Budget debate, and I think it would be remiss of me if I did not raise the subject of the Government's child-care policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has yet again steadfastly resisted the pressure to look at the possibility of child-care costs being either a tax deduction or earning a tax rebate. Whilst the Government has been quite assiduous in its legislation for anti-discrimination and affirmative action, it nevertheless blindly insists, for doctrinaire reasons, on overlooking the biggest structural barrier to women's participation in the work force, and that is the cost and lack of availability of child-care in Australia. The availability of affordable child-care is crucial in removing the barriers to women's participation in the work force in Australia. It would seem to me to be just fundamental in affirmative action practices that the Government would have moved further in this direction.

The Government has, of course, extended child-care availability in Australia, but I am afraid we have been getting more promises than action in the last couple of years. Yet again, the Government is talking about the additional places it is going to provide by 1992. This was, of course, announced in last year's Budget, although there was no chance of anything happening in the previous financial year. This year we get the promise that by 1992 the Government will provide a number of extra places-that is, in three years' time. Last year's promise was for three years as from last year. We are told that the national child-care strategy, which was announced last year, will provide 30,000 new child-care places over the next three years in cooperation with the States, local government and employers. That is precisely what we were told 12 months ago. Further, we are told that agreements have been finalised with most States to contribute to the recurrent cost of these new places. The agreements are not final 12 months down the track and they are still just a promise to Australian women.

There are no recent figures available on usage of child-care in Australia, but the figures that are available can be extrapolated fairly simply. In 1980 the Australian Bureau of Statistics carried out a child-care survey which indicated that of pre-school children 37.4 per cent were cared for at home by their mothers, 12.5 per cent were in pre-school kindergartens, and only 5.5 per cent were in formal child-care centres. The remaining 44.6 per cent of pre-school children therefore were being cared for somehow outside the home. The increases in the number of child-care places and in participation by women in the work force would enable us to reach the situation of concluding that there is still a very large number of children who are in informal child-care situations. Probably at least 35 per cent are still not catered for by Government action of one sort or another.

The leading case in the whole matter of tax deductability of child-care costs is one of Lodge versus the Federal Commissioner of Taxation of 1972. The attitudes that were displayed in that judgment and in subsequent judgments by tribunals-I have no hesitation in saying this, and I do not blush to say it-simply reflect an attitude and a point of view of certain men. In that case there was a taxpayer working at home who had a dependent child and who was a single parent. It was necessary for her to put her two-year-old child in day care for the days that she was working for a law firm from her home. In his judgment on this, Justice Mason concluded that this expenditure was incurred for the purpose of earning assessable income and was an essential prerequisite to the derivation of income; nevertheless, it was not relevant or incidental to the preparation of the bills of costs that this taxpayer was involved in and therefore was not incurred in the course of preparing bills of cost.

This judgment contrasts quite strongly with other judgments that the court and tribunals have given. For example, under the same section of the taxation Act, we allow people to claim the cost of uniforms. Could it really be claimed that a nurse could not carry out her job if she was not wearing a uniform? Could it really be claimed that the attendants in this chamber could not carry out their jobs if they were not wearing a uniform? If one wanted to apply the same strict interpretation of the Act as has been done in the case of child-care, one would find that many deductions that are presently available would not be available to taxpayers. There are many deductions available to members of parliament, indeed, to only would-be members of parliament, that would not be allowable under those circumstances. I remind the House that the Commissioner of Taxation has ruled that unsuccessful candidates for Parliament, people who have never been a member of parliament, are able to claim taxation deductions for expenses they incur in attempting to be elected to Parliament-not in carrying out the job; in attempting to be elected to Parliament, even when they are unsuccessful.

I contrast a case of a judgment by the Taxation Tribunal a few years ago where one tribunal member pointed out that to earn income it was more essential for a car salesman to be able to buy a prospective customer a pint of beer, and so possibly sell a car, than it was for a mother to buy child-care and so earn a wage. In that case he knew he was addressing himself to a sole parent. It might seem a bit extreme when I say that I fear the attitude that has been reflected is one that is more typically unsympathetic and uncaring about the issue than one that reflects justice.
The Board of Review in New South Wales in 1981 said, in once again ruling against child-care costs as a tax deduction for an income earner:
It apparently needs to be stressed again and again that the remedy lies with Parliament, not boards of review.

There it is, fairly and squarely: it lies with Parliament, and therefore with government. If justice is to be achieved and if affirmative action is to mean anything, it is something that this Parliament must legislate.

When one turns one's attention to the actual cost of this, it is curious to find out who speaks and what they say. In 1984 the Australian Financial Review carried a story headlined `Tax deductions for child care could cost $400m'. This referred to some assessment that had been made by the Department of Social Security and apparently leaked to the press-one assumes by the Department of Social Security-in which the Department estimated that it could cost $400m a year to provide tax deductions for child-care expenses. I would view that judgment with some jaundice because of an answer the Treasurer gave to the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) to a question on notice, the answer appearing in the Hansard of 16 September 1986, more than two years after that assessment by the Department of Social Security. In response to the honourable member's question whether there had been estimated a cost to revenue of tax deductibility of child-care, the Treasurer said:

The cost to revenue of allowing full tax deductibility for child care expenses incurred by taxpayers whose children are cared for to enable them to go out to work is estimated to be of the order of $150m in a full year.
That is rather less than the other estimate, which one suspects was prepared in order to oppose any such deduction. The Treasurer went on to say:
For the purposes of this estimate it has been assumed that all such expenditure in respect of children aged 12 years and under would qualify for deduction.
In other words, the extreme case has been taken and still the answer three years ago was only $150m for a full year. The Treasurer further said:
If tax deductability were to be limited to payments to registered child care centres, or allowed only in respect of children of pre-school age, the cost to revenue would be less.

It would be significantly less, I suggest. In other words, the figures that are bandied about as a deterrent to serious consideration of either tax deductability or tax rebates, which are considered to be a fairer system, show that the cost is not high.

I think all of us in this Parliament say that we want to take action in Parliament to enhance the quality of life of families in Australia. The alleviation of stress and financial burden in this area would be of very clear benefit. I would also like to put it to the Parliament that we would not have our dramatically declining birth rate if it were not for the inequities that women in particular suffer under this system. I hear a lot of statements made about why women are not having more children these days. Mortgages, interests rates and so on are mentioned and certainly are a factor. People say that a lot of women go to work only because they want to pay the bills. That is true but it is also true that a lot of men go to work only because they have to pay some bills too, and, given the choice of living comfortably without having to go to work, a lot of men would take that option as well. Nevertheless I firmly believe that women are going to go to work in this day and age anyway, and if we had not put so many penalties on women being mothers and also participating in the work force our birth rate would be higher. More women would choose to have more children if the penalties were not so great for them.

I urge the Government to consider this matter seriously. I am pleased that the Opposition has turned its attention to it and has pledged itself to introducing a tax rebate for the cost of child-care where it is necessary for someone to earn an income. It seems only simple justice and logic.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Peter Morris-As this is a stunt to conceal the disarray in the Opposition's industrial relations policy, leave is not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity at the outset to congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on the high office you have attained. It is a very lonely job and requires the utmost cooperation from the House to assist you to carry out your duties. I wish you well. In doing so, I also congratulate the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on his election as Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Opposition's initial response to this year's Budget it tried to play on the point that perhaps in some way this Budget was an election Budget. The Opposition highlighted the various policy announcements and tried to conjure up the notion that they were in some fashion a bid to buy votes. Budgets of that nature, of course, were very much paramount throughout and following the Menzies years but if we look at the nature of Australian politics now there is a more steady progression in the way in which our budgetary matters are pursued and our economic matters controlled.

This year's Budget had much of its basis in the April statement of earlier this year. It has been the nature of the way that this Government has worked that it has gradually worked on policy items, and a number of those culminated in this year's Budget. One of the most important was the announcement on retirement income. The suggestion that this was in some way a hasty proposition put forward in a run-up to an election is arrant nonsense. One has only to look at the work that has been done by the Social Security Review and the number of papers canvassing issues around retirement income to know that that notion is out of order. Much of the policy that was announced resulted not only from the Social Security Review but also from a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled Income Support for the Retired and the Aged. It has had wide consideration and much community debate.

Another important aspect of the Budget is the putting down of a social justice for youth statement. This again was something that took several months to develop, in consultation with outside bodies. Again to suggest that this was something that was hastily put together is nonsense. The Budget also gave substantive appropriation basis for the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the environment, which he made last month, and the National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia, which he announced last month. Again those two statements were very much proposals that had been developed over time and given great consideration.

This year's Budget establishes a framework of opportunity for Australia. What a contrast it is between the economic management of this Government and that of those opposite. The projected Budget surplus for 1989-90 is some $9,122m. This represents the third consecutive Budget surplus achieved by this Government. It also happens to be only the third time that the Budget has been brought into surplus in the 37 years for which comparable records have been maintained. This is totally in contrast to the projected record deficit of $9.6 billion left by the coalition rabble in 1983. If we take a few moments to do the simple arithmetic, that represents a turnaround of over $18 billion since the election of the Labor Government. The Budget surplus has been created by restraint in Government spending. This is something about which the Opposition has made plenty of statements but, when in government, did very little about.

In this Budget real government spending has been cut for the fourth year in a row. Outlays now constitute 23.7 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP)-the lowest level for 16 years. The surplus will be sufficient to offset the borrowings by all spheres of Government. As a consequence, the public sector borrowing requirement is forecast to be in surplus by 1.2 per cent of GDP. As was the case with the previous two surpluses, the Government will use all of this year's surplus to pay off debt. Australia's foreign currency debt has fallen from $15.1 billion in 1987 to $9.3 billion in 1989. In addition to retiring this massive block of foreign debt, the Government repaid $2.2 billion of domestic debt in 1987-88 and over $2.7 billion in 1988-89. Again this record of responsible economic management by the Government is in marked contrast to the record of those opposite when in government during the dim dark Fraser years. Between 1975-76 and 1982-83 net overseas raisings totalled $4.5 billion. Between 1983-84 and 1988-89 the Labor Government has repaid in net terms a total of $1.5 billion of foreign currency debt. The same contrast applies when we examine the savings question. This Government has both lifted Government savings and encouraged superannuation. The public sector in total, including government business enterprises, State and local governments and the Commonwealth, has been transformed from being a net borrower to the tune of 6.7 per cent of GDP in 1983-84 to a net saver of one per cent of GDP last year.

Under the Labor Government more has been done to encourage occupational superannuation than under any other government in Australia's history. In March 1987, as part of the historic accord with the trade union movement, occupational superannuation coverage equal to a wage increase of 3 per cent was extended across the work force. By 1990 most workers should have access to occupational superannuation providing them with genuine retirements benefits. By the end of this year alone, 80 per cent of workers will be covered by an award where an employer must provide superannuation.

In the Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that the Government would consider a further 3 per cent award for occupation superannuation as part of the wage system next year. This will be achieved under the Labor Party's accord with the trade union movement. The Opposition's determination to smash the wages system would return superannuation to being a privilege of the wealthy. The Treasurer has made it quite clear that superannuation is the Government's preferred savings vehicle. Compare this approach with the rash, ill-conceived savings gimmick that was launched recently by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). The Leader of the Opposition and his erstwhile colleague the professor, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), are attempting to substitute novelties for numbers. We are still awaiting some detailed policies from the Opposition-policies, not buzz words.

The Government's support and encouragement for superannuation is given through generous tax concessions. These tax concessions amount to about $4 billion in forgone tax. Last year's superannuation assets grew by a massive $15 billion. Current savings in superannuation funds are in excess of $100 billion-three times the 1982-83 level. As a result of the Government's actions since 1983, culminating in the measures in this Budget, and with the increasing popularity of superannuation, it is estimated that by the year 2000 superannuation funds will receive more than $30 billion a year in new contributions, leading to a growth in assets of about $60 billion a year.

As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) recently stated, the political issue of the 1990s will be how we as a nation can best use this pool of national savings. The Minister pointed correctly to the needs of Australia's infrastructure-not only for expansion of infrastructure but also for maintenance of existing infrastructure. This need was identified clearly in the main conclusions of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Constructing and Restructuring Australia's Public Infrastructure. The report had this to say:
. . . there is no reason to believe that Australia will be immune from a build-up of rehabilitation needs of the type that has occurred in other developed nations.
Maintenance and replacement needs will substantially increase during the rest of this century due to the overall age pattern of Australian infrastructure.

There are still significant gaps in Australian infrastructure networks, all of which it would be desirable to fill and some of which it is essential to fill. We may have to cope with the ageing of much of our existing infrastructure before we have completed many of its networks.

A similar recognition of Australia's needs into the next century, although on a slightly different tack, led to a recommendation for the creation of the national development fund included in the report Australia Reconstructed. In this report it was suggested that savings of superannuation funds might be directed to new industrial capacity and housing. It might be worthwhile re-examining this proposal and adding infrastructure as a priority.

In the region I represent this issue is especially relevant to the appropriate development of the Plenty Valley, which is one of the most important, if not the most important, growth areas in metropolitan Melbourne. Over the next decade or more it will play a vital role in meeting the housing needs of the expanding Melbourne metropolis. The State Government is now working to ensure that this development takes place with the appropriate physical and social infrastructure, which can be acquired only through the necessary physical and social planning. We cannot afford to have the existing urban fringe placed under even greater pressure because of the lack of infrastructure, with the building of homes outpacing the provision of services. All spheres of Government have a role to play in this social planning. The mistakes of the developments of the 1950s and 1960s must be avoided.

In this Budget funding has been provided to redress one of these deficiencies through the announcement of the funding for the technical and further education college at Epping, which will expand the post-secondary education prospects of much of my constituency. The Federal Government must participate in the development of programs designed to tackle structural and regional inequalities of income, wealth, housing, transport, education and health. For the first time we can consider these options without having to consider overseas borrowings. We have the opportunity to consider an investment in our future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dominant issue of the day is of course the industrial dispute between the pilots and the airline companies. That dispute has the potential to destroy the centralised wage fixation system and to put out of kilter many of the assumptions on which the Budget is based. I wish to address two aspects of that dispute. The first concerns a statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Question Time today when he clearly said that the pilots were outside the system, that somehow there was no jurisdiction in the system to deal with them. The second aspect I wish to address is the likelihood of how this dispute will settle. Settle it will, of course, and, in the end, I believe the odds are that the pressure for settlement will come from the Australian Council of Trade Unions when it sees its members stood down, as they must be.

SPEECH.PARA: First to what the Prime Minister said today. Here we have a man with many years of experience in industrial relations. He claims to know more about the subject than any person, or indeed any group of persons, in the country. One would think that he almost invented the system. He came to us in Question Time today and gave a long-winded and abusive answer to a question put to him by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). He was wrong about the way in which the system works. He said, `As a result of the airline pilots' union following its policy' the pilots are `faced with a position whereby they are out of the system'. There was then an interjection from the honourable member for Flinders. The Prime Minister continued:
I did not say the pilots union; I said the pilots are out of the system.
If we were in doubt as to what he meant, he made it plain again when he said:
I said the pilots are out of the system.
Later he said:
It means that there is now no basis upon which under the industrial relations policy they can be dealt with within the system.

That is an extraordinary state of affairs. Does anybody really believe that there is no way they can be dealt with within the industrial relations system? Apparently the Prime Minister does. He has been given advice to that effect, no doubt. Yet today in the Australian Financial Review we see that Commissioner Alan Paine is reported as taking a quite different view. The quotation from what Mr Paine says is this:

It is appropriate therefore to stress, notwithstanding the cancellation of those awards, that it remains open to the federation as an organisation under the [Industrial Relations] Act to bring the dispute to the commission for resolution in accordance with the processes afforded by the Act.

Who is right? Is the Prime Minister right or is the Commissioner right? Plainly the Commissioner is. In saying that, let me just add this: I wish to make it perfectly plain that I have no sympathy for what the pilots have done and I am not going to allow my name to be added to those whose views had been misrepresented so repeatedly and so assiduously by the Government side. What they have done is to pursue self-interest without regard for the interests, the convenience and the capacity to earn a living of individuals and for the travel industry. It is a great pity that they did not think of the nationwide consequences of their action before taking the action that they have.

But I return now to the main point. These pilots are not out of the system, nor is there now no basis upon which, under the industrial relations policy, they can be dealt with within the system-to quote the Prime Minister again-because what we are dealing with here is a situation where the organisation is registered and as a registered organisation it can go before the Commission after having cut a deal with the airlines. That is specifically provided for by section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act. That section says:
If the parties to an industrial dispute-
and there would not be anybody here who would deny that we have an industrial dispute-
. . . agree on terms for the settlement of . . . dispute, they may make a memorandum of the terms agreed on.
It further provides that they may:
. . . apply to the Commission for the certification of the agreement.
It further provides that:
If the Commission is of the opinion that the agreement is in the interests of the parties immediately concerned-
that is, the airlines and the pilots-
the Commission shall-
subject to certain provisions-
certify the agreement unless it is of the opinion that it would be contrary to the public interest to certify the agreement.

So we have, in this sequence, an agreement reached, an application made to the Commission, and a process for certification laid down by the Act. Then, critically, subsection (5) of section 115 says this:
Certification of the agreement shall not be taken to be contrary to the public interest merely because the agreement is inconsistent with general Full Bench principles.

There are, of course, general Full Bench principles that have been laid down about wages in this country. They were laid down back in 1987, they were reaffirmed and reinterpreted in 1988, and they have been reaffirmed once more in the national wage case of August this year. Those are the wage fixing principles that the Prime Minister must be referring to. But they have nothing to do with the capacity of these parties to reach an agreement and to have that agreement certified by the Commission. Further than that, the Government itself can be heard, because specifically under section 43 and 44 of the Industrial Relations Act, power is given to the Government to intervene. So that if the airlines and the union cut a deal and want to have it certified, then it is up to the Government to decide whether it wants to be involved, as, of course, it would have to be.

So, in short, the position is this, contrary to what the Prime Minister says. First, the system applies. It is open, and it is ludicrous nonsense for the Prime Minister to come here and suggest that somehow these people, through their union-because the union is the registered body that represents their interests before the Commission-cannot go along and use the processes laid down by the Act. They can do that unless, of course, the Prime Minister is going to come into this House and say that there is no industrial dispute-in which event he would be behaving like a nineteenth century lawyer, and I doubt that is the kind of figure that he would want to cut.

So that is the first thing that needs be said. The Act provides a mechanism and the Prime Minister is wrong when he says that the members of the union are out of the system. I raise the question: Why did he say it? How could he, with his experience, have made such a mistake? Could he have been given mistaken advice on such an obvious point? Or is it, perhaps, that the Government wishes to be as far away from this dispute as possible while shouting on the sidelines as loudly as possible and saying two things: `Look, we can't do anything. You fellows fix it up. We wish of course that we could do something, but we can't'. Yet, of course, ironically the powers that could be used to force the parties to come to a sensible agreement, sanctions that the Prime Minister has asked private parties, the airlines, to use, are in a Bill which the honourable member for Flinders a few minutes ago sought to present to this House. What happens? He is cut off-`No, we do not want to know anything about it'. The Government does not want to know anything about it because that Bill contains provisions which were originally in its own legislation and were cut out. Why? Because Simon said so. Simon said no-`No, we are not going to have that, Bob', and Bob said, `Okay, Simon; okay'.

Let us go to the second aspect. What is going to happen? If the pilots hold out, the strike cannot be broken. That is the reality. It cannot be broken because there are not enough pilots to come in and take the jobs. It would, of course, cause a major industrial relations fight if that happened, but it is not going to happen. There have been attempts made to find alternatives, and all we know is that the outcome is just about zero. The airlines are bleeding to death. Financially the cost to the airlines is immense. Yet the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), that enlightened economic body, always with the long term interests of this country at heart, says, `We will fight to the death if you stand down a single member for a single hour'.

Just contemplate this: the airlines, through no fault of their own, cannot fly their planes-because the pilots will not fly them. And what does the ACTU say?-`Well, of course, the reason why we have these thousands of employees in our many affiliated unions is that they are there to help you fly the planes. But even though you cannot fly the planes, even though they have nothing to do, even though those checking-in people will not be checking in people, even though the baggage handlers will not be handling baggage, even though the mechanics will not be repairing minor defects in planes as they are turning about, even though the catering system is not going to be there, even though the airline stewards and stewardesses do not have a job to go to, you cannot stand them down. That would be wrong'.

We know that that is going to happen, because money will not be given by this Government to the airlines. That is something which, at the end of the day, the Government will shrink from, because it is quite impossible. The airlines will have to stand down employees, and when that takes place the weight is going to come on from the ACTU to the Government to cut a deal, to facilitate a deal, or not to prevent a deal being cut. When the threat of stand-downs is on, that is when we shall see a settlement emerge. I do not say that that is a good thing, but I say that all the odds are that that is the reality.

In conclusion, I think that the Government would advance the interests of this country a great deal further if, instead of engaging in a tirade of abuse against the Opposition, it looked to the mechanisms available to it and suggested to the parties that it might be very wise to sit down as quickly as possible, to invoke the mechanisms of section 115, which were brought in by this Government, and to cut a deal. The alternative is a disaster, unless the Government believes that the strike will be broken. It is one thing for the Government to believe that and turn out to be correct, but what are the odds of this occurring? In the meantime the damage that is being done to this country and to individual firms and businesses, and the inconvenience that is being suffered by individuals, is great. It is about time that we had some common sense and some straight dealing by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want to talk about the dispute involving the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, mainly because we have discussed this matter for the last three or four days. I am sorry to see the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) leaving the chamber, because I want to make a few comments about what he has said. I want to defend what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said during Question Time today. With due respect to the honourable member for North Sydney-I understand that he is a prominent Sydney Queen's Counsel-I hope that not too many people are prepared to pay him the $2,000 per day fee that his level of experience would dictate, because he does not know what he is talking about. The reality is that the pilots have resigned. They are no longer employees under the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act. They are not employees of the employers, the airlines. Their award has been cancelled. The Federation of Air Pilots is still a registered union. Orders can be made against it, but not against the membership.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Prime Minister said today-I repeat it in case Opposition members do not understand, although it is kindergarten stuff-the pilots have resigned. They are no longer employees of the airlines. Therefore, the Act does not come into operation. How many more times do we have to repeat this to Opposition members? How many more times do we have to listen to the honourable member for North Sydney say such things? The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) is another lawyer who, thankfully, is a member of this House rather than practising law. Frankly, the kind of legal advice that could be offered by these honourable members leaves a lot to be desired, in my opinion. I am a lowly solicitor, not a QC; but even I understand what is going on. I am not an advocate; I am basically a commercial solicitor. The shadow Minister who is at the table, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), is also a solicitor. He knows full well that what I am saying is correct. Whom should we believe? Should we believe the honourable member for North Sydney, the honourable member for Flinders, Mr McLachlan, or even the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock)? The fact is that members of the Liberal and National parties are in complete disarray on this issue. They do not know what they are doing. They are running around like chooks with their heads cut off. They are running here, there and everywhere. Opposition members should start to do something constructive about this dispute. Instead of asking questions on the airline dispute every day, they should give us some ideas about how to solve it.

I do not want to waste any of the precious seven or eight minutes remaining to me. I say to Opposition members: war has been declared by the Air Pilots Federation on this issue. The Federation has circulated a financial planning advice document from which I quoted the other day during the discussion of a matter of public importance raised by Opposition members, when they again wasted the time of the House and supported the pilots, as they have done for the last three or four days. The document tells pilots to go fishing. It tells them to get a second job. I do not want to continue with this topic because I think it is fairly obvious that the Opposition does not know where it stands on the issue. It sends in its high priced QC to say things which, frankly, I would not expect my articled clerk to say.

I turn to the matter which I want to speak about tonight-that is the 1989-90 Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I am very proud to be a member of this Government. I say that quite sincerely, because the Treasurer has brought down a Budget which has been described as tough but fair; a Budget which, in an election period-I expect this to be the last Budget handed down before the Federal election to be held some time next year-has not been a grab bag of goodies, as is sometimes the case. The fact is that it has looked to the future. I want to read from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 16 August by John Sampson and Graham Williams headed, `Welfare decisions win praise'. It reads:
The elderly will be the major beneficiaries of a `frugal but well-designed' budget for the welfare sector.
Mr Julian Disney, president of the Australian Council of Social Service, said last night that the 1989 Budget by comparison with recent budgets, used the money well without as many horrendous cuts.
Although ACOSS had requested an aged pension of 30 per cent of average weekly earnings, it was happy to get 25 per cent, he said.
Increases in rent assistance, indexation of the pension-free area, simplification of tax arrangements for pensioners, and the further improvement to superannuation, were all satisfactory moves.
The $100 million expansion for homeless and disadvantaged youth, although it fell short in some areas, was still to be applauded, Mr Disney said.
In all, he said, it was a Budget which looked to the future.

It is a Budget that looks to the future. It is a Budget that is part of the ongoing process of economic restructuring that has been undertaken by the Hawke Labor government during its seven years in office.

I was very proud and pleased to serve on the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes. We travelled around the whole of Australia and talked to everybody who was prepared to make submissions to us. I am very happy to say that on the Gold Coast the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), a lady for whom I have a great deal of respect, came along to the meeting and contributed, or at least listened to what was being said. I do not know whether the honourable member for Bass attended any of the meetings. Had he done so, he would have felt that we were listening to what people wanted to tell us, and they told us a lot. We did not let the things they told us go in one ear and out the other. We prepared a full report which we presented to the Prime Minister. I am very happy to say that many of the matters that were raised by pensioners, by superannuants, by retired people in receipt of part pensions, have been taken up by this Government. It gives one a great deal of satisfaction to know that, as a back bench member, one can make some contribution in the area of policy. All of the members of the task force are very grateful for that.

I could talk about what we have done for pensioners, but I had to waste a lot of time counteracting the rubbish that we have been hearing from the Opposition about the airline pilots dispute. Many of the things we have done involved seeing whether we could give pensioners a reasonable living standard. We appreciate that it is very difficult for pensioners to live on a certain amount of money. We are attempting to advance their position in financial terms in accordance with the cost of living. However, some pensioners, spurred on by baseless claims from the Opposition, in particular by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), have complained that the Government does not care about older Australians. Of course, that is not true. The Government has raised the pension to the current level of 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. This has risen from 22.7 per cent in 1983 when this Government came into office. Labor's longstanding commitment to an age pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings not only will be met, but will be exceeded in April 1990.

One of the real benefits of this Budget, about which I have a very smug confidence-and I know that every member on this side of the House has-is that, irrespective of what happens in the future, all of these benefits, such as pensions and family allowances, are indexed. If the Opposition ever gets the chance to do anything about this issue, I would like to see it break the indexation principles. One has to look at the possibility that some time in the distant future the Opposition might get the opportunity to do that. I suggest that it would be a very brave government that would break the indexation principles that this Government has brought in with respect to the question of pensions, family allowances and other benefits.

We all know that one major problem that was conveyed to us which is of concern to the people in the electorates-I might also say that it is of concern to the people in my electorate at Wynnum and Manly-is the amount that pensioners could earn before it affected their pension. In fact, we have increased that amount quite dramatically. In 1995 no pensioner receiving any sort of a pension or part pension will be in a position where he or she will have to pay tax. We have included a lump sum bereavement allowance of approximately $1,207 and other options will give the surviving pensioner the choice of receiving a substantial lump sum payment for use on the deceased's funeral costs or for use on other pressing financial commitments.

Before my time expires I want to touch briefly on one area that we have really got our teeth into and that is the area of superannuation. There is no doubt whatsoever that the superannuation policies that have been brought into place by the Treasurer and by this Government have been an absolute bonanza for this country. I will quickly read from the Chanticleer column in the Australian Financial Review of 16 August. It states:
The revolution this Government has now produced in retirement income and therefore fund management is now as great as anything else it has done, including its deregulation of the financial system.
The growth in the funds management business from here to the turn of the century will be enormous.
Since the Hawke Government started fixing up the retirement incomes system . . .

It would mean that within about 15 years, the savings position of the nation will have been transformed to the point where foreign debt of the size we are all now so worried about will either disappear or become irrelevant.
What Paul Keating and Treasury have done is tackle it now, and not put it off for a future Government, and they have done so in a way that looks like it might work.

Time has beaten me. There are many other measures in the package, such as no tax on non-profit clubs and spending on sport to rise by more than half and then to rise again. The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) who is at the table, will give evidence to the fact that we have actually increased road funding in this country by some $120m. So much for all the rubbish that has come from the Opposition. Finally, this Government has brought in a Budget which members of the Opposition are very envious of. They have no policy and they do not know where they are. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has come out with all sorts of stupid schemes and tax savings breaks and everything else. The fact is that they have no policy and they are extremely envious of what the Government has been able to do. As a member of this Government I feel proud that I have been able to speak to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) today. I commend the Treasurer and all the Ministers, including the Minister at the table, for what they have done and for the moneys that they have made available for the betterment of this country to the absolute dismay of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the last speaker, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), believes what he has just said in connection with road funding, he would believe anything. It discredits everything else that he has said before. I say that with great respect in front of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown). If the honourable member were as good an accountant as he thinks he is a lawyer, he would understand that there has been a 30 per cent decrease in real terms in road funding from the Commonwealth. I wanted to address myself to that matter later, but I might as well address myself to it now. The whole speech of the honourable member for Bowman has lost any impact because of that final statement.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting that earlier today there was a plea within the chamber by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar). He suggested that what we are debating now in the Budget is a consequence of what has happened in Australia over the last 20 years, under three different governments. He indicated that the Budget should be realistically addressing the problems that confront Australia and should avoid any unnecessary confrontation. I believe that those remarks would have been viewed with some kind of regard by most honourable members in this chamber. When one listens to the comments from the Government side that have been made on the Budget, one gets the feeling that an election is in the air. Somebody used to say at election time that he could feel a dam coming on. This time it is an election coming on.

This Budget does not address itself to the fundamental problems that confront Australia at the moment. While we would applaud the Budget surplus of some $9.1 billion, we must remember that with that $9.1 billion we are paying back the extravagances that the honourable member for Wide Bay was talking about earlier in connection with past debts. The Minister pointed his finger at me when I said that we are paying off past debts. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) got to his feet very quickly the other day and suggested that he is paying off the coalition's debt incurred when it was in government. In actual fact, if we look at the 1983-84 Budget and the three Budgets that came after that, we see that the Commonwealth, the Parliament, the people of Australia, chalked up a debt of $23 billion through the deficits that were provided in those Budgets. I understand that of the debt that this Government, this Parliament and this Commonwealth owes, 75 per cent is on a six months roll-over. To say that the debt is paying off one regime's costs as against the other is just not a fair assessment.

The reality is that the $9.1 billion is only a fraction of the amount that has been carried by this Parliament as a deficit and it was an extravagance over those years. While we applaud that, there is some responsibility in it. When we look at the document we see that the election factor is there for one main reason; that is that the fundamental problem in Australia today is that expectations become rights. Over a period governments have catered to those expectations and rights-or what people considered to be their rights-on the basis that there will be a payment by the Commonwealth in order to curry favour with a particular section. What is wrong with Australia at the moment is the fact that those expectations have not been matched by productivity within this country. As we go around Australia today, we hear that what is needed is productivity.

I will just mention the air pilots strike. At the moment people are talking about the eight hours at the stick. People are saying to me-I am not canvassing the proposition-that the 35 per cent increase, or any increase, is worth it if there is an increase in productivity as a result. The reason I say that the Government has not set the framework in this Budget for what will occur in the economy in the next 12 months is that it has not come to grips with productivity or with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). One can feel the dead hand of the ACTU on this Budget because the framework was set well before the Budget presentation as to what the unions would accept and would demand in relation to an increase in their wage component around Australia irrespective of the productivity that was there. This Budget is not addressing those fundamentals.

I will stress where this Budget fails as far as the productivity criterion is concerned. it accepts an inflation rate of over 7 per cent, which represents a loss of productivity. In other words, we are taking more out of the system than we are putting into it by a factor of 7 per cent. That is what inflation means. When we talk in terms of our gross or net foreign debt increasing, that is also an indication that Australians are consuming to a greater extent than they are producing. Last year that figure was set at $9 billion and it went into a deficit of $17 billion, which would seem to me to be an extravagance that Australian cannot afford at the moment because it is bearing a debt for the future to pay for the extravagances of this particular generation. The framework of this Budget does not address that basic lack of production because it sets in place a figure of $18.1 billion as a further deficit for 12 months. That will have the effect of increasing Australia's foreign debt.

During the week I read an interesting address by Mr Ferris, the Chairman of the Australian Trade Commission, Austrade. Apart from the graphs that he gives at the end-I believe that this is so right that one cannot fail to see the point-he says:
As you can see, our trade predicament is of long standing. That was what the honourable member for Wide Bay said earlier today.
It has been a fact of life for the past 20 years. The address continues:
It can perhaps be characterised by saying that we currently have the commodity based export profile of a third world country but the manufacturing based import appetite of an advanced economy.
I think that puts it rather succinctly. So the Budget fails on that score, but it gets 10 marks for being an election Budget as it does not address the fundamental problems.

Where did the 1988-89 Budget fail? It failed again on productivity. It failed again on inflation. Inflation was set at 4 per cent and it came in at 7 per cent. On interest rates, being part of the monetary policy of this Government, the Budget failed because they went up. In the small business area, or the borrowing area, people were paying 16 per cent at the beginning of that period and at the end they were paying 22 to 23 per cent. A question asked of me, not with any political intent, was: How do you expect to borrow money at 23 per cent, put it into a business and make a profit? Growth on the Australian scene is not growth in productivity or economic progress but growth in consumerism, and that is where this Government's monetary policy falls flat.

Last year the Treasurer said that the 1988-89 Budget was the one that would bring home the bacon. I say to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table: the pig is still alive and well. It has its nose well and truly in the trough and it has not been caught yet. I suggest that the Treasurer should get himself into gear, look at what that pig is doing, and see whether he can convert it into bacon to bring home at the end of this year.

I should like to refer to a statement in a book by Victor Hugo that I am reading which really puts this matter into perspective. He commented over 130 years ago that wealth is created by work-that is, productivity, innovation and effort, with everybody interested. Wealth is created by work and productivity and wages are a mere distribution of that wealth. We have to produce the wealth before we can distribute it. I say again that this Budget does nothing in that connection.

The position of our net foreign debt is borne out by the decision this week of Moody's Investors Service-a judgment by a world accredited body on Australia's debt potential. Anybody who suggests that a net foreign debt of $108 billion is not an embarrassment to Australia ought to look again. We could also look at the judgment of the London money market that the Australian dollar is overvalued by some 20 per cent. Of course, the Minister will say that nothing has happened as a result. One solution to Australia's economic problems would be for us to look at the value of the dollar and let it peg at its natural level without being propped up by interest rates. That 20 per cent devaluation would have two effects: firstly, it would pull down interest rates; and secondly, it would leave the economies of the Third World running on a resource base. At least it would allow those resources to trade better in the Western world.

Last year's Budget and this year's Budget both failed on the aspect of competitiveness. At the luncheon today for the Prime Minister of Thailand I asked a diplomat from Thailand what their inflation rate was. Honourable members should bear in mind that Thailand is not really one of the developed countries of the world; it is pulling itself through. Last year its inflation rate was as little over 4 per cent. I asked the diplomat, `What do you expect this year?'. He said, `We expect to bring it in a little over one per cent'. I asked, `How is your productivity? Do you work five or six days a week?'. He said, `No, we work five days a week'. It is obvious, from the productivity point of view, that the cost of Thailand's products is so much below ours that it does not allow ours to be competitive.

Let us look at some other comparisons in connection with inflation. While Australia was suffering an inflation rate of 7 per cent, our major competitors in the European Economic Community had an inflation rate of 5.1 per cent; in the United States of America 5.1 per cent; in West Germany 3 per cent; and in Japan 2.4 per cent. Again, this indicates greater productivity in those countries than we have in Australia. Turning to overseas interest comparisons on long term government bonds, Australia was nearly 14 per cent; West Germany 7 per cent; Japan 5 per cent; the United States of America 9 per cent; and the United Kingdom 9 per cent. How can Australia be expected to compete when those international comparisons are against us and the productivity of other countries is also against us? In so many ways this Budget has failed to address the fundamental problems that are facing Australia at the moment.

Earlier I mentioned the election footing. Something that might have escaped the attention of the general populace is that within Appropriation Bill (No. 1) there is an extravagance-I am not sure how we could afford it-a $3.1m extension of the House of Representatives postal allowance.
