It is intended to increase the allowance from the previous $9,000 to $30,500 for each member. I would like to ask the people of Australia how they view that massive-almost fourfold-increase in the allowance. It is part of the election footing being prepared by this Government for its members in the more marginal electorates, together with the aNiMLS, the postal unit, the computers and the excessive use of telephones. I believe that all of this is an extravagance that Australians ought to be looking at very carefully. The Government is doing this at a time when it is trying to bring a report into this House to limit to its own advantage the amount of advertising available on commercial and other television. I think that is a problem that the Australian people ought to be aware of. The Government is being extravagant in spending this sort of money to boost its own marginal electorates when at the same time it is reducing the road component in the Budget by 30 per cent.

I want to mention roads because in the division of Dawson, which I represent, we had Cyclone Aivu in early April. While I do not attribute all the damage to the Bruce Highway to the lack of funds, it is in one hell of a mess. While at the moment people might be diverted slightly by the fact that we have an airline pilots strike, which means that air transportation is not available, I would suggest that anybody who travelled on the Bruce Highway in Queensland would see the problem as it really is. At a time when there is a desperate need for good roads for internal tourism and for trade, this matter must be looked at quickly.

At the time of Cyclone Aivu I paid a tribute to the manner in which the weather bureau and the radar tracking station at Townsville tracked that cyclone compared with the tracking of Cyclone Charlie the year before. I pointed out that Australia has too much old equipment, including radar and other safety devices. I have heard that the weather tracking equipment I was referring to did such a good job only because that cyclone came in quickly and passed through with great intensity. There was a lot of damage but it went through quickly. Advice has been given to me that the weather observer station at Mount Stewart in Townsville has old and antiquated equipment. The Mount Stewart radar kept on cutting in and out and had to be controlled manually because it could not keep up with the pace of the wind. The radar equipment, which is 1950 technology, is having problems. The radar equipment, which gives measurements of temperature and humidity from field recorders and ground equipment, is not compatible with the programs available to process radar observations. Only two telephones are available at the station to provide an answering service. In many other ways this indicates that there is a lot left to be desired in this area. I mention it because it is a safety factor. Many people rely on those weather forecasts. Many people in north Queensland, where we believe we are neglected-certainly the road situation comes readily to mind-would like to know when there is going to be a lot of damage from a cyclone and would like to know that that radar equipment is available and is going to be on track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major difference between the two sides of the House is that when a government presents its financial statements and what it intends to do in the forthcoming year, it is presenting a factual document about what it proposes and has to do. I have heard Opposition speakers on both political sides of the House, and particularly on the conservative side of the House on a number of occasions-not as often as I would have liked, and not as often as would have been in the best interests of the country, but nevertheless on a number of occasions-and they have no commitment whatsoever to this country when they are in opposition. There is never a word about anything the government may have done which will assist and never a word of support for our national interests in Australia and abroad. Promise, promise, promise and mean none of it is what oppositions in this Parliament of a conservative type have always said and have always done.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1952 we saw the last surplus Budget of a conservative government in Australia-in 1952. Sir Robert Menzies-Robert Menzies as he was then-took over in 1949 with false promises about what he would achieve in the Australian economy. We had a sound economy under Chifley, but within two boom years in the wool market and in other areas he had destroyed that economy and had Australia in deficit. For every year since then that a Liberal government has been in office there has been a deficit Budget. Promises have never been kept. He promised child endowment for the first child in 1949 and introduced it in 1950. When the Liberals went out of office in 1973 it was still at the same rate; never altered in 28 years. Yet the present Opposition talks about looking after the family.

I think one of the most callous things that I have seen in the time that I have been in politics is the misleading and disgusting series of advertisements that we saw recently in a mini-election campaign. We had a family struggling to pay off a home, probably in New South Wales where Greiner has put up every form of cost that it is possible to put up since he has been in office, and we saw the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) come on and say, `I'll reduce the top tax rate from 49c to 39c and that'll save her problems and she won't have to go to work'. The woman in that family was probably earning between $15,000 and $25,000 a year. Tell us some time how she will save money if the top tax rate is reduced. The Opposition would be more likely to throw her out of work, let alone improve her position.

Opposition members should have a look at their record. Australians were told through the 1950s, through the 1960s and also through the 1970s that all it was necessary for Australians to do was to get down on the beach and count the ships coming here to cart away our minerals; that that was the natural wealth of Australia and would pay for all of our future needs. That was the policy that destroyed our basic industries in this country. It gave them no support. In my electorate for major industry, textiles, was destroyed by the end of the 1960s. There was no reinvestment, no encouragement for investment, and no encouragement whatsoever for increased productivity or efficiency-because the government of the day saw minerals as the panacea for all ills and was never prepared to look at anything else.

We do have an election coming up and it is about time that the Opposition told us how many Australians they intend to throw out of work under the policies, supposedly Thatcherite, that are being put forward by the economic spokesman for the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). The Leader of the Opposition obviously reads the economics papers. We saw one a few weeks ago he floated around the country-and I understand the adviser who wrote it has been sacked-about savings interest. Records count too, and it is not that long ago that the conservatives were managing this country-and they did so for a long period. What did they achieve? In my electorate, no kid could get a job; it was impossible. I will tell the House why they could not get a job-the economy was in such a mess because of the incompetence of the government of the day and its advisers. The honourable member for Wentworth was one of them, and Senator Stone was another. Because of the incompetence of that government and because the government never did anything it promised to do-not unusual for conservative governments-we had unemployment growing in this country, at a rate of 1,000 every working day when it went out of office. It tried to con the Australian people with the 1982 Budget and it was going to race off to an election in September, but it forgot about Costigan. It forgot that Costigan's report would be tabled in the Victorian Parliament, because it was a joint report. And what did it reveal? Scandalous corruption, mismanagement and tax evasion in this country which the Liberal Party Treasurer of the day had been notified of in early 1979 and still had not done anything about in 1982.

If there is a change of government at the next election and a conservative government with the policies the Opposition is putting forward now is inflicted on the Australian people, we can forget about the slogans about looking after the family. Unemployed families cannot pay their rent, and those opposite had unemployed families all over Australia and the policies they are advocating now, which they have not got the courage to spell out because they are not prepared to tell the truth, will mean more unemployment. There are over a million more Australians working today than when they went out of office seven years ago. Of course they say they can do better. I even hear people in here talking about how terrible the inflation rate is. It is only 50 per cent lower than when they went out of office, that is all. It is lower than in Thatcher's Britain, which they would copy if they had the opportunity.

Opposition members have panaceas and slogans for everything, but their policies are the same as those which nearly destroyed Australia in the 1970s and 1980s. I wonder how many people in this House are aware that when in 1987 we reversed a $10 billion deficit projected under a Liberal Government, with its expertise in management and its competence-I have heard the speech over there so often that is almost painful-there was not one Commonwealth public servant working in Treasury or Finance who had been in those departments the last time we had a Consolidated Revenue surplus. They were not aware of what had to be done at the end of the financial year; no-one had ever experienced a surplus. We had had over 20 years of Liberal governments in that time. The Liberal Government achieved the biggest deficit in the history of Australia in its 1982 Budget. The reason was that the Budget was fraudulent, just like the 1972 Budget. These were immediately before an election which it was frightened of losing.

In my electorate kids can get jobs today. These kids have an opportunity to advance their education but do not have the privileges to get to the ivy league universities. People can live in dignity. There are problems in Australia and there will continue to be problems until we can restore the damage that was done by the indolence, the incompetence and the lies told to the Australian people during the period when the coalition government said, `You can dig coal, iron ore, bauxite and uranium out of the ground'. Who in this Parliament remembers Ministers standing at the table and telling Australians that the uranium industry would provide 500,000 jobs in Australia? That was in 1977 and some of those former Ministers are still in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has never been a Liberal Minister at this table.

—The honourable member should not try to pass that one off. They were Liberal Ministers and they were lying to the Australian people because the prospects were never there. The honourable member was in office from 1977 to 1983. In every one of those years the number of jobs in Australia declined and more and more people were deprived of the right to work. The coalition government even had Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd on its knees-that is how good it was.
—Tell the truth.

—I do not think that word is in the honourable member's vocabulary. I think he repeats it like a parrot but he has never had a commitment to it. Because of the time I cannot complete all the points that I wished to make. Finally, I want to warn people about the Opposition's tax promises. I was here in 1975. I heard Opposition members make solemn commitments to index the Australian tax system.
—A fistful of dollars.

—That was the next one. No more tax by stealth! Everyone who came to this Parliament as a member elected on a policy to index taxes in 1975 voted that principle out a year later. Those members sat here and voted to remove it. The fistful of dollars promise was like other election promises of the Liberals, completely phoney and never intended to be kept. It was introduced in legislation in this Parliament. Within six months it was voted out again. The former Government stole half a million dollars of the taxpayers' money by running a phone-in to tell us what its tax cuts to the Treasury would be. It worked people overtime. Australia faces great dangers ahead. Every one of them is on the other side of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was rather sad to listen to the arrant nonsense that the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) seemed to be re-cycling. It was the sort of thing he might have said when he was trying to get Labor endorsement because that was about the quality of the speech. As for content, there was not any. I have never heard such arrant nonsense. It is rather unfortunate that someone who has been in this Parliament as long as the honourable member has finds it so difficult to find anything worth while to say in a speech that should be important when we are talking about one of the most important Bills that faces the Parliament each year.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this Budget marks the beginning of the closing chapter of the Australian Labor Party experiment of the 1980s. Labor has failed Australia. It has failed Australia both federally and in the States. We have seen the problems that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is about to inflict upon us. We have seen the problems that Labor is now inflicting on Victoria. We are seeing the mess in Western Australia. There is a common thread. It all starts with Labor and it all shows how the Labor Party, its principles and its policies are a failure.

Two weeks ago the Australian Government was given the opportunity to show its determination to push through important reforms for our economy-the chance to turn around the disaster which looms on our doorstep. Regrettably, the 1989 Budget was notable for its omissions rather than its content. Overall this failure summarises the problems facing Australia. It summarises the Government's failures to address the problem and it leaves Australia vulnerable in a way that we probably have not seen for over 40 years. It leaves all Australians facing a high risk future while all the Government can do is put its head in the sand and hope that the looming disaster will somehow miss us, hoping that with high interest rates we will still be like Voyager II, when somehow we can wind our way through the complexities of the world economic system without having a disastrous collision.

Worse still, the 1989 Budget Speech is full of half truths, full of misleading statements and full of claims that even the Treasurer must know can never be fulfilled. Well do we remember last year's infamous bringing home the bacon Budget, where our current account deficit, our balance of payments problems, were underestimated by a mere 80 per cent, where inflation figures were so wrong that one seriously has to question the Treasurer's credibility in the Budget forecast he makes this year. So serious is the future facing Australia right now, and even more serious because of the Government's failure in the Budget strategy, that I feel it is timely to remind honourable members of some history. It is a well known truism that those who ignore the lessons of history are doomed to repeat them.

I believe it is timely to give a brief summary of what happened in the lead-up to the depressions of the 1890s and the 1930s. In the case of the 1890s, the lead-up to the depression was marked by two factors-firstly, by a sustained rise and then a rapid fall in commodity prices and, secondly, by an inflow of capital which financed mainly long term and unproductive investment. From this the combination of falling commodity prices and the drying up of resources of funds plunged Australia into a depression. In the case of the 1930s Depression it was also characterised by a period of high commodity prices and, again, a large inflow of foreign capital. In the late 1920s there were basically three phases of contraction. First there was a severe liquidity crisis. The second was a balance of payments problem, and the third was a loss of export income. It would seem that while there are differences nonetheless we are now poised in a similar vulnerable position. It needs only one or two changes in our present economic state to see these situations being repeated. It is indeed timely to remember.

With the world economy now in its seventh year of growth one would have to be concerned. After all, growth does run in cycles and even though it is always difficult to predict the end of those cycles they do come around sooner or later. It is pertinent to note that the booms of the 1880s and the 1920s were characterised first by the rapid growth of both government and private debt and, secondly, by an increasingly fragile international trade and financial situation. It would not be drawing too long a bow to suggest that similar conditions are beginning to form, although maybe in the distance, as storm clouds on the economic horizon.

We are running a balance of payments deficit which rivals, if not equals, that of the 1920s and already some commodity prices are declining, which would suggest that our export income will not hold up. These warning signs are coming through in many ways. First, and probably most obvious, is that Australia's number one export commodity of the last financial year-namely, wool-is now facing a difficult marketing situation. Wool prices have declined by 25 per cent over the last 12 months and the Australian Wool Corporation, through its grower funded support scheme, is now buying in over 40 per cent of all wool currently sold. This means that over 40 per cent of Australia's number one export commodity is now being stockpiled and not exported. Should the Australian Wool Corporation continue to buy at the present rate-I am not suggesting that this will necessarily happen-it could wipe $2 billion off our exporting account just from this one commodity. It is frightening to think what would happen if other commodities were to follow suit.

The Parliament has heard from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) on a number of occasions about what is happening to the tourism industry with the continuation of the pilots strike, a strike that was so stupidly fanned by the provocative statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last week when he declared that there was going to be war on the pilots, something he somehow tried to forget this week. The effect on tourism could be equally savage. Again, that is one of our major export earners. It is little wonder that the chief economist of one of the big banks recently said, following the Budget, that the forecast Budget deficit of $18.5 billion-a forecast we have to dig fairly deep to find because the Treasurer does not talk about it too much and he does not tell us that it is yet another record-was likely to be very much understated and would be much more like $22 billion.

It is against that background that the Government deserves to be condemned for its failure in its overall policies for the Australian economy. The Budget Speech was notable for its omissions. When the luck runs out they will be discovered and the Government will stand condemned in the history books from hereon in. The tragedy of it all is that, while we have had several years of high commodity prices and an opportunity to reduce our exposure to overseas pressures, the Government has squandered that opportunity. It has allowed high commodity prices to mask the shaky economic strategy that it has pursued and it has left Australia extremely vulnerable.

The Government likes to use superlatives but it omits to use the ones that are frightening the living daylights out of all thinking Australians. The rate at which we are going into debt and current account problems, as I have already mentioned, are likely to be significantly greater than the Treasurer dares admit. We have seen this country going into the red to the tune of $50m a day. It is a record about which the Treasurer does not trumpet. The Government should hang its head in shame.

In the Treasurer's Budget Speech-a speech that one always used to believe was reasonably accurate and factual, rather than one that was based on rhetoric-he made a number of claims. I will deal specifically with some of those claims to show that his speech was full of half truths and was not the sort of speech that a responsible Treasurer should deliver. Certainly, it does not stand up to the test of close scrutiny. The Treasurer referred to the situation the coalition Government left in 1983 and said:
Then Australia's Budget was in the red by a record $9 billion.

Everyone knows that that is just not true. Furthermore, it is known by the Treasurer to be untrue. The last Budget of the Fraser Government-the 1982-83 Budget-had a deficit of $4.3 billion and it was March 1983 when the present Labor Government came to power-nearly four months before the end of the 1982-83 financial year. So the Treasurer's claims in his Budget Speech are patently untrue. Further on in his speech the Treasurer projected forward three years to show the likely reduction in Government spending. Are those projections to carry the same weight as his forecasts for the current account deficit and inflation last year? It would seem that the Treasurer has learnt nothing from his past mistakes. At page 2 of his speech he stated:
Real government spending is cut for the fourth year in succession . . .
I would like to draw the attention of honourable members to Budget Statement No. 1, which states at page 3.4:
Excluding the impact of asset sales, real outlays are expected to increase by 0.1% in 1989-90 and 1.3% in 1990-91 . . .

In other words, for some strange, quirky reason, asset sales are deducted from outlays. I will not question why that has been done, but I would say that, when the Treasurer claims that real government spending is falling and then has to rely on the fact that asset sales are needed to reach that outcome, it is highly misleading. Furthermore, that is compounded by the fact that, when we take out the cuts that have been inflicted on the States, we find that Commonwealth Government spending has increased by 0.9 per cent. So again the Treasurer is misleading in what he says.

I remind the Government of what the Reserve Bank has said about the state of the economy and what Moody's Investor Services Inc. said when it downgraded our credit rating again. It has done that twice since the Treasurer had held that position. It is a record which no other Treasurer in this nation has been able to claim, and surely even the current Treasurer must be ashamed of it.

We would like to see some real effort made on micro-economic reform. We are sick of hearing nothing but details of report after report, meeting after meeting, and so on. Despite the fact that the Prime Minister said that in this term the Government would concentrate on micro-economic reform, to date we have seen nothing but a few more reports and a lot of hot air.

The Government's failure to address the fundamental problems facing Australia leaves us vulnerable in a way that most Australians alive today have never known. It is a concern that must be eating into the future thoughts of all families. It must leave all those who care about this nation wondering how on earth the stewardship of this great country could be put into such irresponsible hands. The 1989-90 Budget Speech will go down as one of the great failures and, as I said earlier, it will mark the beginning of the chapter of the end of the Labor experiment of the 1980s in Australia.

I conclude by reminding honourable member of a warning given by one of Australia's leading businessmen and most responsible people, Sir Arvi Parbo, the Chairman of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which is Australia's largest public company. Three weeks ago Sir Arvi warned us that debt will ruin us if we do not start to cut it. I urge all honourable members to heed that warning because, as Sir Arvi pointed out, time is running out; the luck could run out. If we do not start to turn around the burgeoning growth of our overseas debt, this country's future will be bleak. That future will rest very much in the hands of the present Government. I suggest that the people of Australia will judge the Australian Labor Party very harshly for the irresponsible way it has handled this nation's finances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who has just resumed his seat, I might have suspected that the Opposition had a coherent alternative set of policies to deal with our current economic difficulties. However, the Opposition never puts forward an alternative policy that begins to make any kind of sense. That has been the case each year that the present Government has brought down its annual Budget and, if the debate so far is any indication, it is certainly true of the current Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition suggested that certain inflation adjustments be made to the tax system. Those suggestions were made some weeks before the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) replied to the Budget Speech and they seem to have disappeared into thin air. They have been mentioned less and less as the basic difficulties and untenability of what the Opposition put forward became more apparent. There was also an absurd proposal for a two-tier tax system. That makes no arithmetical sense when it is set against other commitments that the Opposition has made to eliminate other forms of tax and revenue raising measures. The Opposition says that it would cut expenditure in order to facilitate changes in the tax structure, but it has not said how it would do so. All we get from the Opposition is some nebulous reference to the benefits that would flow from micro-economic reform.

Even if one accepted the view that the reforms which the Opposition advocates would yield benefits, they would not be benefits that would become available in the timeframe necessary to affect the current Budget in any significant way, unless one considers asset sales which, as the previous speaker pointed out, produce a spurious impact on the Budget accounts. What the Opposition singularly lacks is a coherent policy framework or alternative. That is the case this year and it has been the case every year the Government has brought down a Budget.

In these debates the Opposition refers to what are perceived as negatives in the current economic outlook. It looks selectively at economic statistics and attempts to present the situation in the most unfavourable light. Under current circumstances, it fixes its attention on the current account deficit. The nature of the current account deficit and its significance must be considered seriously along with the concomitant question of our accumulation of foreign debt, what that means and what appropriate policies there are to deal with the problem.

It is worth reminding ourselves that there are some pretty positive indicators in the most recent sets of economic statistics. Often, of course, the Opposition fails deliberately to refer to them, but at present there are some fundamental strengths in the economy. Firstly, there is employment growth in 1989-90 of 4.1 per cent, which continues a long pattern of strong employment growth, a total of 1.5 million jobs having been created since the change of government, and there has been a significant reduction in the unemployment rate. Looking at the June quarter this year on the June quarter last year, there has been a fall in unemployment from 7.5 per cent to 6.1 per cent, despite a growth in the participation rate. If the participation rate now in the economy-that is the proportion of people of working age actively seeking work-were the same now as it was at the time of the change of government, then unemployment would be significantly lower again than it is. That is not to say that the unemployment position is satisfactory. Certain economists would maintain, and this is said explicitly in Budget Statement No. 2, that if we look at certain sectors of the economy and certain regions, we are getting close to full employment as economists conventionally define the term.

That is an achievement the significance of which cannot be understated. It does not worry the Opposition, of course-it is not interested in that-but the ability of people to sustain high living standards is clearly related to the growth in employment. A related statistic is the continued growth in household disposable incomes. Despite the real wage restraint that has gone on-in fact there have been real wage reductions over the last few years-household disposable incomes have risen on average by 2.6 per cent per annum over the past six years. So that is the other side of that strong employment growth, and the strong profit growth that has also characterised the current period.

Looking at the longer term, what is of enormous significance is the growth in investment. The Budget statements make clear that a very impressive performance is being turned in on that front. Over the past five years there has been average investment growth of 10.8 per cent real per annum compared with an average 2.2 per cent in the previous 15 years. What that reflects is the installation of productive capacity in the Australian economy that has the potential to address our balance of trade and current account deficit problems over the longer term.

I think it needs to be stressed that there is a close relationship between the investment surge that we are experiencing at the moment and the state of the current account balance. The most strongly growing component of demand which has contributed to this current account deficit problem we have been experiencing in the current year and to the fact that it has turned out to be a lot bigger than anticipated has been imports of capital goods. The Budget Papers I think show a 43 per cent increase in endogenous capital goods imports which, while it certainly creates a short term problem as perceived by the financial press in terms of the current account deficit, the balance of trade deficit, does indicate that the groundwork is being laid for increasing the productive capacity of the Australian economy, thereby increasing its capacity to export goods and to replace imports in the future. The importance of that needs to be emphasised.

There has been quite a debate in the media and in the financial press in recent weeks about the significance of the current account deficit and external indebtedness. Perhaps the most well known exponent of the view that it is not anything like the problem that it is made out to be is Professor Pitchford of the Australian National University, who wrote a lengthy article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review recently. While I would not say that Statement No. 2 totally endorses Professor Pitchford's view-that would be a misrepresentation-it certainly emphasises the aspect that a current account deficit, if it reflects large imports of capital goods, has its good side as well. Another recent contribution to this debate which I will just quote briefly is by Ian Harper and G. C. Lim of the Department of Economics at the University of Melbourne, in an article in the current edition of Australian Economic Review entitled `Is Monetary Policy Too Tight?'. There is obviously not time today to go into this sort of debate in any detail, so I will just quote briefly from the article:

With the release each month of the latest statistics on the balance of payments comes a round of public hand-wringing by politicians and journalists over the size of the current account deficit. The Australian public is admonished for consuming beyond its means and indulging a taste for expensive foreign imports. There seems little appreciation of the fact that the size of the surplus on capital account renders a large deficit on current account inevitable, at least without substantial foreign exchange market intervention by the Reserve Bank.

There might be ground for concern if the surplus on capital account were being absorbed by the public sector to finance a deficit in its current expenditure. One could then ask whether adequate provision had been made by the public sector for the repayment of the debt so incurred. However, the budget of the Commonwealth Government has been in substantial surplus in each of the past two years and that of the public sector as a whole is roughly in balance. The funds being drawn in through the capital account of the balance of payments are therefore financing private sector investment.

I give that quotation just to emphasise the point that there is a connection between the current account deficit and this very large investment surge that has taken place, which implies that there are some very strong positives in the current situation as well as negatives.

I shall conclude by making a couple of observations. There are some areas of concern. One is, of course, that one can ask where that investment is being directed. Is it going into the internationally traded goods sector? That is a key concern and is something about which there is some degree of ambiguity. A very high proportion of that capital investment is going into the financial services sector, although the most recent investment survey published by the Bureau of Statistics shows that while by far the strongest growth is in the finance sector, there is expected in 1989-90 to be also very strong growth in the manufacturing sector. So that is an encouraging sign.

However, I have some concerns about the sustainability of that, given the type of exchange rate system we have. I am a little worried that if monetary policy remains too strong and our currency is valued more highly than it ought to be from the point of view of the competitiveness of industry, we will see a continuation of one other negative in the current situation, and that is a very high import penetration ratio-the ratio of imports to sales. One of the dilemmas in a floating exchange rate system is that tight monetary policy means higher dollar, means our industries are less competitive internationally, means a switching of expenditure to imports. That is one of the perverse effects of the current policy approach.

Of course, the Opposition points to negatives. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), referred to that sort of point in his contribution to one of the recent debates. What he fails to mention is the fact that he himself is on record as criticising the Government for the fact that monetary policy was not tightened more strongly earlier than it was. So there is no coherency or sense in what the Opposition has to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there are a few simple facts that of course are not understood by trade union bureaucrats and people who have never conducted a business, whether large or small. In fact there are some simple rules that always apply. The first one is that if one borrows money one must pay it back. In our environment and our society, one also pays interest. The only difference between a Commonwealth Budget and that small business budget is the noughts on the end of the figures. All the same rules apply. They also apply to a typical household, and every woman who manages a household budget knows very well that if her family goes out and borrows $10,000 or $50,000 they look pretty rich during the period of its expenditure but they find themselves in great difficulty if they have not invested that money wisely and it is not able to repay itself. This is something that is totally misunderstood by that trade union bureaucrat who today presents himself as the Treasurer of Australia who came to this place when he was 24 years old with no skills in business and no academic training, and then stood up here and proclaimed himself the world's best treasurer. That is his background. Of course, he is aided and abetted by a Prime Minister who has had two or three goes at business in his days at the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). They were notable for one thing: they went broke.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue before us is the Budget. Let me tell honourable members what it says. It tells us that our trade deficit for the forthcoming year will be at least $18.5 billion, that inflation will continue at 7.5 per cent, that home loan interest rates will be at least 17 per cent and that business and farming interest rates will be 20 to 24 per cent. It tells us that revenue collections by way of taxation will be $91,325m, up from $41,183m in the last Fraser Budget. The amount of tax collected in the seven years since the Hawke Government came to office has more than doubled. Documents released yesterday show that we now owe the world $108 billion net and that we are spending in excess of 17 per cent of our export earnings in interest alone.

When we divide the 1.5 million jobs that the Treasurer refers to so proudly in his Budget Speech into the additional almost $100 billion of the debt that we have contracted under the Treasurer's economic management we arrive at a figure of $60,000 a job-four or five years wages per job, particularly remembering, as we are never told, that 30 per cent of the jobs in that 1.5 million are part time. To create those jobs we have borrowed every penny of the wages paid from the rest of the world. That is where the money has come from. It is very noticeable when one looks at the job growth areas-primarily wholesaling and retailing, with a little bit in manufacturing. Wholesaling and retailing what? The goods manufactured by energetic people in the countries of the world that know what growth in labour productivity means.

What else do the Budget Papers tell us? They tell us that the Treasurer has not had enough. I am astounded by the speculation we get in the press and from the Treasurer and other members of the Government about what the Liberals might do in terms of taxation. Let me tell honourable members what the Australian Labor Party has done. It has introduced a capital gains tax. I read the other day of a couple who sold part of their existing operating business, which they had owned well before the threshold date, to a fuel company because they wanted to pay off their debts so that they would no longer suffer the 24 per cent interest rate burden. They sold a lease on their existing operating freehold business. That was immediately deemed a new asset by the Commissioner of Taxation. Instead of clearing their debt, they still owe $85,000 because that was what the Tax Commissioner raked off from that simple transaction, notwithstanding that they have lowered the value of their asset which they had owned well before the threshold date.

Of course, there is also the fringe benefits tax that the Treasurer said was a means of putting sandwiches back in the brown paper bags of the people on the trams. That was the purpose of that. It was being done for fairness. One thousand two hundred million dollars later there are no more sandwiches in the brown paper bags. We know that the tax burden of low income earners, as admitted by the Economic Planning Advisory Council, has increased further under this Budget.

What about company tax? We specially went to quarterly payments of company tax to even out the effect on the financial system but the Treasurer tells us in his Budget Speech that he has been lending people their own money and that it has got to stop. He will bring back company tax payments-please remember that not every company is a big business-and thousands of small businesses run under corporate structures will have to pay their tax on 15 July, 15 days after the end of the financial year. It is called a notional tax and nobody has yet explained how people who do not get it right at the first attempt in 15 days will be treated when they pay the 85 per cent of their estimate. Will it be like provisional tax where, if people get it 10 per cent wrong, they will be treated like a tax dodger-fined and penalised? It is time the Treasurer explained that.

Other things have come to our notice in recent times. We have had Moody's Investor Services and the Reserve Bank of Australia trying to tell this Government that there are things wrong with its economic management-simple things that any housewife could work out in a minute if she saw her family debt explode at the rate that it is exploding in this nation. What is the Government's response? It wants to shoot the messenger. It accuses one of the two largest credit rating agencies in the world of playing politics. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was on his feet the other day. His mind is so attuned to politics that he does not think there are any honest people in the world. He has a political response to everything. He cannot see that this Government's economic management is killing our country and that people are just telling him the truth.

When our own Reserve Bank joined the ranks of the Prime Minister's critics, he thumbed through the pages of their report to find a line that would congratulate him, whilst ignoring the major statements that tell him `Prime Minister, you have got it wrong. Please fix it before it is too late'. That is the message. These people do not dislike him. They do not want to replace him as Prime Minister. To suggest that Moody's has some political intent on little old Australia is absurd. Some of Moody's clients would turn over more money than this nation. Its reputation has to be protected. And the Prime Minister accuses them of playing politics! What is the basis of the message? We find in the newspapers today that in two or three months the Australian Wool Corporation has stockpiled half a million bales of wool and paid the woolgrowers, giving them the opportunity to buy perhaps an imported header or another piece of farm machinery. But Australia has still got the wool.

Wool and tourism are our two biggest industries. Half of our wool is not being exported, and we have a pilots' strike-and the Prime Minister only wants to play politics with that. He was playing war games one day; the next day he wanted to accuse the Opposition because it said, `Prime Minister, how will you fix it? How will you get check pilots when the ones we have say they will not license anyone, will not license all these people you say you are getting from the rest of the world when countries in the rest of the world have their recruiters over here?'. One airline alone is looking for 300 pilots. Our whole national tourism industry, employing 450,000 people, is on its knees. Our two biggest industries, in terms of their contribution to alleviating our national debt, are on their knees, and the Prime Minister plays politics. He wants to shoot the messenger. One might wonder what he is all about.

Then we have the housing sector, my direct responsibility. What did I find there today? Housing approvals for July 1989 are 12,015, down from the June 1989 figure of 15,360. The Australian Bureau of Statistics tells us that that fall of 3,000 in a month is the biggest monthly fall since 1977. We find that it is also a drop of 3,000 compared to last July. The Government says, `That is great! That is a sign that the Australian economy is cooling off'. It is freezing in the housing sector, and it says nothing of the damage that is being done to all the others who are locked into their houses because they believed a prime minister and a treasurer who told them interest rates were falling. We do not know who is hurting most-those that own a home or those that would like to build one. But it is just another message. We are being told, `Don't worry about that. That's a good sign'. I do not know that it is.

One of the more silly things about today is that the Government has added 40 more members to this place, and each of us has 10 minutes to speak on the Appropriation Bills of the Budget. My time has run out before I have dealt with all sorts of serious matters, without mentioning the Treasurer's remarks the other day about interest rates. This is just another example of this Goebbels technique of telling a lie often enough so that eventually people believe it.

I will close on this point, in the interests of my colleagues. At Question Time the Treasurer told us that part of the continuing story of success in fiscal policy-meaning his own-is the decline in public debt interest, which was one of the fastest growing components of the outlays and is now one of the fastest declining components. That is all true. It went up dramatically under the Labor Government and is now slowly coming down. We find that this year it has come down by $123m compared to $1,200m worth of asset sales! But what is more important is that when we compare this Labor Government with the previous Fraser Government-Government members spend half their time talking about that rather than the future-we see that during the last seven years of Fraser public debt interest averaged $2.296m per annum or 6.7 per cent of government outlays. Over a seven-year period under Keating--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should refer to the Treasurer as such.

—Over a seven-year period under this Treasurer, average public debt interest was $6,779m-three times as much-or 9.2 per cent of outlays, compared to 6.7 per cent during the Fraser years. Remember: he has doubled outlays in that particular time. I could go on but, as I have said, we cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always enjoyable to follow the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the usual diatribes that he produces in this House. He always accuses Government members of playing politics. I admire him for being one of those fortunate individuals in this House who never plays politics!

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to support the Government's Appropriation Bill (No. 1), which contains details of estimates for ordinary annual government services. In an election year it would have been easy for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to have brought down a soft Budget, an election type Budget. But rightly, the Treasurer has shown that he is not prepared to do that. He has quite clearly said that he shuns what he calls gimmicks and quick fixes. The situation of this country is such that we certainly do not want gimmicks and quick fixes.

In the past I have spoken in this House about the economic problems facing this country. During his speech the honourable member for O'Connor mentioned the $108 billion which we owe abroad. One thing that the Opposition has to remember is this: Australia has traditionally been a capital importing country. We started with virtually nothing and we had to build up with money obtained from abroad. We have always had a high debt ratio in terms of our gross domestic product.

This Budget is a responsible Budget. For the fourth year in a row the Treasurer has kept spending increases below the level of inflation with outlays predicted to rise by $4.6 billion, or 5.6 per cent, against a predicted rise in inflation of about 7 1/2 per cent. This has enabled a surplus of just over $9 billion to be predicted. This will be used to retire the Government's debt. This compares with the deficit financing which seems to have been the hallmark of the Opposition over past years. I remind Opposition members that it was the Fraser Government, with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) as Treasurer, which in 1982-83 gave this country the first negative growth in 30 years.

In the last financial year, 1988-89 spending in the Australian economy grew much faster than what the nation produced. That is simply where we are at in terms of our economy. Whilst it is true that some of the spending by business on investment in equipment will generate big returns in future years, much of the spending was in non-productive areas. This has led to a widening gap in our balance of payments, with a consequential rise in interest rates.

This Budget has three key elements which will establish a framework for lower interest rates. The first element is the increase in the surplus, to which I have already referred, from $5.9 billion to $9.1 billion, which will further build public savings. The second element will be a slowing in the spending growth of the economy from about 7 3/4 per cent last year to 2 per cent this year. The final element will be an improvement in the balance of payments as 1989-90 progresses. These are predictions and they are always liable to be wrong, as we found in the previous year. The stark reality is that in the longer term Australia must increase its production so that we do not have to cut our rate of spending. We need an efficient, well managed and productive economic base.

One of the success stories of this Government's economic management is its use of the surplus from the last three Budgets to pay off debt. The Commonwealth's foreign currency debt has fallen from $15.1 billion as at 30 June 1987 to $9.3 billion as at 30 June 1989. The Government also repaid $2.2 billion of domestic debt in 1987-88, and it has repaid a further $2.7 billion in 1988-89. The Government's record contrasts favourably with that of the Opposition. Between 1975-76 and 1982-83, total net overseas raisings were $4.5 billion. Between 1983-84 and 1988-89 this Government has repaid, in net terms, a total of $1.5 billion. It is estimated that using these surpluses to pay off debt has allowed Australia to save $2 billion in interest.

A number of studies in recent years have shown that lower income families, pensioners and beneficiaries renting privately are among the least well off in the community. In last year's Budget, for the first time, an extra payment was made available to families with children in recognition of the extra costs they face. The level of rent assistance has again been increased for those families. These increases will be paid in addition to those already announced and will effectively double rent assistance. The real value of that rent assistance will be preserved because the assistance will be indexed to the cost of living. If one takes into consideration the grant of over $1 billion provided by the Federal Government to the States in 1989-90 for the provision of public housing to low income groups, one sees that these increases represent a major initiative to reduce housing related poverty amongst the aged and other low income groups.

I would like to commend the Government on its retirement income policy which is fully detailed in the document Better Incomes: Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century which was issued by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). This policy is part of the Government's social justice strategy which is about making a fair go for all a reality and redressing inequities in the Australian society. The retirement incomes policy is a commitment by the Government to maintain and improve the age pension while providing better opportunities and incentives for people to increase their living standards in retirement by adding to their income through greater self provision. Whilst the latest changes do not diminish the choice of retirees to take their superannuation entitlements as a lump sum it will allow those who wish to do so to use the lump sum to ensure a continual income to purchase an annuity from a life assurance office.

From April 1990 the social security income test will be put on the same basis as the tax system so that only the earnings part of the annuity payment and not the return of capital will be taken into account in the income test. This will significantly increase pension payments to people who purchase annuities. Tax deductions for personal superannuation contributions have been substantially increased. At present there is a tax deduction of up to $3,000 a year for the personal superannuation contributions of self-employed persons and employees who are not covered by any employer sponsored superannuation scheme or whose only employer support is under an industrial award scheme-the 3 per cent scheme. From 1 July 1990 self-employed persons and employees without employer sponsored superannuation will be allowed full tax deductions each year for the first $3,000 of contributions and for 75 per cent of the excess of any contribution over $3,000.

As time is at a premium in this debate I would just like to finish by referring briefly to a number of other key Budget initiatives. The Government, I am very pleased to say, has responded to the Burdekin report on youth homelessness with a four-year $100m package including increased housing assistance, major improvements in income support, important means to improve the participation in education of disadvantaged young people, upgrading of labour market assistance, and community based health services. There is a $40m package to improve the health of Australian women, an extra $15m to be distributed under the existing mortgage and rent relief scheme, an increase of more than $40m over the next two years for sport, a 64 per cent increase to $118.4m in funding for environmental programs, as well as funding for soil conservation, which is up from $9.8m to $23.2m. It is clear that whilst this Budget is not an election Budget it is a sensible Budget which has been framed in the light of difficult economic circumstances and I congratulate the Treasurer on the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget strategy of continued high interest rates, high taxes, high inflation and a record current account and foreign debt will not put value back into the Australian dollar. Whilst pensioners will be helped by rises in pension rates this financial year, the increase will not fully cover cost rises and that is worrying every pensioner in this country. There is little hope of a decline in interest rates appearing on the horizon for a long time to come. The Budget contains no relief for those paying off home loans and those wanting to build or buy a home. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has virtually given up on his promise in the Budget of last year to get inflation down and this will have a severe effect on the development of housing, an essential need in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Cost rises through inflation-the Budget now predicts 7.5 per cent-will place a continuing burden on every section of the community. The recognition of the squeeze being placed on pensioners is overdue and the increase in pensions promised in the Budget and which of course will in the main not take effect until next April will for the first time lift the pension entitlement to the promised 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Of course the Hawke Government promised this increase for several years but until now has backed off the implementation of this promise. The higher permissible earning for pensioners in the long term and the lift in the tax threshold will of course help. The fine print in all of the proposals relating to the aged and in particular to superannuation has yet to emerge in real detail. No doubt there will be debates in this House when the required legislation is before the chamber. I am concerned because all of this is a spectacle, deferring the real issue. That real issue is the cost escalation, the inflation rate was and the high debt that this nation faces.

The long term proposals, of course, may well be to the advantage of the older section of the community in a period of, say, a decade. Unless there are changes to the financial approach of the Government, unless we see an effective remedy to the problems confronting us, even those designed to help the aged will have a limit placed on them. Of course the real issues come down to productivity and to the recognition of the sale of our bulk products from this country. What do we find? There is nothing in the Budget that gives an incentive to the productive sector of the community. This is evident particularly so far as the farming sector is concerned. Without increased productivity, without the opportunity to sell on the world market and to try to restore a balance in our overseas commitments, then every section of the Australian community is placed at a disadvantage.

The Budget made absolutely no attempt to enhance the competitive ability of primary industry and of manufacturing because of the high cost built into this Budget and the effect that that will have. Of course interest rates are the main issue. Unless the Government comes to grips with the need for increased productivity then we cannot expect to see an improvement in the overall prospects. I want to come shortly to an aspect that has been, I am sorry to say, denied by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). No way in the world has this been recognised by the Treasurer; yet it is significant as far as this nation is concerned. I refer to the ever growing debt that is being established by the processes of the corporate sector of this nation simply because it is pushed into that process. Let us just take the tax structure as we find it as a result of this Budget.

There is much said by the Government and by the Treasurer about a reduction in personal taxation from 1 July. The truth of the matter is that despite that reduction we still have an overall increase of 9.7 per cent in total taxation compared to the previous financial year. If we take individual tax it is up by 8 per cent. If we take the various components of tax there is an incredible escalation. As has been mentioned by previous speakers in this debate, such areas as capital gains tax, of course, become an enormous burden to sections of the community that really are the source of employment and, as a consequence of this tax structure, will not be able to perform in the remainder of this financial year and in following financial years because the damage will already have been done. It will be too late. It was too late when the mini-Budget was handed down in April. It was too late a week and a half ago, yet the Treasurer and the Prime Minister want to deny that.

I am concerned about Australia's net foreign debt, which now stands at $108 billion. The Prime Minister tells this chamber, `That is not related to an escalation in the public sector commitment'. That may well be true, but there is no way that one can separate the public sector commitment from the overall commitment. Let us look at the percentages. We find that government debt-Federal, State and, of course, the various instrumentalities of government-accounts for about 48 per cent of that total debt, while private sector debt accounts for something in excess of 50 per cent of the debt. I am concerned that those corporations that are the big employers in this country have an enormous debt commitment. The borrowings of companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Bond Corporation, Elder IXL Ltd, TNT Ltd, and many others constitute 50 per cent of our foreign debt.

I think it is pertinent to draw attention to the fact that there has been an explosion in the provision of credit. It is not a case of public sector extravagance; the explosion has been caused by the Government's policies. There has been an enormous speculative boom. In the 12 months to May, the level of credit increased by $52 billion or 21 per cent, compared to the previous 12 months. In my view, that is dangerous. Various parts of the corporate sector are facing extreme difficulty. The shareholders, the customers, are worried, and rightly so. This is occurring because of the Government's policies, which are forcing this very unwise strategy. The Government has done nothing to try to correct it. While the United States balance of payments is falling fast, Australia's is going in the opposite direction. That is one of the reasons for the decision made two days ago by Moody's Investors Service.

The Treasurer denies the consequences of these elements which are so vital to our overall economy. He talks of the need for high interest rates to contain the present economic situation. Evidence gathered as late as today reveals an 18 per cent fall in housing starts. This means, in effect, that we are not strangling those elements in this country that are so vital for employment and for the basic well-being of small business and the family unit. We are not recognising that the policies that have been contained in the last several Budgets are not working. They are not correcting the dangers that this country faces. All in all, the Budget is a tragedy for the average Australian and for the average Australian family. It places on the people of this country a burden that is far beyond what they deserve to carry in the years ahead.

It is time for the Government to realise the folly of its policies and take action which will correct the unfortunate trends that are so evident. What must one do to get the Government to realise that something is wrong? Moody's report has been virtually dismissed by the Government. Of course, there are elements within the corporate sector that do likewise, because unless they toe the line with the Government's policy they will be in even greater difficulty. I hope that in the months ahead much of our corporate sector will realise the enormity of this problem and will face up to the real issues. I hope that they will tell the Government that this is a dangerous situation and that, in particular, they will look at the commitment aspect as opposed to the asset aspect, if I can put it that way. In other words, spending beyond one's means and raising capital to do so is dangerous for the nation, and this must be recognised before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat bewildered. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), said that the Opposition would provide a softer economic policy. The Opposition is actually saying that the Government should loosen policy, lower interest rates and allow more money into the economy. That is, without doubt, what the previous speaker was saying. During the last six years there has been a change in understanding and perception by the community which clearly has not been grasped by the previous speaker or by some other Opposition members who have spoken this evening. The Australian community nowadays is literate, educated and sophisticated. It no longer comprises the uninformed people who accepted pap for decades. They now follow the economy. They follow interest rates and exchange rates. For two years they have been asking the Opposition, `What is the alternative? What would you do?' We have heard the answer: `Corporations in Australia will soon wake up and realise that things are wrong'. Corporations have also been saying to the Opposition for two years, `Tell us what your alternatives are so that we can weigh them up'.

SPEECH.PARA: This country needs a good economic debate. It needs a good understanding of what is happening. It needs to weigh up the pros and cons of the various philosophies and ideologies, and the perceptions of the various sectional interest groups. It is not getting that debate. We are getting the same old pap that we have been getting for 30 or 40 years. Quite frankly, it does not wash any more. People look at the opinion polls and say, `This is quite hard to understand. Interest rates are at historically high levels. The Government should be a million miles behind. Why isn't it?'. The answer, very simply, is that the Opposition is dishing out last decade's rhetoric. People are not accepting it. People will not fall for it. They want to hear something of substance.

The most spectacular aspect of this Budget is the change that will develop and has developed in recent years in Australia's net savings. Let us look at the history, and at the rhetoric of the past. Let us look at things such as transfer pricing. I can recall that when I was much younger those on the other side lauded the development of bauxite mining at Gove, the wonderful deal that was being done, and how great it was for Australia. The previous Government presided for 20 years over a transfer pricing policy which meant that there were no profits to Australia. Nothing came back to Australia. The profit was made somewhere else. This Government had to clean up the matter. It took court action to prove that profits were being made, that the prices were artificially low, and had been low for decades. That is the kind of investment that occurred in the past. It is the kind of investment that was necessary because the conservative government, during all the years it was in power, failed to establish an investment capacity in Australia. It failed to establish a capacity for Australians to invest in Australia, because there was no savings pool. If one compares the savings pools in Germany, Japan, Sweden and Holland to ours over the last 30 or 40 years, one must ask: Who was responsible? We will see in the next decade the most dramatic buildup in savings that any nation except Japan has seen.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Standards-Second World War-City of Wanneroo-Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme-Apartheid: South Africa-Fringe Benefits Tax: Sporting Bodies-Keystone Activity Centre

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your recent appointment. I will take the opportunity in this adjournment debate to get a few things off my chest, despite the late hour and despite the lack of numbers in the chamber. In my maiden speech in this place last year I was critical of the standard of parliamentary debate and of the apparent egotistical one-upmanship which occurs, one would say, too frequently on the floor of this House. This week has been no exception to those undesirable tendencies. What I think we need to recognise on both sides of the chamber is that the Australian people are fed up to the back teeth with party politics and with self-centred prima donna politicians. Increasingly the people are saying to us explicitly and implicitly that we are not doing well enough, that we have lost touch, and increasingly they are searching for parliamentarians, not crass politicians, who will evaluate the issues, make objective assessments of their ramifications, come to considered conclusions and apply them in the broad national interest. While I remain a very proud member of the Liberal Party, sometimes such an approach may call for a modicum of personal fortitude and may even on occasion result in a divergence from a party line. So be it.

SPEECH.PARA: I may be relatively inexperienced in the machinations of this place, but I must say that too often I hear the term `politician'; too little I hear the term `parliamentarian'; and very rarely indeed do I hear the term `statesmanship' in the corridors of this Parliament. Robert Gordon Menzies and Ben Chifley were able to combine these three attributes effectively. Why can we not take a leaf out of their book, and why can we not try to return the people's House to the cut and thrust of debate with reasonable dignity rather than degenerate in the extreme to an unruly bunch of opportunists. It is about time that we all got our feet back on the ground. It is about time that we asked ourselves what we can do for the nation rather than what it can do for us. It is clearly about time that we attempted in the Parliament to put this country back onto an even keel before it capsizes into a Third World economic whirlpool.

All of that said, the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) this afternoon on the contribution of Australian men and women in the Second World War, as we move towards the fiftieth anniversary of that catastrophe on Sunday next, gave me some heart that statesmanship may not be a lost art after all. I have been as critical of the Prime Minister in this place in the last year as anyone on this side of the House. However, what he said in this place this afternoon was said with dignity, with genuine feeling, and with an obvious sense of deep national pride and gratitude to all those who gave their lives for their country. The same could be said for the contributions to that motion by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt). Both gave very moving commentary on a matter of great national significance and from a personal viewpoint I take the opportunity to repeat the central thrust of that motion.

I would like to reaffirm my deep and continuing gratitude to those Australian men and women who served their country in that war, both overseas and at home, and my sympathy to the families and friends of those who died or were wounded in combat. I resolve to ensure that the sacrifices of those men and women were not made in vain, by meeting our nation's continuing defence and security responsibilities and by working to preserve and extend the goals for which the war was fought-a peaceful world in which the human rights and democratic aspirations of all men and women are inviolate. It behoves us all in this place to work to that end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I proceed to my subject matter, I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) on the five-minute speech he has just made. It is the type of speech that I, and I am sure other members on both sides of the chamber, would like to hear more often in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I wish to speak on an issue of concern to my electorate of Moore. I have spoken in the past in this House about the extremely rapid population growth of the City of Wanneroo. In 1969, when I moved into the area, it was a shire with a population of 6,000. Today it is a city with a population of 170,000 and can lay claim to being the fastest growing municipality in Australia. The effect of this growth, which is still continuing, is to demonstrate a lack of Commonwealth services in the area. I have raised the issue of inadequate Commonwealth services repeatedly with Ministers since 1983. Without suitable accommodation, services such as employment placement through the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the delivery of social services through the Department of Social Security (DSS) cannot be provided to the residents of the City of Wanneroo.

As early as 8 February 1984 the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Don Grimes, stated to me that consideration had been given to the establishment of a new social security office in the then Shire of Wanneroo and it was included in the overall plan which the Department had drawn up to provide services to the outer metropolitan suburbs of Perth. He also stated that it was unlikely that an office would be operational until 1985-86. It is now the financial year 1989-90 and I am still waiting. In the same month, February 1984, I wrote to the then Minister for Administrative Services, the present honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown). This letter set out in detail the need for a Commonwealth centre building within the shire. It is an obvious fact that as the electorate grows northwards along the coast the newer areas are further removed from existing services located in the south and south-east of Wanneroo. As nothing eventuated from these actions I again raised the issue of the lack of Commonwealth services in March 1987. This was when I received advice of the relocation of a CES office further south, away from the new growth areas.

A letter I wrote to the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations reflected my anger at the time and the increasing frustration which remains with me today. The Minister's response indicated that a proposal for the development of a Commonwealth centre was under consideration at that time. I am still waiting. Late in 1988 my colleague Senator Jim McKiernan and I approached the Treasurer (Mr Keating) seeking the location of a proposed new Australian Taxation Office within the City of Wanneroo. Whilst the Treasurer was sympathetic, he gave strong reasons why he could not agree to it. He obviously was not able to assist in that regard.

In the autumn parliamentary session I discussed with the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) the problem which Commonwealth departments were having in finding suitable accommodation in the City of Wanneroo. A survey of departmental needs for both the present and future was carried out, but there is still no commitment to the siting of either a CES office or a DSS office in the Moore electorate.

I reiterate the considerable disadvantages faced by people in my electorate who wish access to Federal Government services. We have a ridiculous situation of clients having to catch public transport into Perth and then another bus back to the nearest office. I strongly urge the Federal Government again to reconsider its priorities so that better services can be provided for the clients of both the CES and DSS who are living within the City of Wanneroo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your elevation to your new position. I am deeply concerned over the future prospect for community pharmacies in Australia, especially in rural Australia. The events of the day do little to reassure me that we have less reason for concern. The cuts recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal would if implemented constitute an astonishing savaging of pharmacists' incomes. The proposed cuts of 23 per cent would reduce pharmacists' incomes by an average of $30,000 per annum, on top of the 12 per cent cuts made over the last 12 months. What sort of reward is that for people who spend years studying and who then go on to take the entrepreneurial risks involved in setting up shop? Most of these people have taken great personal and financial risks, often seeing no economic return on their educational and capital investment until relatively late in their working lives.

SPEECH.PARA: What sorts of signals are we sending out into the community and especially to our young people-the very people that we need to encourage to train, to study and, in this case, to go on and set up business exercises? It seems to me that we are telling them that the pursuit of professional training and excellence, let alone the risk and worry associated with setting up and running a small business, is something that we as a society will not value or reward. This Government, lamentably, seems to condone that signal. The results will cost Australia ever more dearly, especially if we continue to discriminate unfairly against rural people. There are no fewer than 16 one-pharmacy towns in Gwydir.

TALK.START.PARA: —Baan Baa is one of them.

—The honourable member for Warringah may be interested to know that Baan Baa is not one of them, but there are 16. Quite a few of the people who own and operate those pharmacies told me today that they will no longer be viable if the Tribunal's recommendations are implemented. In fact, they will be amongst the first of the 1,600 or 1,700 pharmacies that we are told may well close if the recommendations before the Government are adopted. One pharmacist told me that he would have to drastically downgrade the services that he provides. If he lets his assistant go, if he works for 55 hours a week, if he refuses to make himself available on weekends, even in emergency situations, and carries very low stock levels he may just be able to break even. But the level of services to the community obvioulsy would be drastically reduced and, furthermore, he thought that, when he went in a few years time, when it is time for him to retire, it would be very unlikely that he would be replaced. Another pharmacist told me that his business, quite simply, would no longer be viable. No more for his community the security of knowing that the pharmacist could be dragged out of bed if the kids got sick at 3 a.m. He would simply have to shut up shop and move on.

SPEECH.PARA: This is totally and absolutely unacceptable. For social and economic reasons it must not be allowed to develop. Those Australians who live in remote areas must not lose any more services than they already have. They contribute enough to expect their right to certain minimal levels of services to be upheld. It seems to me that we have a vested interest in seeing to it that, if we expect them to go on producing the nation's bread and the nation's export dollars, they have the wherewithal to carry on.

In many cases the loss of a local chemist will not merely inconvenience the locals; it will lead to the closure of the local hospital, the loss of medical facilities and the withering of the town. That would be a disaster for many country people. It is all very well for people to complain about the possibility of having to go to the next block, or even the next suburb, to find services. It is altogether another matter to have to drive for hours on end, as many will if the local town can no longer provide adequate services. I note today a communication I received from one pharmacist which reads:

I have never been particularly active because it demeans my professionalism but this Government is destroying pharmacy and I will do all I can to ensure this Government is defeated at the next election.
For the sake of the bush and, by extension, for the sake of Australia, I have no choice but to endorse those sentiments absolutely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week, on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), I opened an important exhibition in this building under the theme `Apartheid South Africa'. I believe that it is most appropriate that this exhibition should be displayed here in the Parliament of Australia. This building, more than any other in our nation, is a symbol of democracy for our people, who each week visit it in their thousands. It is my earnest wish that they pause long enough to examine this exhibition and to reflect on the situation of the black majority of South Africa, who are persecuted and oppressed in their legitimate quest for democracy in their country. In this way, I believe that this exhibition can do much to reinforce and strengthen the will of our Australian Government to continue, and indeed intensify, its strong stand against apartheid.

SPEECH.PARA: This exhibition reveals in stark clarity the reality of apartheid. More importantly, it reveals the strong spirit of active resistance that lives on in the people of South Africa despite decades of ruthless and violent repression. The exhibition has been arranged by the United Nations Centre Against Apartheid, which was established by the General Assembly in 1976 as a unit of the United Nations Secretariat to strengthen action towards the elimination of apartheid in South Africa. The centre has brought together this exhibition as an affirmation of the resolve of the United Nations to counter the iniquitous and devious propaganda of the South African regime.
