It is the hope of the United Nations that, wherever this exhibition is displayed, it will contribute to a greater public awareness about the true nature of apartheid.

Despite changes in the leadership of the South African Government, the political situation in that country continues to deteriorate. Repression of the black majority persists unabated and even the most peaceful forms of protest are ruthlessly crushed by all means, ranging from legislation and the courts, through an elaborate system of phone-tapping and informers, to the use of tear gas, guns, whips and police dogs.

The regime's activities are not only limited to South Africa. For many years the South African Government has vigorously pursued a policy of destabilisation against the front-line states, leaving them a legacy of disruption, devastation and despair. Having visited the front-line states last year and learned first-hand of the bitter effects of the apartheid regime's interference, I am particularly pleased with the recent decision of the Australian Government to increase funding to these countries under its southern African program to $110m over the next triennium.

I would hope that this exhibition in our Parliament will send a clear message to all Australians who seek financial gain by dealing with Pretoria. It is surely time for them to look beyond selfish gain, to cease their collaboration with the violent apartheid regime and to raise themselves to a higher level of moral conduct. This message should also go loudly and clearly to those in the Australian sporting fraternity who contemplate selling their sporting prowess to South Africa. The exhibition has been displayed in several countries throughout the world. It comes to us from the United States and when it leaves here next week it will go the United Kingdom and then on to many other nations. It gives a strong and clear message that apartheid will be overcome; its days are numbered.

I was particularly gratified that so many heads of diplomatic missions here in Canberra found time to attend the opening. It is an indication of the strength of feeling throughout the world against the evils of apartheid. I hope that my parliamentary colleagues will find time to visit this exhibition if they have not already done so. I know that many have.

The exhibition contains a message of hope as we look forward confidently to the complete dismantling of apartheid and the establishment in South Africa of a genuine non-racial, democratic society which will guarantee the freedom and human rights of all its citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it seems right and proper that we all congratulate you on your elevation to your responsible position in that chair. Last night I listened intently and with interest to the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) when he was speaking in the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90. He spoke at length of the Budget increase in the Forward Estimates for the funding for sport. It was a very good speech and I re-read the Hansard tonight. An amount of $230m has been allocated for sport-$43m in 1989-90. The honourable member's congratulations are right and correct. Our elite athletes have needed this sort of response, support and help. No doubt a lot of pride has been generated in the `Go for gold' campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to wind the story back to suburban sport. Specifically, I am most concerned about the attention the Australian Taxation Office is giving to football, certainly at the league level which is starting in South Australia. I challenge the spirit of the Australian Taxation Office in the fringe benefits tax raid that it is perpetrating upon suburban sport and suburban football. Once it has started there, it is its intention to go into other areas. I will close as I started by saying that I do not really think that the spirit of the fringe benefits tax was designed to trap football clubs, sporting clubs and those non-profit making institutions. Everyone knows that no football club in Australia makes a profit. All football clubs do is make the egos of their presidents larger.

I refer to a very well written article by Geoff Kingston, a leading journalist in South Australia who played football at a State and league level. His article, which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser, refers to the fact that young Australians-and I can target this back to the speech of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin)-and the clubs that nurture them are being penalised. The Australian Taxation Office believes that there is a pot of gold, that there are millions of dollars out there waiting to be harvested from the clubs. Clubs are forced to pay fringe benefits tax on simple pie and pastie nights or on cans of coke. League players may have to pay tax on the pasta they eat to boost their carbohydrate level a couple of hours before they play. Clubs have to pay fringe benefits tax at 49c in the dollar in respect of club dinners following a loss or a victory. All clubs, whether they be hockey, lacrosse or certainly league, strive to win a premiership. That is the ultimate. Even premiership dinners attract the tax. Clubs have been sent accounts for guernsey presentation nights. One club has had to pay $12.50 for each of its 40 players who were presented with their guernseys and their sponsors at such a function. Even the $7.50 entrance ticket acquired by footballers who take their spouse, girlfriend or boyfriend to the football are now being rated. Certainly, a lot of work has been done to try to bring this matter to the attention of the Australian Taxation Office.

As I said, the Tax Office is even attacking young Australians from the bush who are perhaps boarding, or attending university or school. They have to pay tax on the room they share and the food they eat. I support the fact that the fringe benefits tax should apply to the corporate sector but I do not believe that section 38s should be forcing clubs to the wall. These clubs have huge commitments and huge capital assets which they have to maintain on a year to year basis. If league clubs are experiencing difficulties, what hope have other suburban sports at the lesser level? I plead with the Australian Taxation Office to back off. There is going to be a lot more work done on this matter. I do not think the Tax Office's image needs to be tarnished. However, it seems that, along with taxidermists, tax officers tend to mess things up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said in this House about the new Disability Services Act and in fact the way in which it can deliver services for those people in our community who suffer a wide range of disabilities. I would like to draw the attention of the House tonight to a particular project within my electorate called the Keystone Activity Centre which I had the opportunity of reopening this week after a massive fire earlier in the year. This program has been run by the Lutheran Church for 18 years out of a number of church halls and peoples' houses. It now has a very large building out of which to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: With the opening of this new centre has come, in fact, a recognition of the kind of service which can be offered to people with disabilities and which does not condemn them to one particular sheltered workshop type of program. The fire-and believe me, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is an ill wind that blows no good-has offered this group the opportunity to meet the challenge head on. Where previously late last year, parents and members of the group found themselves at odds and in fact in some difficulty with the way in which they were going to diversify and the way in which they were going to meet the challenge of the individual needs of those individuals in our community, the reality of the fire forced the issue upon them and they have been able to rise to the challenge.

What we have seen is a very wide ranging, supported employment program with the community taking part. This is particularly difficult in Logan City since it is a very poor area with a fairly high unemployment rate. But employers have risen to the occasion. With the dynamism of Pastor David Preuss, who in fact has been running the centre for some time, and the information which parents now have at hand, there has been a very different approach to the delivery of services. Indeed, just to give honourable members some idea of the kinds of services and the kinds of programs which are now part of this centre, let me elucidate. We have in fact a small mixed business, a corner shop and a coffee shop in which very many of our people with disabilities work under supported employment and in fact provide a very real service to the rest of the community. It is very handy for people to slip into the shop to purchase items, milk and bread and so on, or to just sit and have a chat and a quick cup of coffee. So, in fact the centre has become an integral part of our very own community. This means that not only are people with disabilities given an opportunity to show their talents but the rest of the community is able to share and participate there too.

We also, of course, have an involvement in the sporting clubs which are now offered a trophy service. These trophies, which are made by numbers of people within the group, are being sold. So there is a wide range of activities, services and businesses and we, as a community, appreciate that. As we have just heard the member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) say, sport is an integral part of our community. We in fact participate across a wide range of sports. It is important in terms of integrating people into the community to ensure that some of our disabled people are involved in our sporting groups. Other groups which operate at the centre include classes for self-esteem and a travel club. They offer a very active social life in which many people can participate.

One of the most important changes under the Disability Services Act in terms of raising the self-esteem of people has been the change from people being called clients to being called employees. I know that very many of our new employees under the Disability Services Act appreciate that enormously because they are employed within the community. They are earning a wage, they are contributing to our system and they feel very much part of our community. I think this is very important. This is a very real example of the way in which the Disability Services Act has changed people's lives. It is very definitely an example of policy becoming reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to join with those other members in this House who have drawn attention to the attitude of this Government towards the pharmacists of Australia. A lot of people think that pharmacists earn a great deal of money and that they have things pretty easy. This Government has deliberately set out to reduce the number of pharmacies in Australia by about half. It is a quite deliberate ambition of the Government to force pharmacies to close down. Of course, the result of that policy by this present Government will be to very greatly diminish the health services available to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Who will suffer most from this present Government policy of attacking pharmacies right around Australia? The people least able to defend themselves, the people in most trouble will be the ones who will suffer most from, as I say, this quite deliberate action of the present Labor Government. We have a situation where those of advanced age and, in many cases, those in the lower income end of economic circumstances, are amongst those who depend to a very great extent upon the services offered by Australia's pharmacists. In fact of course, as my colleague from Gwydir (Mr Anderson) has already pointed out, people living in the more remote areas of Australia in particular will be the first to suffer through the policies which are being pursued by the present Labor Government.

The fact of the matter is that pharmacists provide a most important health service for the community, not only in terms of the drugs they dispense-and they often clear up mistakes made by the medical profession-but also in terms of the great deal of advice that they provide to those who are taking the drugs that are prescribed by doctors in the community. To force these people into bankruptcy, to force them out of their profession, really is a most short-sighted approach by the Government-an approach which has been taken solely to try to save a few pennies.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That this House requests the Federal Government not forward any new listing to the World Heritage Commission until approval has been given by the responsible State and local governments.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say what sum Australia is owed from unfulfilled obligations undertaken under the Offsets Program; if so, what sum.
(2) If the Minister is not able to say what sum, why not.
(3) What steps will the Government take to ensure that the obligations are fulfilled; if none is proposed, why not.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has not been given access to figures regarding the obligations of foreign companies.
(5) Will the Government take steps to make such information public.
(6) Are the results of independent audits which monitor the Offsets Program made public; if so, when.
(7) If results are not made public, why not.
(8) What are (a) the number and (b) the sums involved with respect to agreements entered into under the Partnership for Development Program.
(9) What performance measures have been made to evaluate the Program.
(10) Is it a fact that no penalties are imposed upon multinational companies which fail to meet their commitments under the Program.
(11) Has the Minister explored any legal or other mechanisms to ensure that multinational companies are meeting their commitments; if not, why not.

(12) Has the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that the Government insist on payment in cash rather than handshake commitments to ensure that foreign companies meet their commitments; if so, what was the Government's response.

(13) Why are (a) the Australian National Line, (b) the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, (c) the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, (d) Medibank Private, (e) the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, (f) the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, (g) the Australian Industry Development Corporation, (h) the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and (i) Australian National Railways not required to enter into offsets arrangements with foreign suppliers when making purchases for Government projects.
(14) Is the Minister able to say what proportion of foreign content there is in the purchases of the bodies listed in part (13) for the last six years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is incorrect to consider unfulfilled offsets obligations as being sums owed to Australia. Unfulfilled obligations should be seen as the value of future activities to be undertaken by overseas suppliers in Australian industry. Australian firms will be required to provide goods and/or services in the discharge of these obligations.
To the end of the 1987-88 financial year, the value of obligations discharged since the inception of the program is $1.58 billion while the total of agreed obligations is $1.75 billion.

This discharged figure includes some $260 million credits by suppliers in anticipation of future obligations. There is also an estimated further $600 million of obligations implicit on orders placed on overseas suppliers against which deliveries had still to be made. These figures exclude the sales and achievements of firms which have signed Partnerships for Development agreements which are outside the Offsets Program.
(2) See answer to (1) above.
(3) As will be seen from my response to (1) above a very high percentage of civil offsets obligations are ultimately fulfilled.

As a matter of routine, the offsets activities of overseas suppliers participating in the program are monitored against agreed work programs. On occasions it is necessary for my Department to initiate discussions with suppliers in respect of their offsets performance. This has proved to be a successful technique in obtaining compliance. However, if a satisfactory outcome cannot be obtained by negotiation, future orders may be withheld or in a clear case of non-compliance I may publicise the delinquency of the supplier.

(4) A status report of the Offsets Program was tabled, on a commercial-in-confidence basis, at the hearings associated with the inquiry by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts into the implementation of the Offsets Program in late 1986.

In early May 1989, aggregate information on the Program was provided to the Committee in the form of a draft of the text of the 1987/88 Annual Report of the Program. This Annual Report has now been published.

Successive governments have taken the view that details of the offsets activities of individual firms should not be made public because of the commercially sensitive nature of this data. This position was endorsed by the Committee of Review on Offsets (Inglis) in its report published in December 1984.

Nevertheless my Department has been able to provide information, sought by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. In particular, the Committee was provided with information on Government purchases and extracts from the offsets obligations register. This information was provided in a form which protected the identity of individual firms. I have also offered to provide the Committee with a detailed briefing on individual companies on an ``in camera'' basis.

(5) As discussed in (4) above, the disclosure of an individual corporations offsets obligations, activities and achievements is a complex matter. The desire for more open and transparent administration is legitimate. The desire of our local industry to know more about the scale and nature of the offsets obligations and activities of our overseas suppliers is understandable.

Disclosure of this information, however, must be balanced against the equally legitimate desire by overseas suppliers for confidentiality in their commercial activities. They point to the uses to which the information could be used in their home country and by third countries and the effect it could have on their competitive position.
Nonetheless, while I accept these concerns, I have asked my Department to seek ways in which more information can be made public.
(6) At this stage independent audits of the Offsets Program are not conducted largely due to the cost involved.

My Department maintains appropriate records and is in close contact with both our overseas suppliers and local participants in the program. Information provided by overseas suppliers is checked with information from other sources.
(7) See answer to (6) above.

(8) As at 1 May 1989 there are fourteen (14) overseas corporations which have entered into the Partnerships for Development program. At present the program applies only to the information industries area of Government procurement.

Each partner undertakes to achieve a level of research and development expenditure in Australian information industries of not less than 5% of their local subsidiary's gross annual turnover. They have also undertaken to achieve an export/import ratio of not less than 50% within seven (7) years. These exports are to have an average Australian value added content of 70% by the expiry date of the agreement.

Based upon their projections, the corporations involved have undertaken to increase their research and development in Australia from a level $46.2 million in 1988 to $250.4 million in 1994. Similarly, they expect to increase their exports of information industry products from $183.6 million in 1988 to $1083.5 million in 1994.
(9) The setting of annual targets is an integral part of Partnership agreements.

Annual reviews are held to evaluate progress in meeting these targets and to ensure that the corporations activities are in line with the Government's Information Industries Strategy. Independent auditing of the program achievements is also undertaken.

(10) Where a corporation fails to meet its obligations under the Partnerships for Development program, the Commonwealth may terminate the Memorandum of Understanding by notice in writing to the corporation.

Where the Commonwealth terminates the Memorandum, the corporation shall cease to be entitled to future benefits provided by the Memorandum. All offsets obligations and achievements which would have arisen would then be assessed and the net offsets position of the corporation determined. The corporation would then be required to fulfil its offsets obligations in the normal way.

(11) The Attorney-General's Department has provided advice on ways in which the offsets policy can be enforced. The advice may be summarised to the effect that self help methods are more likely to secure compliance than an action for damages.

Methods used to ensure that multinational companies fulfil their offsets commitments are described in my response to (3) above. The high degree of compliance apparent from the figures provided in reply to (1) above, and the fact that it has not yet been necessary for me to publicise the delinquency of a supplier, support my view that these measures are sufficient.
(12) No recommendation of this nature has been made by the Industries Assistance Commission.

In appendix 4 of its 1987/88 annual report the Commission discussed recent developments in the civil offsets program. It suggested that an option which could be examined would be to let contractors discharge their previous commitment by direct cash payment to the Government.

The objectives of the Offsets Program are directed towards the technological development and internationalisation of Australian industry. The Program seeks to achieve these objectives by providing access to international markets, encouraging technology transfer and research and development and by contributing to the development of business relationships between Australian and overseas firms.

It is not clear how cash payments by overseas suppliers would contribute to these objectives. There would in any case be an inevitable degree of inequity between companies which were fulfilling their obligations in good faith and those in delinquent positions but which were able to regularise their position by making a direct cash payment.

The rationale for the suggestion is unclear but it seems to be based upon the premise that there is a substantial value of unfulfillable obligations which need to be addressed. You will note from response to (1) above that this is not the case.

If the IAC's option was to be adopted very difficult judgments would need to be made about the level of direct cash payments to be set in particular cases. This is especially so as the offsets guidelines require overseas suppliers to undertake offsets activities which are internationally competitive.

(13) In its consideration of the Report of the Committee of Review on Offsets (Inglis) in late 1985 the Government decided that the offsets policy should only apply to purchases made by organisations having a Commonwealth bestowed protective advantage. On the basis of this decision the organisations named are considered to be exempt from the requirements of the offsets policy.
This approach was also used in the Australian Civil Offsets Agreement and has been broadly adopted by the States.
(14) My Department does not maintain records in respect of exempt organisations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 31 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was (a) the total expenditure by the CSIRO on research and development into renewable energy resources and (b) the types of such research and development in (i) 1984-85, (ii) 1985-86, (iii) 1986-87, (iv) 1987-88 and (v) 1988-89.
Does the CSIRO have any plans for future research and development projects concerning renewable energy resources, particularly in relation to research on the greenhouse effect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Details of CSIRO's total expenditure in the fields of energy storage, use and management and renewable energy for the period 1984-85 to 1988-89 are as follows:
Expenditure
n.a.

Expenditure on renewable energy constitutes only a minor part of this expenditure. In 1981 CSIRO decided to vacate the area of renewable energy research. This decision followed the decline in world energy prices, especially fuel oil prices and the recognition that Australia was energy rich in all competing resources except liquid fuels.

CSIRO's ongoing commitment to energy research takes into account considerations of efficiency, conservation and emission control. In particular, such planning recognises the critical importance of the need to balance economic and environmental benefits. The Greenhouse implications of energy usage are being developed in the context of this process.

CSIRO has made a large and successful contribution to renewable energy research, particularly to the international solar energy research effort. This research work is now mature and much has been developed commercially by the private sector. In the photovoltaic area, CSIRO's contribution was to develop amorphous silicon films to replace single crystal silicon slices. This innovation demonstrated Australia's international capability, and its commercial application now awaits large-scale production of photovoltaic cells on an economic basis.

In the period 1984/85 to 1988/89 CSIRO research on renewable and related areas of research such as energy storage, use and management has ranged from efforts to improve the efficiency and extend the range of application of solar thermal and photochemical systems to more recent work to improve and develop new systems for the storage of electrical, thermal and chemical energy.

(2) CSIRO is conducting extensive research on furthering our understanding of the Greenhouse Effect and in relation to providing better estimates of climate change for the Australia region as a result of the build-up of greenhouse gases. It has been able to increase this effort substantially as a result of the Government's initiative in providing funding to CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology. Research effort on impacts (and possible technical response strategies) is minimal and carried out mainly under the auspices of the International Geosphere Biosphere Programme on climate change. The proposed Greenhouse Funding Scheme for impact research to be established under the auspices of the National Greenhouse Advisory Committee is a prerequisite for a more concerted effort.

Response strategies to the Greenhouse Effect will need to be multi-dimensional embracing initiatives across the industrial and economic and social spectrum. CSIRO developed technology can play a major role in developing these future response strategies.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes have occurred in the (a) number of staff positions, (b) real level of Government funding available to scientists for research, (c) real level of Government funding and (d) Divisional organisation in the CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology since mid-1985.
(2) What are the consequences of the changes referred to in part (1) for the research work of the Division.
(3) How will (a) Australian agricultural productivity and (b) the effectiveness of conservation policy be affected by the changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Changes to numbers of staff positions in last four years.
The Division has had a net increase of 13 staff over the past four years made up as follows:
Non-replacement of 37 appropriation funded staff who have separated over this period.
45 staff transferred from other CSIRO Divisions following the relocation of research activities.
5 additional staff supported from external funds.
(b) Changes to amounts of money available for scientists to spend on research since mid 1985.

In actual terms the Appropriation funds available per Appropriation-funded scientist to do research (i.e. excluding inescapable salaries and overheads) has dropped from $14,887 p.a. in 1986 to $8,383 p.a. in 1988-89.
However, taking into account all sources of funds, the average fund per scientist have increased from $16,153 in 1986-87 to $28,180 in 1988-89.
(c) Changes in real level of funds since mid-1985.
Figures for the years 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89, in actual dollar terms, are as follows:
Appropriation-
Running Costs ...

Total Appropriation ...

Total All Sources ...
Notes:
1. 1986-87 expenditure was increased by $612,000 by the transfer of an additional research group to the Division following the restructuring of water research activities within CSIRO.
2. 1986-87 include `one-off' payments ($233.2K) associated with Early Separation Scheme.
3. 1987-88 expenditure was increased by $1,063.000 by the transfer of an additional research group to the Division following the restructuring of the then Division of Forest Research.
4. 1987-88 and later Appropriation figures include, for the first time, employers' superannuation contributions in Divisional (as opposed to Organisational) expenditure.
(d) Changes in Divisional Organisation following funding cuts.
The Division has handled funding cuts in the following way:
Restructured whole research programs and made across-the-board cuts.
Subsequently it cut individual research projects which, while important, were of lower priority than other projects.
Most recently it decided to close a major regional research laboratory at Deniliquin in southern NSW, with the transfer of its research program to Canberra.
(2) Consequences of the Changes
These have been twofold:
(a) Important research curtailed or terminated
(i) Mouse plague research has been severely cut with only one scientist now employed where four were involved.
(ii) The Australian National Wildlife Collection, an important national resource, has been cut from four scientists to two.
(iii) The Division has closed research on introduced pasture grasses in semi-arid regions.
(iv) Rangelands research has been severely cut back, with the loss of scientists working on woody weed effects.
(v) Cuts have had to be made in research into the ecology of native forests.
(vi) Bird pest research work has been stopped.
(vii) Research into Kangaroo studies has been reduced.
(viii) Nutrition and diet selection research in koalas has been terminated.
(ix) Research into vertebrate population dynamics in rainforests and the dynamics of the rainforest/Eucalyptus woodland boundary have been terminated.
(x) All rabbit control research other than that funded by the Wool Corporation has been terminated.
(xi) Research into Coastal dune stabilization by vegetation has been terminated.
(xii) Regional scale maintenance of kangaroo numbers can no longer be carried out, and so prediction of kangaroo population trends is now very imprecise.
(xiii) Recently initiated work on deer farming has been severely curtailed.
(b) New important initiatives not begun
(i) Research into ecological dynamics in the Antarctic with the emphasis on impacts of tourism and other developments (the Division has the expertise in terms of mammals and birds).
(ii) Development of benign methods of fertility control for wildlife (e.g. the development of the kangaroo ``birth control pill'').
(iii) Developments, via molecular biological approaches, to induce sterility in wild rabbits, as an effective means of rabbit control.
(iv) Research into lamb losses with and without fox and/or rabbit control.
(v) Research into the influence of management initiated fires on forest wildlife species.
(vi) Restoration of mining sites in the Pine Creek, NT, Geosyncline.
(vii) Risk assessment and potential outbreaks of exotic diseases and pests in north Australia.
(viii) North Queensland rainforest inventory and mapping (which has had to be deferred).

(ix) Developments in the work on distinguishing land degradation from natural change, and on erosion forecasting, are over two years behind. It is hoped that the new Government initiative will alleviate this particular problem.

(x) Conservation management of arid mountain ranges, one of our most important ecosystem types, has been delayed for two years. (It has recently been able to start thanks to funding from the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory).

(xi) Research into how to prevent species loss in the remnant vegetation of the western wheat belt has had to ignore all of the insects, owing to the loss of scientists. Work on optimal strategies for identifying and revegetating critical areas to arrest salinization in the region has also had to be deferred.

(xii) Allocation and management of resources in the Australian coastal zone. The coastal strip from Gladstone to Adelaide will be the country's major focus for conflict over, and competition for, fragile and economically significant natural resources in coming decades.
(3) Implications
(a) Agricultural Productivity

Agricultural development is proceeding without due consideration for its sustainability. This Division has the expertise but not the resources to give this important problem the consideration it requires, in terms of both management strategies and policy developments.

The multi-million dollar problems arising from vertebrate pests (rabbits, mouse plagues, pigs, foxes, dingoes and even kangaroos) are being addressed at far too low a level. Research is well behind where it could and should be for development of effective control strategies, and this influences the cost efficiency for production in the industry and for exports.

The massive consequences of an outbreak of exotic diseases is of major concern. The spread of such diseases will be largely through feral and native fauna. The initial work by this Division has highlighted the need for a change in strategy towards increased emphasis on early detection. The Division's planned program of research into the interactive dynamics of vertebrates in terms of potential disease spread in tropical northern Australia has had to be deferred until funding is made available.

The work of this Division has had a significant beneficial effect on reducing woody weeds in semi-arid rangelands, with a concomitant benefit to production. The equivalent potential for benefits from its work on perennial grass productivity and restoration of degraded sites has been held up by insufficient funding.

The delay in work on efficiency of livestock production through grazing management strategies in arid rangelands, means that governments will be required to continue support for ``drought'' relief programs.
(b) Conservation Policy

This Division is the only federally funded research organisation with the expertise to undertake the full range of terrestrial ecological research. As such, reducing its research effort reduces the objective basis for underpinning much of the development of national conservation policies. This Division supplied the basic information for the heritage listing of the tropical rainforests. It is vitally involved in the production of objective information on the distribution and requirements of fauna and flora in the SE forests (it will be this work which will be used in the future as the objective ecological information in deciding on the woodchip vs conservation debate). The development of this work is woefully inadequate at present, and equivalent work in other regions is not going ahead.

In the areas of wildlife management, vertebrate population dynamics, marsupial biology, rainforest ecology, fragmented ecosystem ecology, tropical savannas, and land conservation and the impacts of possible climate change, this Division is regarded, internationally, as a leader. Within Australia, the ability of the Division to provide the detailed information needed to develop the best national conservation policies is well short of what it should be and in some areas is virtually grinding to a halt.
